story:
About Our Project

This past summer, four student fellows from around the world (Hallie Sekoff, Sandrayati Fay, Katie Grindeland and Lucia D’Onofrio) convened at the Global Arts Corps office in New York City. We came together with a shared belief that art can unearth buried stories and shift indelible barriers.

We are launching this Indiegogo to support Global Arts Corps' current project, a devised production between performers at the Phare Ponleu Selpak school in Battambang, Cambodia and a team of international artists from Global Arts Corps. We believe that Global Arts Corps' work is a testament to the power of theatre as a transformative medium for education and social change.

The goals of this project are:

  • To raise $ 40,000 to cover our artistic team’s fees, filming of our workshops, local translations, stipends and meal allowances for our performers, and per diems.
  • To give these young performers in Cambodia acting skills that will enrich their talent and allow them to have sustainable careers, long after their circus careers have ended.
  • To support our belief that the Cambodian experience tells a story about all of us. Their story is a microcosm of feelings and experiences similar to those of other people across the world who have experienced conflict, war and genocide. We believe that a sharing of these different ways of seeing and listening gives hope to young people struggling on their own to envision a more hopeful future for themselves and their countries.
  • To engage viewers in a conversation about the role of the arts in fostering communication and shifts of perception in post-conflict countries across the globe.

History of our work in Cambodia 

In 2013, under the artistic direction of Michael Lessac, a small group of international artists traveled to Cambodia to hold a five-week workshop with the performers at the Phare Ponleu Selpak art school in Battambang, Cambodia. Lessac and these artists of Global Arts Corps were invited by a collective of Cambodian artists, themselves survivors of the Khmer Rouge period in Cambodia, who had started Phare Ponleu Selpak (Brightness of the Arts).

The aim of the initial workshop was to determine whether the students at Phare would be interested in working with GAC to develop a touring circus/theatre production that would explore life in Cambodia after the catastrophic Khmer Rouge regime. Following an enthusiastic response to the first workshop, GAC returned to Cambodia in early 2014 to assemble a preliminary cast and the elements of a script for the final production. The time has come to return so as to further solidify the production and begin initial planning for a subsequent global tour.

The results of GAC’s initial work in Battambang can best be experienced through our 25-minute video: 


With continued funding and your help, we wish to return to Battambang for two workshops - one in February 2015 and the second in October 2015 to finish developing the production and prepare for an international tour starting in 2016.


Why Indiegogo?

1. In all of our projects, it’s often easy to find funding for a production’s premiere and tour. Individuals and organizations are interested in seeing a project’s impact within their own communities. Before that can happen, however, much time, energy, and research must be put into the production’s development. It is this work--that takes place “behind the scenes” and is largely invisible to our audiences--that ensures the quality and authenticity of our final productions. An extended development period is necessary for Global Arts Corps (to learn about the people with whom we’re working) and our performers (to have time and space to reflect on the stories they need to share).

2. Crowdfunding offers a simple way for our friends and supporters to play a crucial role in the development of this new production. It allows many people to give what they can afford. Donations of all sizes can have an extraordinary impact ($15 will cover lunches for 3 hard-working performers in Battambang!).

3. This work is driven by a passionate belief that the Cambodian experience tells a story about all of us. Their story is a microcosm of feelings and experiences that needs to be shared with people coming out of conflict around the world. We hope that this Indiegogo campaign will help us spread their story and engage viewers in a conversation about the role of the arts in fostering understanding and shifts in perception in countries across the globe.


Where Your Money Will Go


    About Global Arts Corps

    From Rwanda to Kosovo, Cambodia to the North of Ireland, Global Arts Corps has used the transformative power of theatre to bring together people from opposite sides of violent conflict, unrest and war in 17 countries on 3 continents, reaching over 75,000 audience members, and facilitating reconciliation workshops for over 11,000 participants.

    We are an international community of professional artists who use theatre as a catalyst for dialogue, as a way to shift perspectives, and as a means through which to bring about understanding, tolerance and empathy. Our goal is to become a multi-lingual, multi-cultural resource for conflict resolution and reconciliation in conflict zones across the globe.


    Meet the Team

    We have an incredible team of experienced actors, playwrights and musicians who will be involved in the upcoming workshops in Battambang. They each bring their diverse backgrounds to their artistic work and they all share a deep love for what they do. Read more about them below:


    Multi-talented Thembi Mtshali-Jones is recognized as one of South Africa’s most celebrated artists: as a singer, actress and playwright. Thembi first joined Global Arts Corps as an ensemble member in Truth in Translation. 


    South African native, Andrew Buckland’s dynamic combination of visual comedy, sophisticated political satire, clowning, physical theatre and mime has become synonymous with provocative and stimulating theatre both in South Africa and internationally. Andrew first toured with Global Arts Corps as a cast member in Truth in Translation.  He also was a member of Cirque de Soleil and played Sergant Pepper in Love.  


    Having graduated with a National Diploma in Musical Theatre from South Africa's Pretoria Technikon in 2002, Sibulele Gcilitshana is a triple threat – as a dancer, singer and actress. Sibulele was a Truth in Translation cast member and traveled with the company throughout its 24-city tour. 


    Nick Boraine graduated from the University of the Witwatersrand in Johannesburg in 1994 with an honors degree in drama. Since then he has been involved in countless aspects of performing, writing and directing for stage, television, as well as film. Nick toured the world in Truth in Translation and is currently Global Arts Corps’ Associate Artistic Director.

    Clement Mensah was born and raised in Ghana, West Africa. He is a dancer and teacher for the Battery Dance Company and teaches around the world. Clement aims to use the gift of creativity to bridge different cultures and bring generations together through self-expression.



    Arben Bajraktaraj is an Albanian actor from Kosovo. He studied theatre in Slovenia with Minu Kjuder at Drama Studio and in Paris at Acting International with Robert Cordier. He has appeared in various films such as Xavier Beauvois’ Of Gods and Men (Grand Prix du Jury, Cannes 2010), Maïwen’s Polisse (Prix du Jury, Cannes 2011) and J.K Rowlings film adaptation of Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix and Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows.

    Robert Koen is a South African actor and vocal coach. Robert is an original cast member of Global Arts Corps’ Truth in Translation and formed part of the creative team of Global Arts Corps’ Hold your tongue, Hold your dead that performed at Arts Emerson in Boston, Massachusetts.


    Michael Lessac is an award-winning theatre, television, and film director, a screenwriter, and co-founder and artistic director of Global Arts Corps. He is the creator and director of the international theatre production, Truth in Translation, and artistic director of the Colonnades Theatre Lab, Inc. and of the Colonnades Theatre Lab, South Africa. Michael has directed at the National Theatre of Yugoslavia, the Guthrie Theatre, the Arena Stage, the Kennedy Centre and the Public Theatre in NYC. He wrote and directed the feature film House of Cards, starring Tommy Lee Jones and Kathleen Turner and has directed over 200 television shows. He holds a doctorate in developmental psychology, and has taught both theatre and psychology at Universities in the United States.  


    Jacqueline Bertrand Lessac is co-founder of Global Arts Corps and served as Executive Producer of the Award winning Truth in Translation project. She is a co-founder of The Colonnades Theatre Lab in the U.S. and South Africa, and recently produced the GAC documentary film A Snake Gives Birth to a Snake. She received her BA in Art Education and Drama from the University of Minnesota and has worked as an actress in theatre, television and film.

    Finally, a special thank you to Victoria Kanaris for filming and editing our short campaign video!

story:
Short Summary

This incredible Ballroom Dance performance featuring the best competitors in the country, is going to launch a not for profit dance program for girls ages 12-17 who have suffered sexual or physical abuse. Our mission is to empower our students helping them become confident SURVIVORS so they never feel like, or be seen as a victim again.

I lived through a series of terrible events my first year of high school, and struggled for years afterward. I was blessed when I stumbled across ballroom dance and immediately fell in love with it. Competitive dancing gave me the confidence I needed to reclaim my life. I know there is a reason I survived what I went through and I believe it's to help others heal too.

My dream is to have our own studio with an open door policy for any child to be able to learn and practice dance and music. In addition to the start up funds we'll receive from ticket sales, this performance will inspire people to learn to dance and draw the attention we need to make a strong start.  

Please see photo gallery for the names and titles of the dancers, and be sure to check them out on Youtube!

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is $45,000. Broken down its $18,500 to pay the dancers and cover their expenses; $10,500 to rent an event space large enough, and the rest is for lights, music, photography and video production, program and ticket design/printing, rental and setup of the dance floor, mandatory event insurance and approved workers etc. All of that actually comes to $41,920 but we're taking into account the fees associated with crowd funding and leaving a little room for unexpected costs by rounding up to an even $45,000. 

Every child should have something that motivates them, keeps them active, something to distract them from day to day problems, that allows them to express themselves. This is even more true for those who have been abused. Knowing you're helping to provide this opportunity is bound to give warm and fuzzy feelings :) and the perks we're offering are pretty awesome too. These dancers are breathtaking, just imagine seeing all of them in a high quality video with the whole dance floor to themselves.You also have the option of seeing them in person or better yet having a picture taken with them after watching the show! This is a rare opportunity as they are usually either teaching or competing in different places around the U.S. and the World.

 

Why have a performance instead of using all this money to teach?

In order to really make a difference we have to be here long term. My biggest fear is that we would have initial support and be able to give girls the opportunity to do something they love, only to have it fall apart due to a lack of funding. It would be devastating. Anyone who has been a part of a non profit knows how difficult it can be to receive grants, loans, donations etc. We plan on minimizing these obstacles by becoming a successful business, to allow us to support this program ourselves.

I've had the privilege of watching these amazing dancers in person and I've felt the collective energy they create in an audience. It would make just about anyone want to take dance lessons. Every lesson a paying adult buys from our studio also provides free lessons for the students in our program. Every pair of shoes we sell, every ball gown we rent, everything gives us the income that ensures the success of this project and these children. Think of this performance as one giant ad campaign/launch party to announce who we are, what we're doing, and most importantly why it needs to be done. 

Of course I hope we meet our goal but if we don't, all the money we do receive will go toward teaching a small number of girls less often.

The Impact

Dancing is not only a breathtaking art, it can also be a tool. "To touch, to move, to inspire. This is the true gift of dance" -Aubrey Lynch. Through art people can express and understand things that can't be explained otherwise.

Art serves no other purpose than to make us feel something, to help people connect. It would make sense then, that a group of people whose most common ailment is feeling numb or out of touch with themselves, would need the therapeutic benefits of art the most.

In Washington State, 1 in 4 girls under the age of 18 has been a victim of some form of sexual abuse. Diamond Ballroom Dance Center's goal is to use the powerful life lessons dance has to offer to redirect the lives of girls who are "at risk". All the issues that can arise after a traumatic experience can easily lead to further problems. Depression, further abuse, alcoholism and drug addiction are all pitfalls that are extremely difficult to avoid or overcome without a solid support system.

Diamond Ballroom will provide survivors with a support system of teachers, mentors and peers that reward them for their effort in school and in therapy with ballroom dance lessons.

Ludovic Morlot, Music Director for the Seattle Symphony said "I believe in the intrinsic power of the arts to enrich our lives, and that the influence of the arts can be substantial and transformative, especially for young people." Working in cooperation with parents or guardians and therapists, we will help girls focus on their strengths to build confidence on and off the dance floor. The mental control that develops to quiet nervousness before a competition translates into everyday life to help those with anxiety. With frequent and consistent exercise the body is strengthened and better able to protect and heal itself from injury or illness.

The positive effects of dance are countless but possibly one of the most important lessons students learn is how to build healthy relationships. Ballroom dance is built on a partnership; without proper respect and communication it can become dysfunctional. Practicing these and other skills now with their peers and families will help them maintain positive relationships with others for the rest of their lives.

A favorite quote of mine is “A thousand candles can be lighted from the flame of one candle, and the light of the candle will not be diminished." Helping one disadvantaged child is not simply that, we're creating a chain reaction to provide stronger parents for future generations.

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell us why you love dance! Watching or participating. Quotes from letters we receive can be displayed on a projector during the show. Seeing how many people love this art is very inspiring to audiences, students, and us.

Become our "business partner". Promotions increase exposure and bring new customers. You can strengthen your own business as well as support a good cause by letting us sell gift cards or certificates at discounts that aren't as heavy as the websites most commonly used would ask.

Last but certainly not least, use the Indiegogo share tools and tell people about us. If you like what you see, please say so, word of mouth can work wonders!

story:
About the Play

Zadie and Adso have found themselves in a beautiful Udaipur hotel. Zadie is desperate to forget the flood that took her grandmother. Adso is trying to forget England. As monsoon season starts, and the hotel starts to feel smaller and smaller they will have to learn to swim or find out what is At the Bottom of the Flood.

 

What This Is All About

 

I am raising money to fund a presentation of At the Bottom of the Flood at Dixon Place, a theater on the Lower East Side, on June 27th. I have been working on this play for awhile now. In December it was given a beautiful reading at the Geraldine Page Salon. This time I would love an opportunity to present the work in a fully realized way

The money that is donated will help me pay actors, a graphic designer, sound and light designers, and key buy set pieces.

 

About us

LaShea Delaney is a graduate of New York University's Tisch School of the Arts and  holds an MFA from the Brooklyn College play writing program. She makes work that belongs in boxes, bathtubs and bars. LaShea's work has been performed at the Institute of Contemporary Art in London, Dixon Place, JimmyÂ’s 73, The Bowery Poetry Club , Barbez, The Geraldine Page Salon and a few other places she'll talk to you about later.... if you'd like. LaShea is a Himan Brown Award Winner, a New Georges Fellow and a former MacDowell Resident.

 

Pirronne Yousefzadeh has directed and developed work at The Public/Joe's Pub, New York Theatre Workshop, Ars Nova, Soho Rep, Playwrights Horizons (Sam French Festival), The Woodshed Collective (The Tenant: Best of 2011, The L Magazine), Noor Theatre, HERE Arts Center, New York Musical Theatre Festival, Ensemble Studio Theatre, The Cherry Pit, Atlantic Theater School, Bowery Poetry Club, Collective: Unconscious, Emerging Artists Theatre, Brooklyn Lyceum, Williamstown Theatre Festival, Actors Theatre of Louisville, Two River Theater Company, Milwaukee Rep, Berkshire Fringe Festival, Power Plant Productions, Walnut Street Theatre, Philadelphia Shakespeare Theatre, and Hangar Theatre, where she was a 2006 Drama League Directing Fellow. Pirronne has assisted Anne Bogart, both on Who Do You Think You Are (SITI Company), and at the 2007 Training Intensive in Saratoga Springs, where she trained extensively in Suzuki and Viewpoints. She has also assisted Leigh Silverman (world premiere of Coraline), Tina Landau (world premiere of Paula Vogel's A Civil War Christmas), Anne Kauffman, Kip Fagan, Aaron Posner, Eleanor Holdridge, and Joseph Hardy, among others. Pirronne received her M.F.A. in Directing from Columbia University, where she was a Shubert Presidential Fellow and Matthews Fellowship recipient. Pirronne was among five directors chosen to take part in a course in collaboration at NYU's Tisch School of the Arts, taught by Oskar Eustis and Rinne Groff. She trained at Shakespeare's Globe in London, and graduated summa cum laude with a B.A. in Theatre and English Literature from Washington University. She is an Emerging Artist of Color Fellow at New York Theatre Workshop and the Interim Fellowship Coordinator, member of the 2011 Lincoln Center Directors Lab, New Georges Affiliated Artist and member of The Jam, member of the Old Vic/New Voices Network, and an alumna of the 2009-10 Soho Rep Writer/Director Lab, Ensemble Studio Theatre's Resident Director Program and Drama League Directors Project. She teaches acting and Viewpoints at Bard High School Early College, and is a directing mentor at Fordham University and a guest director at Ramapo College. With support from New York Theatre Workshop, New Georges, and The Space at Ryder Farm, Pirronne is currently developing a new ensemble-based piece, The Food Play (Working Title), with playwrights Nastaran Ahmadi, Lauren Feldman, Charise Castro Smith, Leah Nanako Winkler, and a company of actors. www.pirronne.com
story_txt:
About the Play
Zadie and Adso have found themselves in a beautiful Udaipur hotel. Zadie is desperate to forget the flood that took her grandmother. Adso is trying to forget England. As monsoon season starts, and the hotel starts to feel smaller and smaller they will have to learn to swim or find out what is At the Bottom of the Flood.
 
What This Is All About
 
I am raising money to fund a presentation of At the Bottom of the Flood at Dixon Place, a theater on the Lower East Side, on June 27th. I have been working on this play for awhile now. In December it was given a beautiful reading at the Geraldine Page Salon. This time I would love an opportunity to present the work in a fully realized way
The money that is donated will help me pay actors, a graphic designer, sound and light designers, and key buy set pieces.
 
About us
LaShea Delaney is a graduate of New York University's Tisch School of the Arts and  holds an MFA from the Brooklyn College play writing program. She makes work that belongs in boxes, bathtubs and bars. LaShea's work has been performed at the Institute of Contemporary Art in London, Dixon Place, JimmyÂ’s 73, The Bowery Poetry Club , Barbez, The Geraldine Page Salon and a few other places she'll talk to you about later.... if you'd like. LaShea is a Himan Brown Award Winner, a New Georges Fellow and a former MacDowell Resident.
 
Pirronne Yousefzadeh has directed and developed work at The Public/Joe's Pub, New York Theatre Workshop, Ars Nova, Soho Rep, Playwrights Horizons (Sam French Festival), The Woodshed Collective (The Tenant: Best of 2011, The L Magazine), Noor Theatre, HERE Arts Center, New York Musical Theatre Festival, Ensemble Studio Theatre, The Cherry Pit, Atlantic Theater School, Bowery Poetry Club, Collective: Unconscious, Emerging Artists Theatre, Brooklyn Lyceum, Williamstown Theatre Festival, Actors Theatre of Louisville, Two River Theater Company, Milwaukee Rep, Berkshire Fringe Festival, Power Plant Productions, Walnut Street Theatre, Philadelphia Shakespeare Theatre, and Hangar Theatre, where she was a 2006 Drama League Directing Fellow. Pirronne has assisted Anne Bogart, both on Who Do You Think You Are (SITI Company), and at the 2007 Training Intensive in Saratoga Springs, where she trained extensively in Suzuki and Viewpoints. She has also assisted Leigh Silverman (world premiere of Coraline), Tina Landau (world premiere of Paula Vogel's A Civil War Christmas), Anne Kauffman, Kip Fagan, Aaron Posner, Eleanor Holdridge, and Joseph Hardy, among others. Pirronne received her M.F.A. in Directing from Columbia University, where she was a Shubert Presidential Fellow and Matthews Fellowship recipient. Pirronne was among five directors chosen to take part in a course in collaboration at NYU's Tisch School of the Arts, taught by Oskar Eustis and Rinne Groff. She trained at Shakespeare's Globe in London, and graduated summa cum laude with a B.A. in Theatre and English Literature from Washington University. She is an Emerging Artist of Color Fellow at New York Theatre Workshop and the Interim Fellowship Coordinator, member of the 2011 Lincoln Center Directors Lab, New Georges Affiliated Artist and member of The Jam, member of the Old Vic/New Voices Network, and an alumna of the 2009-10 Soho Rep Writer/Director Lab, Ensemble Studio Theatre's Resident Director Program and Drama League Directors Project. She teaches acting and Viewpoints at Bard High School Early College, and is a directing mentor at Fordham University and a guest director at Ramapo College. With support from New York Theatre Workshop, New Georges, and The Space at Ryder Farm, Pirronne is currently developing a new ensemble-based piece, The Food Play (Working Title), with playwrights Nastaran Ahmadi, Lauren Feldman, Charise Castro Smith, Leah Nanako Winkler, and a company of actors. www.pirronne.com

story:
TheatreRUN's Story

Hello Dear Friends, Family and Arts supporters. I'm Adam Paolozza. I'm Artistic Director of TheatreRUN, an award winning independent theatre company based in Toronto, Canada. We create new plays and promote the growth of theatre through offering affordable workshops to professionals and amateurs. We also present internationally renowned artists to teach and perform with us. Sometimes, we like to make work in French. We have produced critically acclaimed commercially successful work (our show SPENT was a big hit and is playing off-off-Broadway in the Spring) and we tour internationally. We played a show in China this fall!
We believe that making theatre is important because theatre tells us stories about who we are. Theatre connects us to the past and gives us a glimpse towards the possiblilities of the future. It happens live, in the present. It brings people together. We think, in this day and age, that this is very important. We hope you feel the same way.

SO, WHAT DO HEAVY METAL, MIME AND DOSTOEVSKY HAVE IN COMMON?? ...They all come together in our new show, The Double!

Weâ€™re debuting this off-beat new work in February at the Factory Theatre in downtown Toronto. It's a musical adaptation of a classic novella by Dostoevsky called The Double. It's the story of a mild mannered, hard working guy, like you or me, who goes a little bit mad when he runs into a man who is, in every way, his double!
The show is a comedy...imagine a bunch of vaudeville performers who decided to get together and mix it up with Mime, Double Bass and Russian Lit...sort of like The Office meets Dostoevsky. We think it will make you laugh...and wince!

Once again, it's all happening at the Factory Theatre from February 3-19, 2012!

We are also very excited that this piece marks a new collaboration with Arif Mirabdolbaghi, the bass player from the award-winning Canadian metal band Protest The Hero. Heâ€™s dark, mysterious and plays a mean Double Bass...heâ€™s also pretty cute...

What Your Help Means To Us!

We're a small company and we survive on a mixture of arts grants, ticket sales and our own blood, sweat & tears. Oh, and the support of friends...that's where YOU come in.
When we make a new show it's an investment: we put all of our passion and resources into getting it produced â€“ sometimes we have to start small and hope it will grow. Many big shows (like Rent, for example) started off like that and got very big, employing many artists for many years. That's where your investment pays off: your donation will allow us to create a show that will continue to play for years to come... HOW, you ask?

RUNNING OUT OF TIME and THE GREATEST SHOW YOU NEVER HEARD OF...

Itâ€™s tough working on a shoestring budget. Usually we have to make shows faster than bigger theatres. This gives our work an air or urgency and excitement but it can also prevent us from going deeper into what we are creating. Sometimes potentially great shows are botched because we run out of time. And, once the show is ready, we need people to come and see it, right? Many a great show suffered a premature death because no one heard about it. Thatâ€™s where a publicist comes in, an expensive but necessary part of the team. A publicist will also ensure that the show is covered by the press. This will get bums in seats as well as helping the future of the show.

Your Investment and How Weâ€™ll Use It

So, with your help we are looking to raise $3000 to offset our budget shortfall. Your donations will go towards:

â€¢ paying for an extra week of work
â€¢ paying the salary for 3 actors and 2 designers during this week
â€¢ paying for the rehearsal space for us to work in
â€¢ And finally it will help us afford to hire a top publicist so we can spread the word about the show

Weâ€™ve already invested our own money into the project and we have received funding from the Toronto Arts Council and the Ontario Arts Council. This means the project will happen whether we reach our funding goal or not. As they say, the show must go on. But if we do not reach our full funding goal we will still use whatever money we raise to fund as many extra days of rehearsal as we can, so the money will still go directly to the artists. Every little bit will help, I assure you.
We've assembled a team of some of the brightest, up-and-coming artists in Canadian theatre. Helping them work for another week may not seem like a lot but it is huge - it allows us the extra time to focus on providing the best possible experience for us and you, our audience.

Whatâ€™s In It For You!

We are also offering special 'perks' for donating. See the details in the â€œPerksâ€ section of this page...

Other Ways You Can Help

And if you really cannot donate at this time but believe in the project as we do, there are other ways you can help. You can:

â€¢ spread the word to your friends and invite them to donate
â€¢ come and see the show when it opens
â€¢ follow the progress of the show at www.theatrerun.wordpress.com

Sometimes just spreading the word can help in ways you cannot imagine! Thanks!

story:
My name is Jae Antoinette Broderick and I'm a storyteller (writer/director/actor/dancer) born in Jamaica and raised in America.

In 2004 while on a trip to the islands, I stumbled onto an amazing story that would change my life. So I moved to New York City and focused on FORA, a musical inspired by my experiences with the romance and the rhythms of island life, the vibrant, hilarious people I found there and the universal reality of what we love and what we leave behind.

FORA tells the story of the tiny, mythical island of Forafu, its people, its history and brings its heart to life on stage using the music of the islands - reggae, soca, calypso as well as rock, big band and that classic Broadway sound.

The goal of this campaign is to raise funds for a workshop for FORA, at the end of which we will mount a Staged Reading and record key tracks for future promotion.
Your contribution will be an enormous help in getting FORA from the page to the stage. Projected budget for an AEA Staged Reading (29 hours) is as follows:

Actors: $1700
Musicians: $500
Stage Manager: $250
Musical Director: $500
Rehearsal Space:$1400

**Total: $4,850

**Please note that this is a conservative estimate which allows rooms for unforeseen expenses. The balance of funds will be used for miscellaneous administrative expenses as well as the studio portion of the workshop - recording the FORA demo CD.

Additionally, you can help by becoming a FORA Social Media Ambassador! For details contact me at jae@forathemusical.com

Please have a look around the site to see the work on FORA so far. They say a journey of a thousand miles starts with a single step.

Walk with me :-)

Thanks so much,
Jae

story:
Hello...

If you’re reading this you most likely know me and even seen me at work on stage. If not, allow me to introduce myself…I’m Jose and yes I’m an actor / writer.

I am a LaGuradia Performing Arts H.S. alumni currently pursuing a degree in Theatre at Lehman College. Theatre is what I love and being an artist is who I am. After years of pursuing a career in Theatre I have decided to take matters into my own hands.

The Goal

This summer I intend to put up my very own play titled “Out of My Mind.” It’s an original piece which I wrote about the extreme measures some of us take to pursue our dreams. Here’s a quick synopsis…

Joe is an aspiring playwright who moved to New York with dreams of making it big on Broadway. His play is most likely to get the Tony but there’s only one problem; he hasn’t written it yet. Consumed with working side jobs to survive, Joe has no time to write. Wishing there was a way to eliminate the bills and create more time, Joe desperately comes up with a “brilliant” idea. He decides to become a patient at a local mental institution to avoid paying bills and create all the time he needs to write his play. Perfect, right? All he has to do is put on the performance of a lifetime to get instituted. Unfortunately things don’t turn out as planned as it was easier getting in then getting out. There’s a fine line between Broadway and the looney house?      

The play is very much art imitating life as it is inspired by the realities of any artist pursuing the dream and having to deal with “side jobs” just to survive. Hopefully no one has ended up in a mental institution (although it wouldn’t be a stretch in this business).

Your Donations

Your donations will go into mounting up this production. You will make it possible for us to fund the following; Theatre space, rehearsal studio, cast promotional pics, industry invitation packages, hiring tech crew, ushers, dvd promos and so much more. I am planning to raise $2,000 to cover all of this while you can enjoy the “Perks” in donating it.

PLEASE SEE PERK SECTION TO SEE WHAT YOU GET.

Show Dates

The show will go up in June of this year at a local theatre in Manhattan. Depending on your contributions it will determine which space we get and what dates are available. Please email us at – ACrazyPlay@gmail.com to receive all the shows information and website availability.

Note: The play is also pending on a playwriting festival and is currently under the consideration process.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please send the link to this video and project to your friends and family. And if you can think of anything else to help us, we'd great appreciate it. Thank you so much for your time and reading and supporting this endeavor. 

 

Special thanks to Ed Peralta who made this video possible.

story:
About Soup Can Theatre

Soup Can Theatre is a vibrant Toronto-based theatre company dedicated to the reinterpretation of classic theatre for a twenty-first century audience. Our aim is to use existing works as a means to explore and comment on contemporary issues and societal challenges, and in so doing, to offer our audiences a theatrical experience that is both entertaining and enriching.

Since our inception in 2008, we have built a highly successful track record; our productions have played to sold out houses, garnered glowing accolades from the press and audiences alike (including five star reviews of our two most recent shows), and earned us a reputation as a company on the rise. Our creative team is graced with some of Toronto’s most notable young artists; our past and present collaborators have also performed in or worked on shows produced by or in association with Mirvish Productions, The Canadian Opera Company, The Shaw Festival, The Luminato Festival, The Banff Centre, and The Blyth Festival. Furthermore, our work has been singled out for recognition by Toronto’s theatre community with three ‘My Theatre’ Award nominations and one win, one ‘Broadway World’ Award nomination, and participation in the coveted ‘Best of Fringe’ program.

 

About Our Production of Antigone

We are currently in rehearsals for our next exciting project: a visceral and physical adaptation of the legendary Greek tragedy Antigone that will draw present-day inspiration from the searing images of the 2010 G20 Summit protests and the worldwide ‘Occupy’ movement.

The story of Antigone, which centres on a defiant young woman’s quest to honour her two brothers who die fighting on opposite sides of a senseless war, is symbolic of today’s politically divisive climate and offers a compelling artistic opportunity to examine themes of social justice and humanity’s present and historic penchant for bilateral conflict.

 

Why We Need Your Help

Theatre is not a profitable art form. This is especially true for the Fringe Festival where each company only has seven performances, and the average income per ticket sold is less than 9 dollars. Expenses, like rehearsal space at 15-20 dollars an hour, add up all too quickly, and breaking even is never guaranteed.

Next to our artistic objectives, one of our main goals is to support our artists and collaborators. Your donations will not only help us cover production costs, but more importantly, they will also help us provide our cast and crew with honoraria as compensation for their talent, dedication, and hard work. The life of an independent artist is not an easy one, but your generosity can help change that reality.


What’s in it for You?

Your generosity won’t go unrewarded! Check out our unique perks to the right. You could get free tickets to the show, personalized poetry, signed posters, a special brunch date with our friendly director and one of our stars, exposure for your company or organization (if applicable), and more!

(Please note that Indiegogo uses US funds which means you may see a small discrepency between the figures listed to the right and the actual transaction amount depending on the currency conversion.) 

How Else Can You Help?

We understand if you aren’t in a position to make a financial contribution. You can still help us by spreading the word about our IndieGoGo campaign and our Fringe show via Facebook, Twitter, email (check out the convenient buttons above), word-of-mouth, or any other means you can think of.

Also, if you have some other talent or service you think might be useful to us, please feel free to drop us a line! We are always happy to accept favours in exchange for free ad space in our printed programs and on our website!

 

Cast & Crew:

Directed and Conceived by: Scott Dermody

Produced by: Sarah Thorpe, Scott Dermody, and Justin Haigh

Featuring: Glyn Bowerman, John Chou, Adriana Crivici, Thomas Gough, Leah Holder, Daniel Kim, Kathryn Malek, Michael McLeister, Heather Motut, Chloe Payne, Cydney Penner, and Aaron Rothermund

Stage Manager: Alice Ferreyra
Set Designer: Courtney Cathers
Costume/Prop Designer: Morgan-Leigh Hearty
Sound Designer: Mike Rocha
Tech Director: Randy Lee
Assistant Stage Managers: Gabe Nylund and Leslie Thorpe-Dermody

 

Our Website and Social Media

www.soupcantheatre.com

www.facebook.com/groups/soupcantheatre/

www.twitter.com/soupcantheatre

story:
Send the "MARIACHI" dancers to Brussels

(español vease abajo)

TEMPESDANZA company has been invited to perform an artistic residency at DANSCENTRUMJETTE in Brussels during August this year. 

  • This residency is a unique oportunity for us to project our work to Europe.
  • We want o bring our special Mexican flavoured Contemporary Dance to Europe.
  • DANSCENTRUMJETTE in Brussels is the renowned working space of choreographers like David Zambrano, Julyen Hamilton and David Hernandez.

Our Company TEMPESDANZA

has been working in Xalapa, Veracruz, Mexico since 2006. We have been producing at least one new program per year, presenting it in different theatres and public spaces. We are dedicated to:

  • Creation, exploration and investigation in Contemporary Dance, Improvisation, Instant Composition and Contact Improvisation
  • Promotion of Contemporary Dance and Dance Theatre
  • Education in dance and movement for people of all social and economic backgrounds.
  • Building new public for Contemporary Dance

AWARDS

  • 2009 CACHO 'E TABLA "Best performance"
  • 2010 CACHO 'E TABLA "Best dance piece"
  • 2011 scholarship PECDAV
  • 2011 Choreography Prize Culiacán/Sinaloa

 

We are

  • Lou Sturm: dancer, choreographer, multi-media artist, Somatic Facilitator
  • Guiedana López: dancer, actress, yogi from Oaxaca, Mexico
  • Maura González: dancer, originally from Puebla, Mexico; before APocAPoc Company
  • Yohualli V. González: Visual and sound artist
 

We need $5,850

  • The listed costs only consider transportation for the 4 of us, acomodation and food.
  • None of us will receive any salary during the residency.
  • Our project costs in total $11,850
  • We already have $6,000
  • Unfortunately, August is high season for flights to Europe and each flight ticket (MEX-BRU-MEX) costs minimum $1,350

Links of TEMPESDANZA

  • http://blog.udlap.mx/danza/2011/09/19/estreno-estatal-de-la-compania-tempesdanza-%E2%80%9Cololiuqui-abstractions%E2%80%9D-en-la-udlap/
  • http://holaxalapa.com/2011/12/17/tempesdanza-regresa-con-puras-instantaneas-en-la-rueca-de-gandhi/
  • http://www.imagendelgolfo.com.mx/resumen.php?id=78405
  • http://www.xalapadigital.com/?p=1871
  • http://xalapa.tipz.mx/tempesdanza-danza-contemporanea-en-el-agora/

                 DANCE IS OUR PASSION

AND WE WANT TO SHARE IT WITH ALL OF YOU

_______________________________________________________________________

EN ESPAÑOL:

 

Envía a las bailarinas de "MARIACHI" a Bruselas

La compañía TEMPESDANZA ha sido invitada para realizar una residencia artística en el DANSCENTRUMJETTE en Bruselas durante el mes de agosto de este año. 

  • Esta residencia es una oportunidad única para proyectar nuestro trabajo en Europa.
  • Queremos llevar nuestro estilo de Danza Contemporánea con sabor mexicano a Europa.
  • DANSCENTRUMJETTE en Bruselas es un reconocido espacio de investigación coreográfica donde han trabajado coreógrafos como David Zambrano, Julyen Hamilton y David Hernandez.

La Compañía TEMPESDANZA

se estableció en Xalapa, Veracruz, Mexico en el 2006. Desde entonces hemos producido al menos un programa nuevo por año, presentándolo en diversos foros y espacios públicos. Nuestra labor ha sido dedicada a:

  • Creación, investigación y exploración en Danza Contemporánea,  Improvisación, Composición Instantánea y Contact Improvisación.
  • Promoción de  Danza Contemporánea y Danza Teatro
  • Formación en danza y movimeinto para personas de todas las condiciones socioeconómicas.
  • Educación de nuevos púbicos para la Danza Contemporánea.

 

PREMIOS

  • 2009 CACHO 'E TABLA "Mejor performance"
  • 2010 CACHO 'E TABLA "Mejor obra de danza"
  • 2011 beca de producción PECDAV
  • 2011 Premio Culiacán de Coreografía

 

Somos

  • Lou Sturm: bailarina, coreógrafa, artista multi-media, educadora somática
  • Guiedana López: bailarina, actriz, yogui, de Oaxaca, México
  • Maura González: bailarina, originaria de Puebla, México; antes Compañía APocAPoc 
  • Yohualli V. González: Artista visual y sonoro
 

Necesitamos US$5,850

  • La lista solo considera los gastos de transporte aéreo, hospedaje y comida para las 4 personas del equipo.
  • Ninguno de nosotros recibirá salario alguno durante la residencia.
  • El presupuesto total de nuestro proyecto es de US$11,850
  • Ya contamos con US$6,000
  • Desafortunadamente, el mes de agosto es temporada alta para los vuelos a Europa y cada boleto (MEX-BRU-MEX) tiene un costo mínimo de US$1,350.

TEMPESDANZA en la web

  • http://blog.udlap.mx/danza/2011/09/19/estreno-estatal-de-la-compania-tempesdanza-%E2%80%9Cololiuqui-abstractions%E2%80%9D-en-la-udlap/
  • http://holaxalapa.com/2011/12/17/tempesdanza-regresa-con-puras-instantaneas-en-la-rueca-de-gandhi/
  • http://www.imagendelgolfo.com.mx/resumen.php?id=78405

LA DANZA NOS APASIONA

Y NOS GUSTARÍA COMPARTIRLA CON TODOS USTEDES
story_txt:
Send the "MARIACHI" dancers to Brussels
(español vease abajo)
TEMPESDANZA company has been invited to perform an artistic residency at DANSCENTRUMJETTE in Brussels during August this year. 

This residency is a unique oportunity for us to project our work to Europe.
We want o bring our special Mexican flavoured Contemporary Dance to Europe.
DANSCENTRUMJETTE in Brussels is the renowned working space of choreographers like David Zambrano, Julyen Hamilton and David Hernandez.



Our Company TEMPESDANZA
has been working in Xalapa, Veracruz, Mexico since 2006. We have been producing at least one new program per year, presenting it in different theatres and public spaces. We are dedicated to:

Creation, exploration and investigation in Contemporary Dance, Improvisation, Instant Composition and Contact Improvisation
Promotion of Contemporary Dance and Dance Theatre
Education in dance and movement for people of all social and economic backgrounds.
Building new public for Contemporary Dance

AWARDS



2009 CACHO 'E TABLA "Best performance"
2010 CACHO 'E TABLA "Best dance piece"
2011 scholarship PECDAV
2011 Choreography Prize Culiacán/Sinaloa

 


We are


Lou Sturm: dancer, choreographer, multi-media artist, Somatic Facilitator

Guiedana López: dancer, actress, yogi from Oaxaca, Mexico

Maura González: dancer, originally from Puebla, Mexico; before APocAPoc Company

Yohualli V. González: Visual and sound artist


 
We need $5,850

The listed costs only consider transportation for the 4 of us, acomodation and food.
None of us will receive any salary during the residency.
Our project costs in total $11,850
We already have $6,000
Unfortunately, August is high season for flights to Europe and each flight ticket (MEX-BRU-MEX) costs minimum $1,350

story:
About Me

 

I grew up in Beaverton, OR and I have been dancing for seven years now, and I'm absolutely thrilled to have found my passion.  My dream is to dance in a professional modern based dance company. Amongst that list is Hubbard Street Dance Chicago.  Now a Freshman dance major at Cornish College of the Arts, I study Ballet and Modern.  I have found my love for modern dance over the past few years, and it has taken the form of being my religion.  As a dancer and artist it is incredibly important to continue training throughout the year, and while school is out for the summer it is the perfect time to enter the world of dance and study abroad.  To my surprise, after auditioning for the Hubbard Street Summer Intensive, I was accepted. This is an incredible opportunity and I really want to make it happen. I want to be one of these dancers who is able to further examine themselves through the art of dance. Please help me live this dream of dancing with other dancers who also want to do the same; continue to find the artist within.  The life of an artist is very expensive, already paying for college I am unable to attend Hubbard Street this summer without the support of my community. Thank you for your time and ANY donation really does help!  

 

 

What I Need

 

I aspire to attend the Hubbard Street 4 week Summer Intensive in Chicago, IL.  I have been graciously given a few scholarships that I am able to apply only to my tuition.  That being said, I need help raising the funds for the housing that is connected to the program itself.  All funds raised will go towards paying for housing.   

Tuition: $1,900

Housing: $2,200

 

 

The Impact

 

As I continue to study dance, my hope is to dance professionally very soon.  Training with Hubbard Street is a phenomenal opportunity to learn with one of the top Modern companies in the world.  It is rare that one comes across a passion so big that it ignites every aspect of their life, for me dance has done this. Recently, I have begun to become mindful of the connection between myself and dance.  The reason I dance, and what it does for my body and soul are questions that I have been exploring recently.  I find that when I am creating dance and movement it helps me further understand what it is that I love about dance.  It is the simple action of dancing through space. Dance is my voice.  It is the way I am able to convey stories, information, or the feeling that simply cannot be put into words.  It allows me to show that dancing is not purely a hobby, but rather a necessity in my life.  Please help me continue on this beautiful journey that I have already set the path for.  THANK YOU!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

ANY donation helps!

Aside from donating, SPREADING THE WORD would help immensely.

Sharing this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, E-mail, or even in person will help.

 

Thank you for your time!

story:
Pride Films and Plays is doing a play called Angry Fags. It’s a Chicago premiere written by Topher Payne.  It will be performed in Spring 2015 in the Steppenwolf Theatre Company's Garage Repertory produced by Pride Films and Plays.  It’s funny.  It’s dark. It’s the most important show you’ll see next year. 

Yes, we know it is controversial and will get some people upset. We can't even get the Chicago Tribune to print the full title.  So we need you to DONATE NOW to help us make this production as good as it can be, and reach as wide an audience as possible.

Angry Fags is a play about doing whatever it takes to win. It’s a battle-cry and a cautionary tale; it’s Oscar Wilde-meets-Tarantino! It’s about being in the trenches, about continuing to push forward and fight. Angry Fags does not want to wait while it gets better. Angry Fags wants to MAKE IT BETTER NOW. 

We are excited for the opportunity to perform as part of Steppenwolf Theatre
Company's Garage Rep. But that means we have over twice as many seats to fill as we have had for any of our other shows this year, which means we need additional marketing dollars to reach audiences outside of our regular base. Your donation today means we can not only reach people through social media, but with direct mail pieces to their homes. Your support helps us spread the work to non-gay media outlets that will enable us engage with audiences outside of our regular base.

We also need costumes and props for the actors including 'Designing Women' shoulder pads, ' Steel Magnolia' hair supplies, cherry flavored stage blood, bathhouse towels, glitter-bombs, pistachios, red wine, Tequila sunrises, tazers, tiny cupcakes, cans of paint and a baseball bat. The show features a video wall of original and archival footage. It is a big project.

Please DONATE now!

We are Pride Films and Plays. We tell stories with gay, lesbian, bisexual, and transgender characters or themes.  We develop powerful theatrics and films that speak for the LGBT community and are essential viewing for ALL audiences.


DONATE NOW to support this production of Angry Fags.

Angry Fags is directed by Derek Van Barham*, and features Kevin Webb*, James Nedrud*, Jude Hansen*, Kelli Walker, Joan McGrath*, Lisa Herceg, and Dennis Frymire. Designs are by Raquel Adorno (costumes), G. Max Maxin IV (projections and set), Kallie Noelle Rolison (sound) and Rebecca Barrett (lights). *Indicates a member of Pride Films and Plays Artistic Ensemble.

Production Details: Angry Fags by Topher Payne

  • Location:  The Steppenwolf Garage, 1624 N Halsted St, Chicago
  • Previews: Sun Feb 22, Fri Feb 27, Sun March 1 and Wed March 4 at 8PM
  • Press performance/opening: Saturday, March 7 at 8PM Sunday March 8 at 1PM
  • Performances run through April 26 (Specific dates/times at www.pridefilmsandplays.com). 

Pride Films and Plays presents great new plays and films for this generation, while developing new pieces of arts for generations to come. Find out more about our work - including the World Premiere musical The Book Of Merman coming in January, If you would like to join us as a subscriber for 2015, you can do that here.

And if you would like to support this production by making a donation outside of Indiegogo, you can do that here.

story:
"The holidays are like a microwave. It's over before you know it"

Four Scottish teenagers sit on a wall.

Award-winning writer D.C. Jackson's heady cocktail of laugh-out-loud comedy and poignant truth follows Barry, Michelle, Norma and Rab as they tackle the onslaught of love, life, and identity over one hot summer.

Mayford Road are delighted to present Jackson's first play in association with


                                    THE  WALL BY D. C. JACKSON

                                           At The Hope Theatre, 

                                   207 Upper Street, Islington N1

                                   28th October to 15th November 

                                             Tues - Sat at 7 45pm


We are raising money in order to pay the actors so that all profits made can be donated to  http://www.sharefound.org

Since their work began in 2012 the organisation has benefited over 50,000 young people.

INTRODUCING YOU TO   -  THE SHARE FOUNDATION operates the Junior ISA scheme for children and young people in care.  They are responsible for:

 1  Opening their accounts with an initial Government contribution of £200;

 2   Ensuring that their accounts are properly operated and invested appropriately with a range of Junior ISA providers;

 3  Raising additional voluntary contributions by donation or fund-raising

4   Providing financial education to help ensure responsible use of the funds when the Junior ISAs mature at age 18.

http://www.sharefound.org


Our Target explained…

Equity Fringe Agreement = £20 per 3 hour session for actors and stage manager (SM)

Rehearsal week:

4 actors at £20 per session x 10 sessions = £800

1 session of Stage manager (SM) = £40

Total:  £840

Tech Week:

Monday  - 3 sessions (technical and dress rehearsal) of 4 actors and 1 SM (5x20) = 300

Tuesday   - 2 sessions x 5 (afternoon working notes and 1st preview) =200

Wed to Sat - 4 sessions/4 shows x 5 = 400

Total:  £900

2 remaining weeks of shows:

5 company members (4 actors and 1 SM) for 5 sessions per week

Total: £1000

TOTAL: £2740

Minimum budget for 4 weeks of work from a company of 5 ( 4 actors and 1 stage manager)


The Company of 'The Wall

Writer - D. C. Jackson

His first full length play The Wall was nominated for several awards including the Best New Play at the Critics' Awards for Theatre in Scotland and the Saltire Society Scottish First Book of the year.[3][4] His play My Romantic History' (which starred Iain Robertson) won a Scotsman Fringe First at the 2010 Edinburgh Festival and sold out its run at the Bush Theatre London.

Co-directors - David Ricardo Pearce and Marianne Oldham

David and Marianne have worked as actors for 10 years since graduating form Bristol Old Vic Theatre School.  They have worked across the board in theatre, film and TV.

 David has just finished at the Barbican and a world tour of Handspring's new production of ‘A Midsummer Nights Dream’.

Marianne has previously been nominated for ‘Best Actress for The Stage Awards’ and ‘Best Performer’ for the Theatre Awards UK and recently starred in the BBC’s ‘The Crimson Field’ and is currently filming for ‘The Musketeers’ Season 2. 

The Cast = Coran Royle, Rosalyn Paterson, Emma King and Sam Watson

actors for 10 years since graduating form Bristol Old Vic Theatre School.  They have worked across the board in theatre,
film and TV. David has just finished at
the Barbican and a world tour of Handspring's new production of
‘A Midsummer Nights Dream’.Marianne has previously been nominated for ‘Best
Actress for The Stage Awards’ and ‘Best Performer’ for the Theatre Awards UK
and recently starred in the BBC’s ‘The Crimson Field’ and is currently filming
for ‘The Musketeers’ Season 2. 

The Cast = Coran Royle,
Rosalyn Paterson, Emma King and Sam Watson

story:
• Kelsey's Story

    Remember your college days with all of the studying, test, and hard work? I'm sure you remember the tight budget you lived on. Kelsey has studied dance since she was a little girl and is finally graduating from the prestigious University of the Arts in Philadelphia with Bachelor of Fine Arts in Dance.  She has an awesome opportunity to audition with a prestigious dance company in Italy.

    • Weller Thomas and I recently met Kelsey when she volunteered to help a bunch of hapless volunteers learn basic steps for a non-profit fundraiser. Yes, we were a motley crew. But, the volunteer dance students turned us in to respectably participants and I even won second place in the competition! Amazing. 
    • Week after week Kelsey showed up to help us learn to dance. It was then we learned she was a student who was also carrying a full load of senior-year studies! And what's more, she has volunteered her talents to the non-profit organization for the past three years.

    • Together we can take the burden of, "How will I get to Italy to audition?" off of her mind. Won't you join me in helping raise the airfare to send her?

    • Kelsey is trained in West African, Ballet, Pointe, Ballet Partnering, Latin, Jazz, Horton, Contemporary, Improvisation, Modern Partnering, Alto/Tenor Vocals. 

    If you can make a contribution, (no amount is too small) together we can make it happen.

    Help raise $1500 for Kelsey's airfare and  expenses for three days.

    • Please donate, $10, $25, $100 or whatever you feel inclined to give.
    • Kelsey will write a personal thank you note for each and every contribution.
    • The goal is $1500, but if we fall short (and I hope we don't) we will give Kelsey whatever we raise. 

The Impact

I know there are many charities you probably support, but let's do this and send a young lady off to fulfill her dreams. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If your budget absolutely won't allow you to make a monetary contribution at this time, you can STILL help in a major way by sharing information about this campaign.

  • Ask your sorority, fraternity, church, mosque or synagogue for a modest contribution of $100 or more. 
  • Use the share tools here on Indiegogo to forward this information to friends and family. Consider sharing with five people.

I thank you so much. And Kelsey will too. 

P.J. Thomas, 

Editor, Pathfinders Travel Magazine

story:
Short Summary

Hi Everyone! Thank you for taking out time to look at our campaign page. I am Director and writer Keith D. Bracker tag teaming with Actress and Producer Jan Mizushima. 

We are excited to launch this campaign for our stage play 'Feathered Thorns' which is to be an exciting experience on stage! 

Keith: 'Feathered Thorns' is a story that I wrote in 2008.  I began to shoot it as a feature length movie but after finances fell through and a cast member caught walking pneumonia we had to put production on hold. Recently, the story was picked back up and I decided to adapt it into a stage play to challenge myself to capture the life of artists the best way me and the team know how on the stage. This will be my directorial debut for a stage play, in which I'm very excited about! However, I've been writing and directing well over a decade. I'm passionate about telling unique, creative, powerful, challenging stories that explore lives of complex characters and themes. 

Jan: I am an founder/artistic director of Plug-In Theater Company ; a producing organization found in 2004 with a mission to provide plays related to political and social issues.  'Feathered Thorns' is a beautifully written play about two artist in different stages of life finding their voice through art. I am so excited and passionate to be apart of telling this story.

'Feathered Thorns' covers the relationship between a speech impaired twenty year old Qiao, living with her overprotective mother, Xiu, who wants her daughter to pick a more stable profession than being a painter. However, Qiao is a skillful artist but she is still looking for her 'voice' in her art. So Xiu, sets up a deal with Nhung, a well established popular female painter, whom Qiao admires greatly, to where Qiao will live with Nhung for a couple of weeks to learn from her. Qiao finds out Nhung is not what she expected but both women end up effecting each other in unexpected ways.  

'Feathered Thorns' is a coming-to-age tale, that delves into passion, acceptance, self importance, faith, friendship and the relationship between mother and daughter.

What We Need & What You Get

We're looking to raise $20, 000 to cover cast and crew pay, production design, props, catering and theater space. We have some cool rewards we're giving out to contributors!  One of the rewards is that you get a chance to take a picture with the incredible cast and there's a chance to receive a email directly from me, the director, or from one of the cast members thanking you for your pledge! 

Be apart of this journey today!

The Impact

'Feathered Thorns' expresses how important art can be in someones life. The arts is  an inspiration to millions, it's an outlet for those who feel like 'outsiders', the 'neglect' and those who just find it easier to use art to communicate more effectively to others. 

Keith: This is my stage debut as a stage director and playwright. I'm very excited to share what I believe to be a unique and fun story that will inspire those who want to take that leap wholeheartedly to pursue their passion but are afraid; and the importance of self worth. A lot of my stories deal with people who struggle to become a successful artist or trying to remain successful while facing some type of opposition. And the story deals with the complexity of a mother and daughter relationship, a theme that I've explored in the past in my writing. 

Jan: This story is about love of art, relationships, identity, finding your path and much more. It is a beautiful story between the two artist and the mothers love. 

Risks & Challenges

The cast and crew will be putting in a lot of hours to bring 'Feathered Thorns' to life on stage in a spectacular way-so we want to show our appreciation with compensation and feeding them. To dress the stage can be costly, so the funds will be needed for that. This is to help audience to suspend their imagination and get lost in the world that we create on stage before them. Renting a theater for several days can be costly as well but with these funds from contributors like you we know we can overcome that so we can pick a comfortable, clean, well organized theater to welcome the cast and crew, so they can give their best performance each night and of course for the audience to feel comfortable in. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand some of you may not be able to contribute, but spreading the word about our project would be a great help! Thank you!

story:
DAY OF THE FEAST


Hi everyone! I'm Ju, the founder of J&S Young Artist Project.  I'm originally from Korea and I want to encourage and facilitate cross-cultural collaboration between theater professionals in the U.S. and Korea.  

 

J&S is proud to present the world premier of Day of the Feast, an exciting new play by Idaho playwright, Patrick Rexroat.   Day of the Feast is a lyrical portrait of one family’s encounter with tragedy. Through the perspective of the family members, their dog, and the rat under their porch, a sequence of events unfolds that challenges their values and the reality on which their world is built. In Day of the Feast, the simple tradition of a family dinner can both fracture and fuse the bonds of family.  The production features music by the composer, Ahmed Alabaca, which he will play live at every performance. 


Your donation directly supports the work of young theater artists.  We can't do this without you! 


So here's the deal...

Day of the Feast opens on February 7, 2014 at DCTV, originally a lower Manhattan firehouse that has been converted into a performance space. Your donation will help pay for the rental of the theater and technical equipment such as lighting, and materials for the set and costumes.  Every dollar counts toward these essential production costs!

For $15 you will recieve a personal Thank You! card signed by the entire company, a heartwarming message showing our gratitude.   

For $25 you will recieve a Day of the Feast T-Shirt!, This will help us spread word of the play, while helping you look just a little bit more awesome! Please choose M, L, or XL.

For $50 you will be cordially invited to the invited dress rehersal to see the magic of the production happen. After the rehersal you will be treated to wine and meet the cast.

For $100 you will be given two free tickets to see the show on any night, with seats reserved just for you! Just email us the date of your choice, walk up to the box office and recieve your tickets and thank you!

For $175 you will be given not two, not three but Four free tickets! These are valid on any night you wish to attend, with seats reserved for your party. Just email us the date of your choice, walk up to the box office to recieve your tickets and a big hug!

New York City and Beyond

Day of the Feast is the second play to be produced by J&S.  In the spring of 2013 we opened with a steampunk rendition of Shakespeare's A Midsummer Night's Dream, transporting the magic and mystery of this classic tale to the phantasmic world of Victorian steampunk.  After a successful five-performance run, we knew we wanted to continue to bring works with a similarly unique perspective to audiences.  

Our goal is to bring Day of the Feast to the Busan International Performing Arts Festival (BIPAF) in Korea in 2015.  Your donation today will not only support the NYC world premier of Day of the Feast, but will also bring us one step closer to BIPAF!

$$ is awesome, but there is even more you can do!

We sincerely value each and every dollar that you contribute.  No amount is too small.  You can also support us by sharing this campaign on social media.  Tell your friends, family, co-workers, and random people on the street to visit our page! And don't forget to check out our website (http://jsyoungartistproject.com/) and facebook page where you can learn more about the cast and production team!

story:
“ im·mu·ni·ty" is a new intense psychological thriller set in 1942 Auschwitz, right in the middle of the second World War.

Here’s your chance to be a part of this extraordinary theatrical experience!

What makes “ im·mu·ni·ty" so extraordinary?

"im·mu·ni·ty" shows us people wrestling with their own humanity in ways never before seen:
A Nazi experiencing guilt, struggling with childhood lessons vs SS propaganda.

A Kapo turning against her own people to survive in the camps.
A Jewish heroine willing to sacrifice her life to save her husband.

“im·mu·ni·ty" takes us inside the camps and the struggle in the minds of the prisoners, workers and oppressors who were once kind men —party loyalty vs morals, faith vs fear. See and hear the stories that "Schindler's List", "Judgement at Nuremberg", and "The Boy in the Striped Pajamas" left out.

It is with great pleasure that we present the first premiere of " im·mu·ni·ty"as a full-length play, presented by The Manhattan Repertory Theatre’s Play Development program.

The one-act production of" im·mu·ni·ty" won 1st place at NYC's 2014 Venus Theater Festival. This gripping tale has been expanded to a full-length play, and your support can help bring it to the world!

The Story:

Auschwitz, 1942. Torn from her family, Gita Weitz stands locked in a dark interrogation room with nothing to hold on to but her faith. She is suddenly confronted by an SS officer whose voice is familiar. Doctor Schuller, once known to Gita as Franz  was her most prized pupil during her days as a Berlin schoolteacher.  Gita’s relief at this recognition is short lived, however. 

Schuller, raised amongst the Jews and taught to regard them as equals, has since been re-educated to believe Jews are the enemy. Believing himself misled by the teacher he trusted and had been smitten with since childhood, he now sees the virtues of tolerance, humanity and compassion she instilled in him as detrimental weaknesses. 

Schuller designs a plan to make himself immune to his humanity by physically, psychologically and emotionally torturing Gita each day until he is no longer affected by her pain. 

Can a flicker of humanity overcome evil or hope to survive in Auschwitz?


A scene from the award-winning 50-minute play, “im·mu·ni·ty”


Our History:

Read for yourself the incredible floodgate of emotions opened by this play by reviewers and audiences alike.

 "Mesmerizing! Applause isn’t enough to show appreciation for the experience”
- Glen Quentin of StageBuddy

“Shari Umansky immortalized a powerful and haunting picture of the darkest color of the soul of humanity.”
- Franco Moschetti, Artistic Director of The Cabrini Repertory Theater

“For 50 minutes I didn’t take a single breath.”
- Doreen Firestone, THE PRODIGAL DAUGHTER

The comments didn't stop with praise. People wanted more of the characters, the story and the journey.
“What were they like before they got to Auschwitz?"
"What were Gita and Schuller like as teacher and student?"
"What was the relationship like between Gita and Joseph?"
"What was Schuller like before he joined the SS?"
Now the riveting tale continues to a shocking conclusion!

What started with this post-festival buzz is now picking up steam around the country. We’ve already had interest expressed from theaters in Washington DC, Miami, New York, and even Israel.

Our Goal

Our first priority is to present the story in as historically accurate and emotionally authentic way possible. We will record a professional video and pass it along to JCC’s, Educational Programs, professional theaters and film producers around the world in order to reach as large an audience as possible. Of course, the more money we raise, the greater the likelihood of a successful campaign...and we can't do it without your help!

How you can help!

Phase One is achieving our biggest initial goal --creating a compelling, powerful and entertaining evening of theater, leaving audiences awe-struck. When larger theater companies develop work, the process can take months. We only have weeks to put up a show that producers want to give money to and theaters want to adopt — and we know that making it great will be a monumental task. In order for this to occur, a few certain things are necessary for a complete and satisfying evening and campaign:

Programs

Sets and Props

Costumes

Reserved Tickets for Potential Investors

Posters, Programs and Signage

Rehearsal space

Travel expenses for actors

Lighting and sound

Marketing and Promoting

Press packages

Our show dates are February, 4th and 7th, with more dates being added. Tickets are $20 at the door. To reserve tickets, email MRTRESERVE@gmail.com with your preferred date and number of tickets. 

Once the run at Manhattan Repertory Theater is complete, we move to…

Phase Two is creating an “im·mu·ni·ty” promotional theatrical trailer to submit to national theaters, festivals, producers and potential investors.

At the same time we will be promoting “im·mu·ni·ty” locally with the goal of touring of educational facilities, JCC’s and more!

 
A scene from the award-winning 50-minute play, “im·mu·ni·ty”

Playwright Shari Umansky on the birth of Immunity:

"Despite 10 years of Hebrew school and spending most of my adult life researching the Holocaust, I felt both unqualified and unprepared to write the terrifying tale of Schuller and Gita.

I traveled to Auschwitz & Auschwitz II, Birkenau and spent two full days touring the camps with a private guide. I left the camps knowing that at the soul of the story of “im·mu·ni·ty” would lie a question: Whether a flicker of humanity could survive in Auschwitz despite the most heinous and tenacious efforts to extinguish it.

“im·mu·ni·ty” is the culmination of my life’s work, both a revelation of horrors and a vehicle to promote the endurance of humanity.

By contributing to" im·mu·ni·ty in NYC”, you're helping to awaken, preserve and share a global understanding of humanity –and show that the Holocaust is not merely a page in our history. There are new stories to tell --and this one promises to have you on the edge of your seat."

-Shari Umansky  


The Playwright with Original Award Winning Cast


About the Playwright and Directors:

SHARI UMANSKY (PLAYWRIGHT + DIRECTOR) is both an accomplished playwright, screenwriter and director. A member of the Dramatist Guild of America and WGA, her work has been seen in film, television and on stage. Shari received the Best Screenwriting Award at the Delray Beach Film Festival for her feature film, “Why George?” She has also penned the short films “Why Knot?” and “Bystander.” Shari has received several awards and festival accolades for her one-act plays, "Jedi Mind Meld", “The Devils Advocate” and “Chosen.”
“im·mu·ni·ty”, the culmination of her life's work, premiered on March 6th 2014 and was awarded 1st place for "Best Play" at the Venus Theater Festival. "im·mu·ni·ty" has recently been reworked into a screenplay and has already received a coveted  “Special Mention Award” from Sundance affiliate, The Table Read My Screenplay.

DENNIS GLEASON (DIRECTOR):  With a MFA in Directing from the Actors Studio Drama School here in NYC, Dennis has directed over 140 plays and musicals coast to coast winning 15 "Outstanding Director" and "Outstanding Production" awards. He also directed AN ADULT EVENING OF SHEL SILVERSTEIN Off Broadway. Other credits include DOUBT, MISERY, CUCKOO'S NEST, STREETCAR, DEATHTRAP, AND THEN THERE WERE NONE, SCOTLAND ROAD, TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, and LOST IN YONKERS among others. He served as Managing or Artistic Director for theatres in CA, SC, LA, SD, TX and WI.
