great will be a monumental task. In order for this to occur, a few certain
things are necessary for a complete and satisfying evening and campaign: 
Programs
Sets
and Props
Costumes
Reserved
Tickets for Potential Investors
Posters,
Programs and Signage
Rehearsal
space
Travel
expenses for actors
Lighting
and sound 
Marketing
and Promoting
Press
packages
Our
show dates are February, 4th and 7th, with more dates being added. Tickets are
$20 at the door. To reserve tickets, email MRTRESERVE@gmail.com with your
preferred date and number of tickets. 
Once
the run at Manhattan Repertory Theater is complete, we move to… 
Phase Two is creating an “im·mu·ni·ty”
promotional theatrical trailer to submit to national theaters, festivals, producers and potential investors.
At the same time we will be promoting “im·mu·ni·ty” locally
with the goal of touring of educational facilities, JCC’s and more! 
A scene from the award-winning 50-minute play, “im·mu·ni·ty” 


Playwright Shari
Umansky on the birth of Immunity:
"Despite 10 years
of Hebrew school and spending most of my adult life researching the Holocaust,
I felt both unqualified and unprepared to write the terrifying tale of Schuller
and Gita.
I traveled to
Auschwitz & Auschwitz II, Birkenau and spent two full days touring the
camps with a private guide. I left the camps knowing that at the soul of the
story of “im·mu·ni·ty” would lie a question: Whether a flicker of humanity could
survive in Auschwitz despite the most heinous and tenacious efforts to
extinguish it.
“im·mu·ni·ty” is
the culmination of my life’s work, both a revelation of horrors and a vehicle
to promote the endurance of humanity.
By contributing to" im·mu·ni·ty in NYC”, you're helping to awaken, preserve
and share a global understanding of humanity –and show that the Holocaust is
not merely a page in our history. There are new stories to tell --and this one
promises to have you on the edge of your seat."-Shari Umansky
  The Playwright with Original Award Winning Cast
About the Playwright and Directors:
SHARI UMANSKY (PLAYWRIGHT + DIRECTOR) is
both an accomplished playwright, screenwriter and director. A member of the Dramatist Guild
of America and WGA, her work has been seen in film, television and on stage.
Shari received the Best Screenwriting Award at the Delray Beach Film
Festival for her feature film, “Why George?” She has also penned the short
films “Why Knot?” and “Bystander.” Shari has received several awards and
festival accolades for her one-act plays, "Jedi Mind Meld", “The
Devils Advocate” and “Chosen.”“im·mu·ni·ty”, the culmination of her life's work, premiered on March 6th
2014 and was awarded 1st place for "Best Play" at the
Venus Theater Festival. "im·mu·ni·ty"
has recently been reworked into a screenplay and has already received a
coveted  “Special Mention Award”
from Sundance affiliate, The Table Read My Screenplay.
DENNIS
GLEASON (DIRECTOR):  With a MFA in Directing from the Actors Studio Drama
School here in NYC, Dennis has directed over 140 plays and musicals coast
to coast winning 15 "Outstanding Director" and "Outstanding
Production" awards. He also directed AN ADULT EVENING OF SHEL SILVERSTEIN
Off Broadway. Other credits include DOUBT, MISERY, CUCKOO'S NEST, STREETCAR,
DEATHTRAP, AND THEN THERE WERE NONE, SCOTLAND ROAD, TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, and
LOST IN YONKERS among others. He served as Managing or Artistic Director for
theatres in CA, SC, LA, SD, TX and WI.

story:
"Talya Chalef’s vision and execution provided me with an unforgettable performance experience. I encourage anyone and everyone to support this global odyssey (and attend too!) "
Marcia Callaghan - American Australian Association 
(Post 2011 Port Cities NY workshop) 

What is Port Cities & Port Cities NYC


Over the course of approximately 5-7 years, The Public Works Department, which includes award-winning visual theater-maker Talya Chalef and awesome media designer Sofi Yuditskaya,  will devise five port cities performance events around the world in collaboration with local and international artists.

Each port cities performance will contain the same elements:

  • a non theatre performance space close or on the port.
  • a projected video montage sequence depicting ‘movement’ particular to that city
  • an exploration into that particular city’s connection with Dutch trade route history (and its own location on the route).

Local myths, legends and folklores will be explored against the backdrop of current contemporary issues affecting each city. The port cities performance events will be available online on a port cities website allowing participating cities to interact and reflect on the project as a whole. At the end of the journey, the sum of the five cities will be compiled into a DVD documentary available for each city's host festival/organisation to keep as a performance in ‘five movements’ like an opera.

Port Cities NYC?

A shipwreck uncovered under the World Trade center construction site, an African burial ground uncovered streets away, Wall Street, tulips, police violence and a world wide protest occupying public space and questioning our value/s. What were we trading in then? What are we trading in now? When will the ship crash? And what will fall down when it does?

The timeline? 

In 2011 we created a first development workshop aboard the Red Hook Museum barge. 

With some of your help, we brought an audience over the harbor at sunset with a specially designed soundtrack, into an installation on the pier and onto the barge and our initial ideas. 


Since then the work has evolved. The ideas have been simmering away with fresh new perspectives on what is ‘current’, topical and salient.  

  • September/October 2014: Workshops in Brooklyn & writing time at Space on Ryder Farm
  • February 2015: Residency Mount Tremper Arts
  • September 2015: Port Cities NYC premiere in Red Hook Brooklyn. 

Outcomes & Partners

We are in conversation with the Brooklyn Waterfront Artists Coalition to partner with them and present a public performance on the Red Hook pier at the end of summer 2015. We are also in conversation with an arts/light festival examining the Dutch history of NYC. (Partner TBC) It is our goal to install six shipping containers, which will act as our set. Each container will hold a world inside it and the actors will move in and out of each world as they begin to connect back and forth through time and geography. The audience will witness multiple worlds against the backdrop of the New York City skyline. 

The development of the work will be partly scripted and mostly devised, using projection, music, installation, movement and images woven together to tell our story. 

But to create ensemble work in NYC is challenging. And after spending time away at Space on Ryder Farm, it became clear that getting out of the city was key to concentrated focus and creative productivity. 

Mount Tremper Arts has offered us a subsidized week in their farmhouse and studio up in Woodstock NY. It is our goal to develop the script whilst workshopping the physicality, musicality and installation worlds of the piece together. 


What do we need the money for?

We need money to pay the actors and designers for their time away, to transport everyone back and forth from the city and to feed and house them for one week. 


Budget: 

  • Five actors @ $300 wkly = $1500
  • Director & Projection Designer @ $300 wkly  = $600
  • Composer, Scenic Designer, Lx designer for 3 days @ $150 each = $450
  • Subsidized residency fee for one week $650 
  • Transport to and from Woodstock & food for one week $500 
  • Indie Go Go $4% platform fee  = $160 
  • Miscellaneous = $140 (incidentals/petty cash/ gifts and postal) 

Total: $4000 

Our goal is above, as I believe artists should all be valued for their time, talents and skills - even though these wage amounts are not fully reflective of that. 
If we don't make our full total, the budget will have to be altered accordingly.

story:
WHO ARE WE?

Let us introduce ourselves! We are Michelle Ciccotelli and Stephanie Occhipinti, Co-Founders of Amateur Hour. Hi there. We are women. We like comedy. Women are funny, despite what you may have heard.

WHAT ARE WE DOING?

Gutenberg! The Musical! is a hilarious musical spoof in which two aspiring Broadway writers perform a staged reading of what might be the greatest musical of all time. With an unending supply of enthusiasm, the two playwrights play all the parts and sing all the songs in the hopes of finding a Broadway producer to make all their dreams come true. Though the play is originally written for two male characters, Michelle Ciccotelli and Stephanie Occhipinti will be featured in the leading roles.

WHY ARE WE DOING IT?

We recently graduated from Boston University’s School of Theatre.  As we neared the end of our college experience and shifted our focus to post-grad professional life, we noticed the work we were hungry for didn’t exist in the ways we had hoped. Comedic roles for young women are few and far between. The ones that do exist often lack dimension or are written more simplistically than roles written for men. We wanted to create a space where women with an interest in comedy will have the opportunity to grow and develop those artistic muscles. Each project brings us one step closer to gender parity in the world of comedy.

Gutenberg! The Musical! has been near and dear to our hearts for many years, but suddenly we find ourselves wondering why it has only ever been produced by men. The humor is reliant on the versatility of the actors, not their genders.

HOW CAN YOU HELP?

Donate! Every penny counts!

Every donation will go towards funding….

  • Licensing Fees!
  • Venue Rental!
  • Props!
  • Compensation for Collaborators!
  • Musical Materials!
  • Printing Costs!
  • Unforeseen Calamities!
  • Future Amateur Hour endeavors!

If you’re not in a position to donate financially, please help us spread the word by sharing this page and following us on social media! @DamnateurHour

story:
Synopsis

Synopsis:

Annie and Max were so close to their story. (You know the one: the "...and then we lived happily ever after" story) That is until Max, without warning, left her alone and heartbroken. 7 months later, she opens her door to find him standing there.  What's next? Well, that's up to Annie. 

What We Need & What You Get

This is Red Wit Production Company's first bout in the New York Scene, and with the majority of the team coming straight out of undergrad, we are looking to the artistic community to help us get there! We've got a heck of lot of passion and drive and we are ready to take the city by storm.  

  • For this particular production, our main concerns are raising funds in order to pay for festival fees, rehearsal/audition space, and artistic stipends. Our goal is to pay everyone involved for their hard work, talent, and time.
  • We are so beyond grateful for you, as you are a huge part of making this happen – so we want you to benefit as well! There are a long list of perks, but every dollar counts (truly every single one) 
  • Once you've contributed, you are a part of our Red Wit family–should you choose to provide your email, we will keep you posted every step of the way on this production and future ones! 

The Impact

The goal of this production is to create work that we, as young artists, are passionate about and feel needs to be seen. This show is about relationships: when to wait for love, and two people who can't seem to find their way back to each other. This is our first attempt to say something, and we need your support in order to succeed. New York New Works gives us the opportunity to be a part of a festival with many connections–this is our chance to get the work seen as well as our actors, which is the most important thing we can be doing as young, emerging artists.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone is able to financially contribute, but every bit helps. Even spreading the word or sharing the campaign would make a huge difference.  Use that social media for good! 

We also hope you will come to our show; the most important thing is to get this show onstage for you to see.  We're ready to tell you a really great story and perhaps surprise you along the way.  

 

The Production Team: 

Aiden Dreskin (Director) is an NYC-based Director, Playwright, and Sound Designer. He is a graduate of NYU's Tisch School of the Arts, where he wrote and directed a number of original plays while working towards his BFA. Recently, Aiden has been applying his talents to programs and productions of various companies around New York, including the 52nd Street Project, Believe NYC, the Playgroup Theatre, and the Brooklyn Academy of Music. For more information, or to view samples of his work, visit www.aidendreskin.com

Cam Wenrich (Max) is a recent Ithaca College graduate, originally from Plano, Texas. Previous roles include Ellard in The Foreigner at the Hangar Theatre, Richard of Gloucester and Antonio in Henry VI and Twelfth Night at the Ithaca Shakespeare Company, and Septimus Hodge in Ithaca College’s mainstage production of Arcadia. As an up-and-coming NYC artist and avid pun enthusiast, he’s thrilled to be a part of the A-Door Me team. He’s currently represented by Meg Pantera - The Agency. www.camwenrich.com

Allison Reed (Playwright/Annie): is an NYC/Toronto based Playwright, Actor, and Singer.  She is a recent grad from the New Studio on Broadway's Acting and Musical Theatre program at NYU Tisch. Favorite roles include: Hope Cladwell (Urinetown), Audrey (Little Shop of Horrors), Jeanie (Hair), Maureen (RENT), and Hattie (Kiss Me Kate). For updates or more info head to: allisonsheareed.com

story:
Video:  Shakespeare Downtown's Richard III at Castle Clinton in 2017 - Richard (Evan Olson).  Directed by Geoffrey Horne. 

We hope you will be a part of the new Shakespeare theatre at Castle Clinton.

We have started a new 501(c)(3) nonprofit Shakespeare theatre company in Lower Manhattan, Shakespeare Downtown.  We stage free Shakespeare plays every summer at Castle Clinton National Monument in Battery Park.  Like Shakespeare's Globe Theatre, Castle Clinton is in the open-air, in the round, on the water.  There will be seating for 200 people a night - a new Shakespeare in the Park for Lower Manhattan.  A Midsummer Night's Dream, our third production, will open June 14th and run through June 24th (Thursdays through Sundays) from 6:30 pm to 8:30 pm.   (Our first production, Romeo and Juliet, was in 2016, and Richard III in 2017.)

Shakespeare Downtown evolved out of 10 years of successful productions.  Geoffrey Horne, the director, is a founder of Shakespeare Downtown, and a long-time member of the Actors Studio.  He has been an acting teacher at the Lee Strasberg Theatre & Film Institute for over 35 years.  He also worked as an actor in movies such as The Bridge on the River Kwai and Bonjour Tristesse, and in the theatre and television.  Billie Andersson is the co-founder of Shakespeare Downtown, and an actress and producer of 13 plays.  Filmed excerpts of the plays can be seen at www.shakespearedowntown.org and at www.billieandersson.com.

We have gotten support from the National Park Service, Downtown Alliance, Battery Park City Authority, NYC & Company, A.R.T./New York, and Community Board 1.  We have been mentioned in The Observer, The Downtown Express, DNAinfo, Tribeca Trib Online, Time Out New York, and NY1.  Well-known members of the acting community - Alec Baldwin, Terence McNally, Estelle Parsons, John Douglas Thompson, Anna Strasberg, and the late Mike Nichols have lent their names as supporters of Shakespeare Downtown. 

All of the artists involved in the production are donating their services to make this new theatre possible.  By supporting these free outdoor Shakespeare productions, you will help provide the opportunity for thousands of people to experience Shakespeare in a castle – and help to create a new annual cultural event in Lower Manhattan.  Please join us in our endeavor! 

What we need:
$3,000 for the audio rental
$1,000 for the lights
$1,500 for the insurance for the castle
$1,500 for 200 chairs
$1,000 for the costumes
$500 for the programs and flyers
$8,500 total

Why we need your help:
Individual donations show community support and help us build our audience.  Every single dollar helps us get closer to our goal.

Other ways you can help:
If you can't contribute, you can still help.  Please share this campaign with your friends and family.

You can make a difference.
Thank you in advance for your generous support!

story:
We are Ben Kulvichit and Clara Potter-Sweet. We make live performance, under the name ‘Emergency Chorus’. We like loud music, costume changes and getting sweaty.

We made ‘CELEBRATION’, and performed it in December 2016, as a response to the most politically unstable year we could remember, but which was also the year we met each other, became good friends, and had felt the happiest in our own lives. In short, CELEBRATION is a show about reconciling those two contradictory feelings and finding joy in uncertain times.

We’ve been very fortunate to be chosen for the National Student Drama Festival 2017; so we- along with the inimitable Ciara Shrager and Nat Norland, who made beautiful lights and beautiful sounds respectively- are all heading to the bright lights of Hull this April!

We do need your help to get us there, and are crowdfunding to raise money for:

> Transport up and down from Hull

> Accommodation for the week

> Food for the week.


We’d very much love and appreciate your donations, big or small, to what is (hopefully) the first step in a much longer journey for Emergency Chorus!

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.
story_txt: Short Summary Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:  Introduce yourself and your background. Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you. Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.  Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?   What We Need & What You Get Break it down for folks in more detail:  Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.  Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited! Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.    The Impact Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:  Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world. Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!   And that's all there is to it.

story:
“Who protects those that protect us?”
 
New one woman play, Victim invites us to step inside the prison walls and into the minds of officer Tracey and inmate Siobhan.  Brutal, topical and darkly funny, this explosive new work from Bruised Sky looks at the power struggle between prison guard and criminal as they come face to face with a notorious inmate. 

This one-women show follows on from Bruised Sky’s 2016 hit Villain and we are delighted to have confirmed a run at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival with Pleasance Theatre. 

Bruised Sky Press:

Scarily and effectively shows how life can be shattered by public vilification
The Stage ★★★★ (on Villain)

an incredibly engaging, relevant and well performed piece of theatre. 
Remote Goat ★★★★★ (On Villain.)

Timely, relevant and deftly crafted, it will leave you reeling 
ThreeWeeks ★★★★ (on Villain.)

Who We Are

Bruised Sky Productions

Our aim at Bruised Sky is to push the boundaries of theatre and film.

We make raw, passionate, truthful work.

We want new productions with no limits. No excuses.

Martin Murphy – Playwright and Artistic Director

Martin's previous writing credits for theatre include Worlds (VAULT Festival), RockStar (Lyric Hammersmith, YHWF), Villain (Underbelly)  Manor (Soho Theatre) and Barren (Old Vic) as well as numerous works at venues including Liverpool Everyman Theatre. For screen Martin's work includes the short film Poisoned. 

Kevin Millband – Technical Manager

Kevin trained in Sound Design and has worked as a technician in a range of venues including Soho Theatre and the Edinburgh Fringe.

Hannah Cox – Associate Producer

Hannah is the Young People's Programme Manager at the National Theatre and has been working in Arts Education for 13 years. She has extensive experience programming and producing for National Theatre, Southbank Centre, Soho Theatre, and numerous smaller organisations, as well as running her own company Crafternoon Cabaret Club. Hannah is a passionate advocate for political theatre and new writing.

Why we need you

Taking a show to Edinburgh is an expensive undertaking, but a huge opportunity. Due to the success of our previous show Villain we have been able to reinvest profits into this show and secured some private backing which has helped us to cover some costs including travel and accommodation.  However we are also hoping to secure investments, of every size, to help us cover these costs:

- Paying our actress and marketing team.

- Pay for marketing materials such as flyers, posters and brochure listings .

We are looking to raise £1000 to support this show and give this important story a future life.  Our fundraising objectives mean that every penny of money made through ticket sales up at the fringe can then be reinvested into a London run and UK tour of this play.

How to donate

You can donate via this Indiegogo campaign where we have a range of fantastic rewards waiting for you for donations ranging from £10 to £50.

Other ways you can help

You can also help us by sharing this campaign with your friends and colleagues and spreading the word on social media about the Edinburgh run.

#VictimThePlay

@BruisedSky

www.bruisedskyproductions.com

story:
The Team

We’re Wendy Hui, Zack Rocklin-Waltch, and Diaya Fuller, a couple of theatre creators based in the LA area, and we need your help getting our next project, Confessions of a Former Boy Detective, onto the stage of the Hollywood Fringe Festival this year. Wendy, our producer, is a recent graduate of USC’s B.F.A. program in Theatre Design and minor in Cinematic Arts, with years of experience producing student theatre. Zack, our writer and performer, is currently enrolled in USC’s B.F.A. Acting program, and has written and produced two full length plays in a university setting. Diaya, our director, is a current USC student majoring in Theatre with an emphasis in acting and minoring in Screenwriting. She has worked as teaching artist and assistant marketing director with Fringe Benefits Theatre.

The Hollywood Fringe is the premiere festival for new and independent theatre projects in Los Angeles. Every summer, hundreds of artists produce groundbreaking works of theatre throughout venues in the city, and this year, we would love our project to be among them.

The Solo Show

Confessions of a Former Boy Detective is an honest and humorous solo play at this year's Hollywood Fringe Festival that tells the story of a young man who was once half of an illustrious child detective duo with his twin sister. He reflects on his old cases, his struggles with mental illness, and the now broken relationship between him and his sister. It is a frank meditation on childhood, addiction, queerness, and siblinghood, and we believe it is a story that needs to be told.

Link to the show website - http://hff21.co/7199

Your Contribution Matters

It's exciting to bring live theatre back to our lives after over a year of quarantine! However, producing theatre can be costly, especially for young artists. That’s why we’re asking for your contribution to help us produce this piece and continue to create bold and exciting theatre. With your donations, we can tell this important story and use the opportunity to begin dialogue, create work for other young artists, and join the upcoming generation of creators who are challenging what theatre can and should be, for everyone, forever.

story:
Wanton Theatre is a group of students from St Andrews University with a passion for theatre. We are taking John Ford's 'Tis Pity She's A Whore to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe. This play offers opportunities to 16 students to experience professional theatre at the world's largest arts festival.



'Tis Pity She's A Whore is a bloody and thought-provoking spectacle. We are looking for £1500 to help cover venue costs, which will be our greatest expenditure. Every little helps! 

As thanks for helping us out, you'll receive some of our fabulous perks: personal video thanks, a heart preparation experience with our stage manager, production hoodies, and limited edition souvenir bottled hearts  are all up for grabs!

We are an experienced team and have put a lot of time into our preproduction: lighting, set, costumes, and script have been very carefully planned  - and we are already rehearsing! 

If you can't spare any money then please please please follow us on social media, and share our campaign! And, of course, come see the show in Edinburgh! 


Thank you!

Danielle, Ryan, and Mishia

story:
We at Loquitur Theatre are taking our second project on tour. Already a four star hit at our previews at The Vaults in Waterloo last month, we have another two previews at Hackney Showroom, before the Edinburgh Fringe in August. 

Our Show

Fémage à Trois is a trilogy of independent stories, told by the women central to them, as they battle with their demons and the consequences of their situation. Charming, dark, sometimes hilarious, desperately normal; each story illustrates the incredible strength needed to meet life and its challenges head on. 

Directed by Lou-Lou Mason, and featuring ground breaking work by Charlotte O'Leary with the shocking 'I Don't Care’; simple, empathic 'Closure' by Bruntwood Prize winning Anna Jordan, and Nick Cox with the beautifully poignant 'And, Breathe'. Performed by Cat Van Dort, Gemma Harvey & Meryl Griffiths. 

Our Pitch

Making theatre is really hard work. It's doubly hard as there's no money to do it with. It's even harder, because in these challenging times, we need theatre more now than ever. We, as audience, as human beings, need to see stories, complex situations and each others lives and issues in a safe environment to make sense of the world we live in. There is very little funding for theatre, so now we're asking you to be part of it. If you believe in championing the arts, then this is a really easy way to get involved. No donation is too small. All donations are gratefully received.  

Our Company

Founded by Gemma Harvey and Lou-Lou Mason, Loquitur Theatre works collaboratively with artists, writers, directors, producers and venues to present a range of exciting, dynamic classical and contemporary plays. You can learn more about us here: www.loquiturtheatre.co.uk

Us
Gemma and Lou-Lou have worked together for many years, both artistically and through creating and developing relationships and opportunities across theatre, film and television, with casting directors, writers, directors and actors. We believe in encouraging an open-door policy throughout the industry, and we actively support artists in developing their career. Loquitur Theatre is the culmination of a decade of our shared experience across the industry and our close personal and professional relationship.


As our company name translates – ‘She speaks’ – we are committed to increasing the level of representation of women in theatre, therefore the stories we tell will have women central to them, and women will fill at least half the roles of cast and crew engaged to each Loquitur Theatre project.

story:
Short Summary

Fab Nobs Theatre Inc is a non-for profit organisation, which is dedicated to producing three major musical theatre productions a year.Based in the Eastern Suburbs of Melbourne, Fab Nobs is known for not only presenting high quality and diverse productions, but for its unique theatrical space and strong ties with community involvement.

 Fab Nobs formed in 2003, staged its first production A Slice of Saturday Night in a converted factory on Burgess Road, Bayswater.   In 2008 Fab Nobs changed location to 33 Industry Place, Bayswater, where they transformed “the factory” into a theatrical space ideal for diverse productions. 

 The cabaret like atmosphere provides the perfect setting to stage unique concerts and productions that range from the classics: Little Shop of Horrors, A Little Night Music and A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum, to the contemporary: Next to Normal, The Drowsy Chaperone and Avenue Q, as well as the quirky Zombie Prom, Return to the Forbidden Planet and tick, tick, BOOM, just to name a few. 

 Fab Nobs is dedicated to involving all members of the community, whether it is to be on the stage or behind the scenes. Everyone is welcome. Fab Nobs are also devoted to giving back to the community, having made donations to many charities. Students have also had the opportunity to experience the ‘theatre world’ through a ‘Work Experience’ program, which has been highly regarded within the community.

What We Need & What You Get

For anyone who has been to a production at Fab Nobs, you’ll know that our venue does not do well with the elements; it’s either too hot or too cold! This has had a massive impact on when we put on shows throughout the year and has made rehearsing for shows a bit uncomfortable too. We would love to install new air-conditioning and heating units into the factory by Summer, but we need your help! Our goal is $7,000 this will include the purchase of the units and installation. Having these new units will mean our theatre will be more comfortable for our audiences and everyone who is involved with our various productions throughout the year. Every little bit helps!
Our perks include complimentary drinks and snacks from the bar, tickets for our upcoming shows and special mentions in our programs. It also means that you'll be toasty and warm in winter and nice and cool in summer when you catch our productions!
Even if we don't reach our end goal, any donated funds will go towards purchasing and installing the new unit into our theatre.

Other Ways You Can Help

Every little bit helps but we understand that sometimes donating isn't possible. All we ask is that people spread the word about our campaign!

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help.

story:
Hi, we're F*It Club!

You know, in the spirit of "why are we waiting for people to give us work; f*it, let's make our own work!"

Since 2011, we have worked exclusively on short-form projects: short film, short theatre, and short-term events. To date:

  • We've worked with over 360 artists
  • Presented over 50 world-premiere, commissioned pieces of theater (plus films, web series, pop-up bar experiences, retreats, Halloween events, site-specific work, and more)
  • Been nominated for 17 New York Innovative Theatre Awards (with 2 wins!)
  • Hired TV people, Broadway people, Pulitzer Prize-winning people...and everyone in between, with our mission always being to bridge the gap between established and emerging artists.

Coming up on 2019-2020, we're entering our ninth and tenth seasons, respectively. And in 2020, our tenth year, we'll be bringing F*It Club and our tentpole piece, The Spring Fling to a close. (Sad! But also YAY! TEN F*ING YEARS!)

For almost a decade, we've relied primarily on individual donations and ticket sales to help keep our work going, without much, if any, government support or grants. We're just going to ask for money from you *one last time* to get us through Spring Fling: On Screen in 2019, and Spring Fling: Finale in 2020.

We're so proud of all of the work we've made, relationships we've formed, and the impact we've had in the off-off-Broadway community. We need your help, however, to see us through to the end of ten years and send off our work with the respect and celebration it deserves!

More specifically:

In 2019, we're producing THREE new, world-premiere films, written by two former Spring Fling playwrights, Hilary Bettis (The Americans), and Ashlin Halfnight (Bloodline), as well as Allyson Morgan (Tribeca Film Festival). All of the films will also be co-produced by Allyson and Academy Award-winning producer Mara Kassin (yes, really!) Each film is a distinct meditation on death, but will also be a stand alone piece that we intend to submit to festivals world-wide.

We anticipate the budget for all three of these films landing between $10-15K, going to cast and crew salaries, insurance, equipment rentals, transportation, catering, and post production services, among others.

In 2020, we'll blow it out with our final return year of The Spring Fling: Finale, featuring ten world-premiere commissioned plays and ten performances in honor of our tenth year. Our intention is to bring back five alumni playwrights and add five new. The Spring Fling always traditionally costs between $8-$10K, with money going to rehearsal space, performance space, insurance, copies, props, costumes, set, lights, sound, and more.

As you can see, we're ultimately reaching out to fund about half of our last two years, and hope to bring in the remainder through grants and ticket sales.  The more we are able to bring in, the better both of these productions will be and run - our intention is not to keep any money in the bank at the end of 2020. We've learned how to be frugal and make ends meet, but we'd really like to step it up these last two years

Perks!

Check 'em out to the right! ----->

We'll be adding more throughout the campaign, so keep checking back! We have theatre, film, and assorted miscellaneous perks to cater to all of your heart's desires. (Well. Some of them, anyway.)

Truly, any help you can give MAKES A BIG DIFFERENCE, including shout outs and sharing via social media and forwarding on email!

We have only ever been on a biennial fundraising schedule for these nine (almost ten) years, demonstrating that we’re both fiscally responsible and extremely cautious about how we use your money throughout the year. Hopefully our track record of not just surviving, but thriving, over this time thus far should help demonstrate the value of  your contribution.

SO SMASH THAT DONATE BUTTON!

But don't just take our word for it:

"The writing here is insightful and often funny" - The New York Times

“Shows like ‘Spring-Fling’ are rare. Indomitably weird and high-brow, but without being esoteric to the point of pretension. The writing is unique, the direction excellent, and the cast on-point. I highly recommend it if you need to see theatre that is unlike every other show on or off Broadway. It’s what I wish every one-act festival could be. This was a venue for honest theatrical experimentation, performed by people who unquestionably knew what they were doing. I love that. I recommend checking out F* It Club’s work in future.” – On Stage Blog

“F*It Club ... have come up with an enjoyable invitation in this entertaining night. It gave me an appetizing taste of some gifted writers, actors, and directors, and kept me engaged and interested throughout much of the evening. Overall, it was a highly enjoyable night of theater. F*It Club is right, you do deserve a Spring Fling.” - NYTheatre.com

“The Spring Fling has its S*IT together. Not only are all of the pieces thoughtful, but the overall production values make for a cohesive and enjoyable evening of theatre. Producers Allyson Morgan and Mara Kassin have assembled a stellar team of playwrights, performers and directors to bring these works to life. ...includes work by artists who are simply good at what they do. This evening of quick and high-quality work is well worth your time and attention.” 
- Theatre is Easy

"A sumptuous theatrical buffet...It is thrilling to see how each playwright has imaginatively explored the theme and developed rounded, detailed characters and powerful dialogue. It's a gratifying marathon of plays that gives your feel-good synapses a workout. It’s such a lot of fun to watch this carousel of creativity whip past. It’s a wonderful project to support. “The Spring Fling” is a well rehearsed, sleek, sophisticated evening where you can see the evidence of a strong production and design team ensuring a high standard of work...an extremely enjoyable night at the theater." - Stage Biz

“The results this year held a few surprises, some standouts, and never failed to be fascinating. Overall, another strong year for F*IT club, showcasing plays that one legitimately feels would not exist anywhere but here. More than that though, it should once again be stressed how few evenings of one-act plays are assembled with any sense of cohesion. Spring Fling categorically feels like it is put together with care, nuance, and with the aim to produce a night of plays that flow gracefully from one to the other, rather than zig-zagging across a wild spectrum of content, and quality, as most similar festivals do. Everything here is consistently enjoyable, comparable in its content, and creative in its presentation.” – PopDust

In Closing:

We love you and are so grateful for any and all support. And again: this is the last time we'll ask for your help! So maybe consider throwing in a couple extra bucks to get us to 2020? 

We would sincerely love and appreciate if you could help spread the word for our campaign with your friends, family, and colleagues. Twitter, Facebook, Instagram, and other social media are all great ways to get the word out.

Thanks in advance for your support.

Yours (for two more years of f*ing up film, theatre, and events),
Allyson + F*It Club

Coming up on 2019-2020, we're entering our ninth and tenth seasons, respectively. And in 2020, our tenth year, we'll be bringing F*It Club and our tentpole piece, The Spring Fling to a close. (Sad! But also YAY! TEN F*ING YEARS!)
For almost a decade, we've relied primarily on individual donations and ticket sales to help keep our work going, without much, if any, government support or grants. We're just going to ask for money from you *one last time* to get us through Spring Fling: On Screen in 2019, and Spring Fling: Finale in 2020.
We're so proud of all of the work we've made, relationships we've formed, and the impact we've had in the off-off-Broadway community. We need your help, however, to see us through to the end of ten years and send off our work with the respect and celebration it deserves!

More specifically:
In 2019, we're producing THREE new, world-premiere films, written by two former Spring Fling playwrights, Hilary Bettis (The Americans), and Ashlin Halfnight (Bloodline), as well as Allyson Morgan (Tribeca Film Festival). All of the films will also be co-produced by Allyson and Academy Award-winning producer Mara Kassin (yes, really!) Each film is a distinct meditation on death, but will also be a stand alone piece that we intend to submit to festivals world-wide.
We anticipate the budget for all three of these films landing between $10-15K, going to cast and crew salaries, insurance, equipment rentals, transportation, catering, and post production services, among others.
In 2020, we'll blow it out with our final return year of The Spring Fling: Finale, featuring ten world-premiere commissioned plays and ten performances in honor of our tenth year. Our intention is to bring back five alumni playwrights and add five new. The Spring Fling always traditionally costs between $8-$10K, with money going to rehearsal space, performance space, insurance, copies, props, costumes, set, lights, sound, and more.
As you can see, we're ultimately reaching out to fund about half of our last two years, and hope to bring in the remainder through grants and ticket sales.  The more we are able to bring in, the better both of these productions will be and run - our intention is not to keep any money in the bank at the end of 2020. We've learned how to be frugal and make ends meet, but we'd really like to step it up these last two years

Perks!
Check 'em out to the right! ----->
We'll be adding more throughout the campaign, so keep checking back! We have theatre, film, and assorted miscellaneous perks to cater to all of your heart's desires. (Well. Some of them, anyway.)
Truly, any help you can give MAKES A BIG DIFFERENCE, including shout outs and sharing via social media and forwarding on email!
We have only ever been on a biennial fundraising schedule for these nine (almost ten) years, demonstrating that we’re both fiscally responsible and extremely cautious about how we use your money throughout the year. Hopefully our track record of not just surviving, but thriving, over this time thus far should help demonstrate the value of  your contribution.
SO SMASH THAT DONATE BUTTON!

But don't just take our word for it:
"The writing here is insightful and often funny" - The New York Times
“Shows like ‘Spring-Fling’ are rare. Indomitably weird and high-brow, but without being esoteric to the point of pretension. The writing is unique, the direction excellent, and the cast on-point. I highly recommend it if you need to see theatre that is unlike every other show on or off Broadway. It’s what I wish every one-act festival could be. This was a venue for honest theatrical experimentation, performed by people who unquestionably knew what they were doing. I love that. I recommend checking out F* It Club’s work in future.” – On Stage Blog
“F*It Club ... have come up with an enjoyable invitation in this entertaining night. It gave me an appetizing taste of some gifted writers, actors, and directors, and kept me engaged and interested throughout much of the evening. Overall, it was a highly enjoyable night of theater. F*It Club is right, you do deserve a Spring Fling.” - NYTheatre.com
“The Spring Fling has its S*IT together. Not only are all of the pieces thoughtful, but the overall production values make for a cohesive and enjoyable evening of theatre. Producers Allyson Morgan and Mara Kassin have assembled a stellar team of playwrights, performers and directors to bring these works to life. ...includes work by artists who are simply good at what they do. This evening of quick and high-quality work is well worth your time and attention.” - Theatre is Easy
"A sumptuous theatrical buffet...It is thrilling to see how each playwright has imaginatively explored the theme and developed rounded, detailed characters and powerful dialogue. It's a gratifying marathon of plays that gives your feel-good synapses a workout. It’s such a lot of fun to watch this carousel of creativity whip past. It’s a wonderful project to support. “The Spring Fling” is a well rehearsed, sleek, sophisticated evening where you can see the evidence of a strong production and design team ensuring a high standard of work...an extremely enjoyable night at the theater." - Stage Biz“The results this year held a few surprises, some standouts, and never failed to be fascinating. Overall, another strong year for F*IT club, showcasing plays that one legitimately feels would not exist anywhere but here. More than that though, it should once again be stressed how few evenings of one-act plays are assembled with any sense of cohesion. Spring Fling categorically feels like it is put together with care, nuance, and with the aim to produce a night of plays that flow gracefully from one to the other, rather than zig-zagging across a wild spectrum of content, and quality, as most similar festivals do. Everything here is consistently enjoyable, comparable in its content, and creative in its presentation.” – PopDust

In Closing:
We love you and are so grateful for any and all support. And again: this is the last time we'll ask for your help! So maybe consider throwing in a couple extra bucks to get us to 2020? 
We would sincerely love and appreciate if you could help spread the word for our campaign with your friends, family, and colleagues. Twitter, Facebook, Instagram, and other social media are all great ways to get the word out.
Thanks in advance for your support.
Yours (for two more years of f*ing up film, theatre, and events),Allyson + F*It Club

story:
Short Summary

Hey guys! My name is Greg and I am producing a show for children in Long Beach, California. I have produced various shows on the East Coast, so I really want to bring my production company to Southern, California!

What We Need & What You Get

We need $1000,00 dollars. However, we are only asking for $500.00 because we know times are so hard. 

The Impact

I will be taking a HUGE step by producing my first children's show in Southern, CA. Bringing happiness to people with the arts is my biggest passion. Making this show is SO important to me. 

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help.

If you can't help and live in Southern CA, message me about to see how you can spread the word about the show!

Thank you. So much love to you all.

-Greg

story:
Short Summary

Hello friends!  It's been an exciting year at Elite!  Our student body has almost doubled, as have our competition teams (and they've brought home some first place trophies!)  We have big plans for expanding our space to accommodate the ever-growing studio!  We're doubling the size of Studio B by combining it with the birthday party room, and we're installing a state-of-the-art sprung wood dance floor.  We're also doubling the parent lounge, getting vending machines, creating a reception area in the lobby, and installing an aerial rig in Studio A!  In addition to the BIG changes, we are purchasing additional acrobatics mats and ballet barres, and we have a few little beautification projects planned.

What We Need & What You Get

 We've secured three-fourths of our needed funding, but we need your help to close the gap and make it all happen! For your kindness, we will gladly give tokens of our appreciation, ranging from an Elite Dancewear Item, to a free dance class for a semester!

The Impact

 We strive to keep up with the growing needs of our dancers' expanding talent.  These improvements and expansions will allow our dancers to improve upon their abilities with the proper space and equipment to increase their skills.  The larger observation area for parents, play area for young siblings, and front desk area will improve and streamline parents' and guests' experiences in our studio.

Risks & Challenges

 Taking on the loans we've secured for this project is a leap of faith, but one that we know will pay off.  Your donations will close this gap and allow us to complete this project, and no amount is too small!  The better our dancers are, the better our studio is, and we know that this is something that will attract even more new students, as well as sparking our existing dancers' interest in expanding their skills with new classes.

Other Ways You Can Help

The opportunity to be a part of your lives is truly a gift.  We appreciate our Elite family so much!  If this is not a good time for you to donate, please help us by getting the word out about our studio!  Bring a friend to an Elite event or class, share this link with friends or relatives that may be interested in donating to this project, or just keep being your wonderful selves.  Thank you for all that you bring to this great studio!

story:
Who Are You & What Do You Want?

Alright you primitive screw heads, listen up. Tacoma Belly Dance has been putting on themed belly dance shows since 2013 and we are excited to announce our 4th run of the hit show, Horrific!: A Night of Horror Themed Belly Dance! What's that? Horror...themed...belly dance? You heard that right. 450 people agree, that Horrific is a hell of a show. Seeing that our show has grown from a small studio show to a public theater experience we are looking to up the ante and put on the best show yet. To do so, we need support from viewers like you.

Tacoma Belly Dance started with its owner and artistic director, Kat Welsh. Kat is a long time belly dance perform who teaches classical American Cabaret Belly Dance weekly at Tacoma Dance Studios. She has always had a strong love for horror and wanted to fuse the two loves into a show that would be fun, all inclusive, and a littel bit weird. Ok, it's real weird. 

What We Need & What You Get

To fund the show is not a cheap task:

  • We are asking $3,000 to help fund the initial deposit for the theater. Last year we utilized the Rialto Theater in downtown Tacoma. We so enjoyed the space, and it truly allows us to grow in our audience as well as give dancers an amazing stage. The Rialto can hold up to 700 people, allowing our annual audience growth of 50%. The Broadway Center (owners of the Rialto) helped provide us with a lighting crew, backstage crew, ushers, security, and ticket sales. As a small company, these kind of services are invaluable. We are also interested in keeping our show in Tacoma as we truly believe in local art and business.
  • "Yeah yeah yeah, but what do I get out if it?" Perks! We want to make sure you know your money is well invested. In return, we have added perks. Those include a "thank you" in the program, Stickers, Merchandise, Tickets to the show, backstage passes, private belly dance lessons, photos with the cast, and even a role in the show!
  • If we don't reach the goal, all funds will still go to the production of the show. The show must go on!

The Impact

Our show brings something different and unique to the horror scene. It showcases professional belly dance performers through the art of storytelling. It also houses a space for people of all genders, ages, and body types to showcase their art. When you contribute to our show, it also supports the artists who deserve a space on stage. 

  • Your contribution means that we can focus on the art and direction of the show making a better overall product. Peace of mind means a lot to us!
  • Being that this is our 4th year, we have a strong handle on how to make a successful production. Help us provide the show to you.
  • The people who work on the show have other life commitments outside of dance. Any help beforehand makes the process much smoother.

Risks & Challenges

Putting on a production is a risky process! We invest a large amount of time, energy, and money into the show. It is always possible to fail and not sell the tickets that we hope to sell. We hope to overcome these battles with these key elements. 

  • This is our 4th year for the show. Each year it has more than doubled in attendance with new and old faces returning every time. Last years show sold just over 450 tickets. If we continue the growth, we should see numbers of around 600 attendees. 
  • This is also not a new adventure for us. Tacoma Belly Dance has been putting on successful dance productions since 2014 and smaller monthly shows since 2013. 
  • Our plan is to merge into different avenues for marketing. This includes more involvement at Crypticon (a yearly horror convention), local horror-themed shows, presence with bands in the shock rock scene, and heavier social media presence and content creation. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Share our event, IndieGoGo, or website both on social media and in person!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to make this easy!

story:
Mon histoire

Je danse depuis que j'ai 5 ans. J'ai d'abord commencé une heure par semaine mais j'aimais tellement le ballet que j'ai vite passé à deux heures par semaine. En 2011, je suis partie vivre un an en Jordanie et j'ai dû me rendre à l'évidence: le ballet est un hobby au Proche-Orient et il n'y a pas encore de bonnes écoles pour apprendre la danse classique. 

En 2012, je suis rentrée en Suisse et j'ai intégré un programme pré-professionnel chez Brigitte Roman à Yverdon. Je dansais 14 heures par semaine. En 2014, j'ai fait un stage chez Igokat à Lausanne et j'ai beaucoup aimé l'approche, j'ai alors décidé d'intégrer le programme pré-pro dans cette école. Je danse à Lausanne depuis 8 mois à raison de 14 heures par semaine.

En Jordanie, j'étais scolarisée dans une école américaine et j'ai donc appris l'anglais. Je considère les Etats-Unis comme ma deuxième patrie et je rêve d'y aller, j'ai d'ailleurs de la famille là-bas.

Mon avenir

Je termine l'école obligatoire dans quelques mois et je dois décider si je continue au gymnase ou si je me lance dans une formation de danseuse pour en faire mon métier. Pour cela, j'ai postulé pour des stages d'été de danse dans plusieurs écoles aux Etats-Unis afin de voir si je pourrais envisager de me former là-bas à plus long terme.

La surprise!

J'ai eu l'énorme surprise d'apprendre que j'étais sélectionnée parmi plusieurs centaines de candidats pour un stage d'été (summer intensive en anglais) et j'ai donc l'opportunité de partir pour Jackson, Mississippi durant 1 mois cet été pour danser entre 4 et 6 heures par jour. Je me réjouis de partir mais pour cela, j'ai besoin de vous car le stage et le voyage ont un certain coût.

Pourquoi j'ai besoin de 5500 dollars:

  • Cours de danse, logement/nourriture sur le campus pour 4 semaines: 3200 $
  • Billet d'avion aller-retour: 1800 Chf
  • Vêtements pour le gala: justaucorps, 24,50 $, jupette 23,50 $
  • Chaussons pour le stage: chaussures de jazz 30 chf, paires de pointes 120 chf, collants, 30 chf, justaucorps, 25 chf, short pour le moderne, 25 chf.

Voilà où je vais: http://www.balletmagnificat.com/

story:
What if you could live forever? On New Year's Eve in 1625, Will Timeson and Jack Mercer discover the secret of immortality – an elixir that will grant them the gift of eternal life. But is it a gift? When the two men fall in love with the same woman -- a beautiful, young woman with a dark, painful secret – the stage is set for a grand, musical epic about friendship, love, betrayal and redemption spanning several tumultuous centuries and set to a sweeping, romantic score.

My name is Brett Boles, and I've written the book, music, and lyrics to FOREVERMAN, which will have its world premiere at the New York Musical Theatre Festival (NYMF) this July.  NYMF is the largest and most prestigious musical theatre festival in the world, and we are incredibly excited to have the opportunity to put this show up this summer.  NYMF is our first major step on the road to Broadway and the rest of the world.

YOU can help make this happen.  Wouldn't it be awesome to see this show on Broadway and know that you helped get it there?  New, original work simply cannot happen without grass roots support to build a fan base and propel it forward.  The world (and producers) need to know that YOU want to see this succeed.  They need to know that YOU believe in it.

So please support FOREVERMAN on its journey from my home studio to the rest of the world.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise a total of $85,000 in order to bring this show to life the way it deserves to be.  The goal here is set at $5,000.  We would LOVE to exceed this.

Your money goes to pay our dedicated actors, design staff, directors, and production crew.  Some of your dollars will be used to pay for rehearsal space, copies of scripts and scores, orchestrations for a six-piece band, advertising and publicity, and perhaps even a much needed coffee on tech day!

Indiegogo keeps only 4% of the money we raise if we reach our $5,000 goal.  If we do NOT meet our goal, we keep all but 9%.  

Make sure to check out the perks you'll receive as well, including (at varying levels of contribution) a baseball cap, tote bad, and a T-shirt - all with the FOREVERMAN logo.  Be one of the few to have an ORIGINAL piece of FOREVERMAN merchandise before it evolves into the Broadway version...it may be worth something one day!

The Impact

NYMF is our first big step on the road to Broadway and the rest of the world.  Let's make this a sensation.  The message of this musical is universal, and could have a huge impact on people from every corner of the earth.  With the internet available to us, there are no limits to what we can accomplish with this piece.  NYMF's motto is "Changing the world, 30 musicals at a time."  It only takes one to change the world.  Let's make it FOREVERMAN.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, please spread the word on Facebook and Twitter and other social media.  Share the songs with friends and family.  Each person has the ability to EXPONENTIALLY increase the circulation of this material.  Let's do it!

Visit the Official Foreverman Website at www.forevermanthemusical.com for news, updates, MEDIA, and to join our email list.

Visit the show's page on the NYMF website for show dates and/or to buy tickets at www.nymf.org/foreverman (tickets go on sale for NYMF members Tuesday May 15th and for the General Public on June 15th).

LET'S MAKE THIS ONE FOR THE RECORD BOOKS!

story:
If you believe more in the humanity of 9/11 than the tragedy,

If you believe in volunteerism,

If you believe in the power of music and theater,

Join us in our campaign today.

Thank you to the many people who have contributed over $12,000 in in-kind support over the past several months. This continues to increase with every passing week. We couldn't have done it without you!

PIECES OF PAPER - ASPIRATIONS OF 9/11 is a visceral multimedia meditation on the power of human compassion in action the week of September 11, 2001. A large ensemble of performers representing every walk of life take you on an emotional theatrical journey, using movement, video, text and an original soundcsape by internationally acclaimed composer Anton Batagov, conceived and directed by Michael Simon Hall, theater artist and 9/11 first responder.

 

This story of hope is inspired by actual handwritten documents created the week of 9/11 by grassroots volunteers at the Chelsea Piers Support Center in New York City.

 

The project has been in development since the spring of 2010, and was recently awarded the opportunity to present at the acclaimed producing organization, HERE, NYC, May 12 - 14, 2011, to work toward the goal of a full fall production for the tenth anniversary of 9/11.

 

PoP strives to be a source of healing for all peoples everywhere affected by the attacks of September 11, 2001. By depicting the actions of grassroots volunteers that week, PoP hopes to inspire others to compassionate action in the name of our fallen heros and departed loved ones, as a way of never forgetting.

 

Supporting the 9/11 Community

 

The production also plans to raise awareness and monetary support for various September 11-related community groups. One example of how we are doing this is by providing a venue for the First Responders Alliance, a program of Tuesday's Children, to enlighten the audience on their mission and resources for helping first responders and their families everywhere, as well as ways to volunteer. Tuesday's Children is a national non-profit organization supporting the children of 9/11 and others impacted by global terrorism.

 

The impetus for this production, the pieces of paper themselves, were collected by the creator Michael Simon Hall on Sunday, September 16th, 2001, when the grassroots volunteer operation at Chelsea Piers where he was volunteering was shut down by the Office of Emergency Management, and the hundreds of volunteers were sent home.

 

These artifacts were featured at the New-York Historical Society in an exhibit called "Radical Hospitality", and have been on loan to the National September 11 Memorial Museum.

Please read on to learn more about the project, the creative team, exactly what we need your help with at this time, and what we can offer you in return.

 

 

Meet the Team!

 

Please learn more about us by clicking on our names at the bottom of the page or visiting the team page.

 

Composer: Anton Batagov

see team profile

 

"It is an honor for me to participate in this project. I feel some special connection with it. I am saying this not just as a composer but as a human being. This project is about the most important thing in this world: about transformation through active compassion. We live to help others. I am trying to use musical language to transmit these feelings."

 

 

Video Projection Designer: Shawn Boyle

 

Shawn's design work has been seen all over the US, including the Berkshire Theater Festival, and as associate/assistant for the national and international tours of Wicked and Spamalot. His New York credits include work at 59E59th, Ars Novas, and associate for Thurgood on Broadway and currently, the new Broadway musical, The People in the Picture, opening in April at Studio 54. 

 

 

Writer/Director: Michael Simon Hall

see team profile

 

"I was given a gift of these pieces of paper. This project is my personal way of saying thank you to volunteers and first responders everywhere. Hopefully it will act as a source of inspiration for all of us, to remind us of who we really are."

 

"Michael is a dynamic artist who does not limit himself to a particular form to realize his vision. He exhibits a sensitive intelligence and deep understanding. I couldn't imagine a more inspired or effective collaborator."

                                                                    - Pulitzer Award winning author, Robert Olen Butler

 

"This was a wonderful journey. I only hope Michael Simon Hall takes me along for another ride."

 

                                                                    - two-time Tony Award nominee, Andre DeShields

 

Justin Partier: Lighting Designer


Justin's designs have been seen regionally from coast to coast as well as internationally, with his associate design work seen on Broadway and off, in such productions as The Importance of Being Earnest currently at the Roundabout, 33 Variations starring Jane Fonda, as well as at Lincoln Center, The Public, New York Theater Workshop, LABrynth and 2nd Stage Theater companies.  

 

 

What We Need Help With Right Now

 

Pieces of Paper has already benefited from over $12,625 in in-kind donations, which is growing daily as you read this.  In the true spirit of cooperation that this project celebrates, we want to take this opportunity to say THANK YOU to all the dedicated professionals who have generously given of their time and talent.  It would not have been possible to come this far without the contibutions of many artists, administrators, 9/11 community leaders, marketers, and arts organizations.

 

While we have indeed gotten off to a great start, we do need financial support to defray the hard costs of completing this developmental leg of our journey.

 

PoP has been given a special opportunity to perform at HERE, the acclaimed NYC producing organization that supports multidisciplinary work not fitting into a conventional programming agenda. This production is a part of the Artists Lodge series of HEREstay, HERE's curated rental program, which provides artists with subsidized space and equipment, as well as technical and administrative support.

 

Let's hear it for HERE!

 

Being at HERE significantly defrays the hard costs of the development process that is essential to creating live theater, but unfortunately does not eliminate them.

 

The Breakdown

 

Right now, your contribution will help defray our most pressing developmental costs:

 

1. Current operational costs for the work-in-progress presentation at HERE: $7,800 (rehearsal space, insurance, equipment rentals, set pieces, basic marketing, and stipends for the company of 20 artists and crew.)

 

2. Legal and general management consultation to prepare for the fall production: $2,900.

 

Be sure to check out the great perks we are offering such as one of Anton's cd's, or tickets to opening night and a reception with the cast afterward.

 

In addition to the our growing in-kind donations, other, more traditional sources of funding are also being pursued, including grants and fundraising events, to ensure we meet our goals. This show will go on as an essential part of the development process for the fall production. Any donations received in excess of this campaign will go directly toward the full fall production.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

Can you spread the word to others who might be interested in our cause? Can you help make sure this inspiring story of compassion in the shadow of 9/11 gets seen by an audience at HERE and later this fall? This actually makes a big, BIG difference! There are great "share tools" you can use right at top of this page to connect with people you know who may be interested.  If enough people are aware and pitch in, we can achieve our goal in a short time.

 

Please don't hesitate to contact us for more information about this campaign or the fall production, and be sure to check back often for updates as things progress.

 

Thank you!

story:
Last year, William Hobbs founded Opera Slavica to provide an opportunity for up and coming artists to experience "big opera in small spaces"--making the grandeur of opera accessible to everyone. Director Kara-Lynn Vaeni accepted the challenge of staging the company's inaugural piece, Rusalka (double-cast and in Czech), with great success.

This year, Vaeni and Hobbs are building on their success and they need your help.

Follow us on twitter: twitter.com/operaslavica

story:
THANK YOU TO ALL OF OUR DONORS! 

We've reached our online goal of $6,000.00 - thanks to each of you!

Our plan for this tour is to raise $6,000.00 online and $6,000.00 offline to meet our minimum $12,000.00 target out of our total $18,000.00 production budget. We hope to make the remaining $6,000.00 through ticket sales in Halifax. 

We have $2,650.00 left to raise "offline" - but because there are still officially 23 days left of our Indiegogo campaign, this page will remain active and hopefully help us to raise the remaining $2,650.0 of our production budget. 

THANK YOU FOR YOUR CONTINUED SUPPORT! YOU ARE MAKING THIS TOUR POSSIBLE. 


Our Story

This past November, Theatre Erindale and our cast of 22 students created 1917: The Halifax Explosion, an original stage play based on the Halifax Explosion. Our play is a living portrait of Halifax during WWI, before and after the devastating explosion on the morning of December 6th, 1917. Our show combines true first-hand accounts, movement and choral singing with a silent film aesthetic to tell the story of Halifax’s resilience. The show ran for two weeks at Theatre Erindale in Mississauga and became the second-highest grossing show in the program’s history, selling out all but one performance. 1917: The Halifax Explosion was directed by Meredith Scott, choreographed by Marc Richard, musically directed by Anthony Bastianon (all part-time faculty members at Sheridan College) and designed by Toronto designer Angela Thomas. The piece is based on Mary Ann Monnon’s “Miracles and Mysteries,” and “December 1917” by Janet Kitz and Joan Payzant.

 

The box office success we experienced in Mississauga indicates that there is genuine interest in this compelling chapter of Canadian history. Our cast is dedicated to bringing our production to Halifax this spring to perform at the Alderney Landing Theatre from May 9th to 12th, 2012. As a self-producing student company, we are unfortunately ineligible for most government grants. We are relying on support from family, friends, and other individuals to make this ambitious tour possible. Any donation will help to cover the myriad of costs associated with a theatrical tour – everything from paying our theatre rental fees to laundering soldier uniforms! We are truly grateful for any support you can offer us.


Well Fought Theatre Company presents the Theatre Erindale production of...

 

December 1917: The Halifax Explosion

Adapted by the Company 
under the direction of Meredith Scott
from Mary Ann Monnon's Miracles and Mysteries
and Janet Kitz and Joan Payzant's December 1917
with the permission of Nimbus Publishing

 


Where Does Your Money Go?

Funds raised are purely for production, not personal costs! We're aiming to raise $6,000.00 here on Indiegogo and $6,000.00 from other sources. We'll be depending on ticket sales to cover the remaining $8,900.00 of our total production budget!

* Alderney Theatre rental cost

* Paying our Artistic Team (director, costume designer, choreographer, music director)

* Paying the Alderney Team (technicians, ushers, house manager)

* Transporting our set/costumes 

* Costume Fees (Wardrobe Assistant, dry-cleaning, mending/building) 

* Promotional Costs (poster/program printing, newspaper/radio ads) 

 

Other Ways You Can Help...

Follow us on Twitter @december1917

Like us on Facebook at http://www.facebook.com/pages/Well-Fought-Theat...

Check out our Tour Blog at http://halifaxexplosiontour.wordpress.com

story:
Short Summary

The Slapdash Festival started in 2010 with the Old Vic Tunnels, to showcase the best in UK improvisation. Over the two years since, the festival has expanded from a couple of days to nearly a week. This year our ambitions are even bigger.

The festival is being put together by Ryan Millar (Artistic Director) and Jules Munns (Executive Producer). Both are passionate about improv and are experienced performers, with over 15 years of improvisation between them. They perform regularly with The Maydays, Marbles and Silly String Theory. Ryan had some international connections, and after two years of a national festival, Jules was ready to expand on the success of the first two Slapdashes. 

And Slapdash International was born. Well almost... The festival kicks off in a little over six weeks, and we're looking for some funding to help deliver on the scope of the project.

We'll be bringing improvisers from all over, from Vienna to Vancouver and points in-between, and we need to make sure that they can eat and have places to sleep while they're here. We'd also like to pay them for their time and talents.

 

What We Need & What You Get

So here's what we need to pay for:

  • Publicity materials
  • Equipment rental
  • Per diems for performers
  • Travel expenses

We're looking for $1,300 (£800) which should just about cover the shortfall in our budget. We're going for 'revenue neutral' (i.e. not going broke).

The Impact

Improv can be powerful theatre, as well as a positive experience in the lives of improvisers. Creativity, personal growth, having laughs and sometimes surprising yourself with stories that are told only once. 

Contributing to this project will help us put on an important and powerful festival that will bring some of the finest improvisers from around the world to London, to collaborate, perform and teach with local improvisers and audiences.

The improv festival circuit is an incubator of talent and ideas - by bringing in accomplished talent from other countries we strengthen the work that happens in the UK. We also build audiences.

If you're not based in the UK, but love improv, you'll feel good about helping London and the UK grow its passionate improv community.

This is the third Slapdash Festival, each of the last two have grown in scope, but this festival is a whole other phase. That's why we're looking to the Indiegogo community for help.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not able to contribute any money, that's cool. It would still be great if you were able to help us spread the word. 

  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to help get the message out.
  • If you know someone who might be interested and able to help tell them about this.
  • If you're able to, come see a show and have a drink at the bar. Meet some great people, laugh, watch some great theatre.

That’s all there is to it.

story:
“OMG, I Love That Show!” Productions is a brand new theatre company in the San Francisco East Bay that is shaking up this suburb with a new and exciting kind of theatre experience. "OMG!" is a platform for unknown and rarely seen musicals giving new shows a venue to be seen, and audiences the opportunity to experience theatre in a fresh and vibrant environment. There is truly no other performing arts organization in the area devoted to producing the original shows that “OMG!” does.

At “OMG!” our mission is to present innovative and non-traditional shows with contemporary and cutting edge themes that showcase local talent and offer professional affordable theatre to the community. 

Audiences will walk in thinking, "Never heard of it" and leave saying, "OMG, I love that show!"

Where Does the Money Go?

-$800 to file for 501(c)3 tax-exeption with the IRS. 

-$200 to secure the theatre for performances.

-$1000 upfront production costs for our inaugural production including insurance, costumes, props, rehearsal space, etc...
