story:
Now more than ever, Chicago is a Tale of Two Cities.

The Problem:

In low-income black and brown communities on the South and West Side, school budgets are cut. Library budgets are cut. Half the city's mental health clinics are closed. Fifty public schools are closed. Thousands of good jobs are lost. Wages are low. Pensions are stolen. Affordable housing is slashed. Violence spreads. Rent rises. Homes are foreclosed, families are left out on the streets, and properties are left vacant. 

Meanwhile, the rich are getting richer. Our taxpayer money is going away from our neighborhoods and communities, and into the pockets of greedy downtown corporations. CEOs and big banks are seeing greater and greater profits. Jobs are created downtown- but not for the people who live in the neighborhoods. And our aldermen and the Mayor are letting it happen. They're listening to corporations, not communities.  

The Solution: 

But we're not going to let it happen. This summer, workers, youth, parents, teachers, students, seniors, and community members throughout Chicago are taking to the streets and demanding that our politicians put communities before corporations. We're registering voters, fighting for a $15/hour minimum wage, and demanding that our aldermen create good jobs, expand affordable housing, and fund our public schools, parks, clinics, libraries and services. We are knocking on doors, talking to our neighbors, building new independent political committees and gathering like-minded people to raise funds to support a new independent politics in Chicago. Check out the new article about Grassroots Illinois Action in The Chicago Sun-Times, 'Progressive Movement That Thrived in NYC Coming to Chicago'!

And to make sure that we can all find out who our elected officials are actually listening to, we're building a website, TakeBackChicago.org- a place where we can see how our aldermen have voted on the issues we care about, find out how much money they've gotten from corporations, and take action to demand they step up- or step down.

But we need your help. 

TakeBackChicago.org is already up and running. Now we need $10,000 to take it to the next level. These funds will make it possible to-

- Research, collect, and analyze the City Council's voting records, campaign contributions, and stances on important issues 

- Generate individual scorecards that show whether each alderman stands with communities or corporations

- Bring residents together to take action and hold our aldermen accountable


The elections are coming up next February, and politicians are scared. They closed our schools and took money and services from our neighborhoods, but our communities are strong and ready to fight back. Your contribution will help build a movement that will put Chicago back in the hands of its people. Together, we can build power and win a city that cares about healthy communities, not greedy corporations. 

Help us Take Back Chicago, one ward at a time. Make a contribution, and get great T-shirts, buttons and screen prints with our 'What Would Harold Washington Do?' Take Back Chicago design, featured below. We also have books about the 2012 Chicago Teachers Union strike and other Chicago movements, signed by their authors and by CTU President and movement leader Karen Lewis. Share this page on Facebook, Twitter and email. Tell your neighbors, get organized, register to vote, and build the movement. 


'What Would Harold Do?' Take Back Chicago screen print, featuring image of 1980s civil rights leader Mayor Harold Washington. Designed by Amisha Patel, Executive Director of Grassroots Illinois Action. Available with $30 donation. Image is also featured on Take Back Chicago buttons and T-shirts, available with $10 and $75 donations. 
Check out the articles written about Grassroots Illinois Action in the last month!

'Progressive Movement that thrived in NYC Coming to Chicago'- Chicago Sun-Times
'Chicago Teachers Union, Progressives Form Chicago Coalition'- Chicago Sun-Times
'Want to Take Back Chicago? Here's How, Say Activists'- In These Times
'Amisha Patel's Idea for Keeping Track of Aldermen'- Chicago Reader

About Grassroots Illinois Action-
Grassroots Illinois Action is building a permanent, independent grassroots electoral movement to promote a progressive agenda that values all of our city’s residents, all of our children, all of our neighborhoods. We set out to unite Chicagoans in an effort to build real independent political power in and for our communities. We work to expand the political influence of our members by supporting candidates who embrace our vision. Additionally, we support our grassroots leaders by providing them with the tools they need to win political power in their communities.
Grassroots Illinois Action is a 501(c)(4) social welfare organization. Activities performed by Grassroots Illinois Action include legislative lobbying, partisan organizing, and coordinated electoral work. Donations are not tax deductible.
story_txt:
Now more than ever, Chicago is a Tale of Two Cities.The Problem:In low-income black and brown communities on the South and West Side, school budgets are cut. Library budgets are cut. Half the city's mental health clinics are closed. Fifty public schools are closed. Thousands of good jobs are lost. Wages are low. Pensions are stolen. Affordable housing is slashed. Violence spreads. Rent rises. Homes are foreclosed, families are left out on the streets, and properties are left vacant. Meanwhile, the rich are getting richer. Our taxpayer money is going away from our neighborhoods and communities, and into the pockets of greedy downtown corporations. CEOs and big banks are seeing greater and greater profits. Jobs are created downtown- but not for the people who live in the neighborhoods. And our aldermen and the Mayor are letting it happen. They're listening to corporations, not communities.  The Solution: But we're not going to let it happen. This summer, workers, youth, parents, teachers, students, seniors, and community members throughout Chicago are taking to the streets and demanding that our politicians put communities before corporations. We're registering voters, fighting for a $15/hour minimum wage, and demanding that our aldermen create good jobs, expand affordable housing, and fund our public schools, parks, clinics, libraries and services. We are knocking on doors, talking to our neighbors, building new independent political committees and gathering like-minded people to raise funds to support a new independent politics in Chicago. Check out the new article about Grassroots Illinois Action in The Chicago Sun-Times, 'Progressive Movement That Thrived in NYC Coming to Chicago'!And to make sure that we can all find out who our elected officials are actually listening to, we're building a website, TakeBackChicago.org- a place where we can see how our aldermen have voted on the issues we care about, find out how much money they've gotten from corporations, and take action to demand they step up- or step down.But we need your help. TakeBackChicago.org is already up and running. Now we need $10,000 to take it to the next level. These funds will make it possible to-- Research, collect, and analyze the City Council's voting records, campaign contributions, and stances on important issues - Generate individual scorecards that show whether each alderman stands with communities or corporations- Bring residents together to take action and hold our aldermen accountableThe elections are coming up next February, and politicians are scared. They closed our schools and took money and services from our neighborhoods, but our communities are strong and ready to fight back. Your contribution will help build a movement that will put Chicago back in the hands of its people. Together, we can build power and win a city that cares about healthy communities, not greedy corporations. Help us Take Back Chicago, one ward at a time. Make a contribution, and get great T-shirts, buttons and screen prints with our 'What Would Harold Washington Do?' Take Back Chicago design, featured below. We also have books about the 2012 Chicago Teachers Union strike and other Chicago movements, signed by their authors and by CTU President and movement leader Karen Lewis. Share this page on Facebook, Twitter and email. Tell your neighbors, get organized, register to vote, and build the movement.

Designed by Amisha Patel, Executive Director of Grassroots Illinois Action. Available with $30 donation. Image is also featured on Take Back Chicago buttons and T-shirts, available with $10 and $75 donations. 
Check out the articles written about Grassroots Illinois Action in the last month!'Progressive Movement that thrived in NYC Coming to Chicago'- Chicago Sun-Times'Chicago Teachers Union, Progressives Form Chicago Coalition'- Chicago Sun-Times'Want to Take Back Chicago? Here's How, Say Activists'- In These Times'Amisha Patel's Idea for Keeping Track of Aldermen'- Chicago Reader

Additionally, we support our grassroots leaders by providing them with the tools they need to win political power in their communities.
Grassroots Illinois Action is a 501(c)(4) social welfare organization. Activities performed by Grassroots Illinois Action include legislative lobbying, partisan organizing, and coordinated electoral work. Donations are not tax deductible.

story:
Why HOOLIGAN?

HOOLIGAN Theatre Co. Provides many things for us UCLA theatre kids: a family, a home away from home, a place to just be ourselves; most importantly, though, it provides a theatrical, educational and inspiring environment for our audiences. UCLA students get to see each HOOLIGAN show for free, a service we proudly provide - everyone should have the opportunity to experience live theatre.

I am one of the newest members of HOOLIGAN and could not be more proud of this beautiful organization. Entirely student-run, we HOOLIGANS come together multiple times a year to put on magical shows for our audiences in record time - this time we have just 6 weeks! - but, even then, we do more. We treat each other like family, we care about one another, and we always strive to not only bring a story to life because it is fun but because it is meaningful.

Why HAIR?

Hair is set in the 1960s, the age of flower children, peaceful (and some non-peaceful) protesters, and psychedelic vibes. In this age of America, musicals on Broadway were idealized: social issues weren't brought to the stage, rock musical was still Broadway Taboo and traditionalism was the norm. Hair changed all of that - Hair began the rock musical movement, inspiring shows such as RENT, Footloose and Rock of Ages to come to the stage. Hair also discussed the real problems of the age, such as the stigmas of the young adults who were just trying to be themselves and be free and liberated and spread the love. Hair broke the ice; after Hair, America's youth started to speak.

Why does it matter now? Why is it so imperative that HOOLIGAN put on this show in 6 weeks? I'll tell you why: because the lessons Hair teaches are still relevant today. Freedom, expression, acceptance, love, and open-mindedness are still values today's teens need to learn and adopt.

Why TWO THOUSAND DOLLARS?

Well, actually, our goal is $30,000.00! Since we are entirely student-run, we rely on grants and cast fundraising to put on our shows. Grants sometimes cover about a third of our budget, but that is if we’re lucky. Basically, it’s all up to us to personally raise as much as we can!

I’m trying to rally up as much as I can, and if you can’t contribute, THAT IS OKAY! Direct this page to someone who might be able to – everything counts. We appreciate every single bit of help we get.

$30,000.00 is a lot, but if we all work together, I know we can do it. THE SHOW MUST GO ON!

THANK YOU!

Thank you so much for reading this, for watching the video, for even clicking on the link to this campaign. HOOLIGAN Theatre Company would not be in its 10th season without all of you helping us reach our goals. Because of you, we can continue to bring free theatrical experiences to thousands of UCLA students, and modest theatrical experiences for non-UCLA students. ;) Thank you for making my theatrical debut at UCLA possible!!

Much love,

Sheila Franklin (Lindsey McCumber)

story:
The 411, Dear Funder

In Fall 2012, I wrote and performed "The Memo." It was a great joy and success. And  a surprise (to all except those who voted me "Best Actor in the State of Utah" in high school -- true story!).  Such is the lot of the performer/introvert: "He seemed so quiet, kept to himself …"  

It would have gone nowhere without Martha Rynberg and the Solo Performance Workshop. Learn more here!  I've since gone back to SPW to write and perform three more pieces (see all four of them here). 

It's no longer surprising that I've had a lot to say about teaching troubles, manly trials, OKCupid exploits, PTSD, and fairy grandparenting.

So, it's Fall 2014 and I'm ready to write, produce, and perform a much longer show! 

I can't say for sure what this show will "be about."  (Details, details…)  I can say is that Martha Rynberg and SPW collaborators will again inspire and shape the work; and a piece of 40-ish minutes is 100% guaranteed to be performed in mid-November of this year. 

Gulp!

With any luck, this will also become the nervous system, backbone, skeleton, vascular system -- choose your favorite core bodily function related metaphor --  for what we call in the biz a "full-length" show. 

Yowza-gulp!

Here's what I will offer to my audiences in a temporally-expanded dose:
  • A surprising (possibly unpredictable) resonance and insight. 
  • Relief through compassionate, irreverent laughter. 
  • To be totally stopped, however briefly, in their tracks. 
  • Wonder. 
  • Delight. 
  • To be challenged as in to squirm (possibly to wince) in their seats. 
  • An expansion of social awareness and conscience.
  • An appreciation for the power of saying something just-so.

    What I Need & What You Get

    This is a big leap creatively but I feel more than ready for it. It's just the big stretch financially that's keeping me up at night. So, I'd like to raise $1,500 for:
    • Workshop fees and coaching
    • Rehearsal time and space
    • Videography of the performance(s)
    • BART to/from San Francisco
    • Chocolate
    • Coffee
    In asking for your support, I'm taking my work more seriously and developing the means to sustain it. Rest assured that whatever progress I make toward this goal, I am doing this show! 


    Also, your contribution supports the Solo Performance Workshop (again, learn more here). SPW helps people share their stories in timely and entertaining ways. It's a collaborative process that exposes audiences to powerful insights on our personal and social struggles. It's not just a class but truly a community of artists.


    Finally, there are perks! Namely, if you contribute:

    • $10 or more, I'll send you a "thank you" in the form of a signed memento from the night's performance;
    • $25 or more, you'll get the above plus a special treat at the performance;
    • $50 or more, you'll get the above plus a free ticket to the performance;
    • $100 or more, you'll get the above plus an invite to a cocktail hour hosted by yours truly; 
    • $200 or more, you'll get all of the above for two!


      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you can't contribute, help me to get the word out about this project (and my solo performance work in general)!  Please contact me (andygpeck@gmail.com), or use the indiegogo share tools.


      Thanks so much for your interest and support!

      Big Luv & Hugs,

      Andrew George

story:
Help me train in LA!

Hi! My name is Yosola-Camille.  I am 8 yrs old and I live in Massachusetts.  

First and foremost, I am a DANCER! I fell in love with dance when I was 2yrs old (and yes I remember very clearly, I went to see the Nutcracker and I got a really strong feeling--it's hard to explain but all I can remember is that it wouldn't go away).  Six months later I began dancing and I haven't been able to stop.  As I grow, dance grows inside of me.   

My biggest dream is to travel the world dancing on different stages, meeting all kinds of people, and learning all kinds of dance.  

For me, that dream is almost real.  Recently, I was invited to train in LA with dancers from all around the world.  Now, I am so thankful because I am getting closer and closer to beginning to live my dreams. With your help, this dream could easily become a reality! 

What We Need & What You Get

  • I am asking for $3,800 to cover some of the costs for tuition and travel expenses.  The Debbie Allen Dance Academy offers extensive training from 8:30am-5:30pm Monday-Friday and provides me with a host family for $4,300.  If we get extra, that money will be used for travel expenses, insurance (in case I get hurt), dance attire, and/or future training.  
  • In return for your generosity, I will send personal thank you notes, autographed pictures, a video of what I gained during my time in LA, and more! 
  • Let's say I don't reach my entire goal this year. I would be devastated but I won't give up. I will save what I have raised and use it towards future programs.  I plan on attending Alvin Ailey, DADA, The Boston Ballet School, and when I get old enough I would like to train in other countries.  

Your Contribution Makes a World of a Difference! 

  • For the past six years I have worked so hard at becoming the best dancer I can be.  I am the youngest dancer on my acro and ballet dance teams.  I love competing. And I am ready to take it to the next level! 
  • So many people say, "wow, this kid has really got something." "Or, she belongs on stage." I was invited to be a part of this program because dance makes me feel happy and complete.  I want to be able to help people through dance. I want to teach people through dance.  I realize I have a calling! But first I have to be a student.  
  • Your help will help me become better so that I can help others.  

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you are not able to contribute but would like to help, first, thank you! And please tell everyone you know about my campaign.  Spread the word as much as you can.  
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools above to get the word out on Facebook, twitter, your email, etc!!

story:
We Need Your Help

Please help donate to our foundation so we can keep exploring as artist and making our dreams come true. We have so much planned for the future but we need your help to help us get there! Any donation big or small will help. WE cant do this without you

Who We Are

Qualia Dance Theater was founded by Christina Nova Zych and myself (Tiffany Stacey). The two of us met while earning our bachlors degree at the Califorinia Institute of the Arts (CalArts). We are a relatively new company, forming steadily with purpose! As an emerging dance company in the Los Angeles area we are striving to pick our feet off the ground and get the ball rolling. Our mission is to help build a strong foundation for Calarts and the dance community in the local area, while maintaining the creation of strong, conceptial work. 

But what is this "Qualia" business you might ask?
 
Qualia is a term most widely used in philosophy. In simple terms, it is a name for the feeling of a sensory experience. When you look at the color brown, it will be a different experience versus looking at the color turquoise. When you feel something coarse, it will differ from feeling something smooth. Qualia reminds us that no two lives are experienced the exact same way, but we are here togther, as artists, pushing physical extremes and testing boundaries with our mind and bodies. 
 
 

What We Are Working On

Starting our fall season, we are developing new work titled, Phantom of Obsessions. Phantom of Obsessions explores the impulses that drive our obsessive desires. Each indivual indulges in some type of obession through their daily lives. Obessions come in many forms of rage, passion, tenderness, emptiness, power and stillness. The work will ride the wave of each impulse, creating texture, contrast and vulnerabilty. 

Performers for this new work are:

Arian Winn

Christina Nova Zych

Olivia Goldberg

Jordan Saenz

Anne-Marie Talmadge

The Impact

This new work will be an oppurtunity for us to really push ourselves in a new direction and grow as a company. We need your help to make this happen! We have a 'new works' show we are so proud to be a part of titled "New Shoes" presenting this October, with other upcoming artists, at Highways in Santa Monica. There are 5 dancers in this piece, each struggling to keep jobs that are flexible enough to move around for rehearsals and still pay the bills. All of us are putting our heart and souls into the art we create. 

You can help us continue our path as artists. Help us rent studio space for rehearsals, pay dancers for their comitment, reimburse gas, hire a videographer, a lighting designer, pay for costumes and other finances that come along the way. We are hoping to perform this work at least 3 times in the next coming months to help put our name out there and create a buzz for our new work. 

How Your Contribution Will Help

Your contribution however large or small will helping us reach our goal, your funds will support the following:

1. It will fund studio space for 3 months worth of rehearsal.

2. The design of costumes.

3. Hiring a professional Videographer to shoot & edit our performances. 

4. The lighting designer. Lighting is the most crucial part to the experience of any dance work!

5. Reimbursing for travel. Gas is expensive! Some dancers are traveling at least 40 miles to make this commitment!

6. Artist Fee, includes paying dancers for their commitment during long rehearsal hours and dedication to the next 3 performances. 

What You Will Get

  • $50   You will receive a special thank you card from all of us!
  • $100  You will receive a special thank you card + QDT company Fall Season Photograph
  • $500  You will receive a special thank you card + QDT company Fall Season Photograph + DVD of Phantom of Obsessions
  • $1,000  a very special QDT Company T-shirt + Free Ticket to our 3 fall performances+ 1 Free Private Pilates Session instructed by Tiffany Stacey + company Fall Season Photograph + DVD of New Work+ Special thank you in all programs and on our website

Other Ways You Can Help

                                                                                         

  • Attend our 1st perfromance! "New Shoes" Highways Performance Space, Santa Monica. October 5 & 6th
  • Spread the word! Forward our campaign on to your friends 
  • Like and Join our Facebook page at www.facebook.com/pages/Qualia-Dance-Theater/177...
  • Check us out at our website www.Qualiadancetheater.com

1. It will fund studio space for 3 months worth of rehearsal.
2. The design of costumes.
3. Hiring a professional Videographer to shoot & edit our performances. 
4. The lighting designer. Lighting is the most crucial part to the experience of any dance work!
5. Reimbursing for travel. Gas is expensive! Some dancers are traveling at least 40 miles to make this commitment!
6. Artist Fee, includes paying dancers for their commitment during long rehearsal hours and dedication to the next 3 performances. 
What You Will Get


$50   You will receive a special thank you card from all of us!

$100  You will receive a special thank you card + QDT company Fall Season Photograph

$500  You will receive a special thank you card + QDT company Fall Season Photograph + DVD of Phantom of Obsessions

$1,000  a very special QDT Company T-shirt + Free Ticket to our 3 fall performances+ 1 Free Private Pilates Session instructed by Tiffany Stacey + company Fall Season Photograph + DVD of New Work+ Special thank you in all programs and on our website
Other Ways You Can Help
                                                                                         



Attend our 1st perfromance! "New Shoes" Highways Performance Space, Santa Monica. October 5 & 6th

Spread the word! Forward our campaign on to your friends 

Like and Join our Facebook page at www.facebook.com/pages/Qualia-Dance-Theater/177...


Check us out at our website www.Qualiadancetheater.com

story:
THE HIVE is a visceral and darkly thrilling adaptation of Euripides’ Greek tragedy Trojan Women set within a beehive in the midst of colony collapse disorder.  In our production, Hecuba (protagonist of Trojan Women) is the Queen Bee with a buzzing Greek chorus!  We will use multiple medias to tell our story including dance, aerial, and video. 

The hive set is a beehive jungle gym created from metal and wood designed by architect Dimitri Chatzipetros.  It is a collection of interconnected hexagonal cells each of which will be large enough to house an individual. The set fills the entire stage at Galapagos Art Space! (www.galapagosartspace.com)

WHAT IS C.C.D.? C.C.D., sometimes known as honey bee depopulation syndrome (HBDS), is a phenomenon in which worker bees from a beehive abruptly disappear.  Colony collapse is economically significant because many agricultural crops worldwide are pollinated by bees.  It is estimated that one third of the human food supply depends on insect pollination, most of which is accomplished by bees.  In other words, if the bees disappear, eventually we will too.

The goal is to look at colony collapse disorder through the lens of war and the fall of great societies.  It is our hope that this production will not only entertain, but will also raise awareness regarding CCD.  We want to encourage a vision of our world that is interconnected and inter-specied.

We need help to make THE HIVE happen. When you help us, you also support local beekeeping! Contributors of $100.00 or more will recieve local organic honey products from http://www.sunbeamcandles.com/ and http://www.weilfarms.com/

ABOUT KATE VALENTINE: As a director, I have come to specialize in collaborating with performers on developing their original works. These artists include Whitney Biennial performance artist Julie Atlas Muz, Ed Hamell (winning the Herald Angel Award at the Edinburgh Festival 2007), and the World Famous *Bob* among others. My first effort as a feature filmmaker, Rant and Roll, was completed in spring 2008. As performer, I am best known for character-based comedy performances in the downtown NY scene, particularly the louche Austrian Mistress of Ceremonies character Miss Astrid.  As a producer, I am the creator of the seminal burlesque show The Va Va Voom Room (1997-2005). Besides having the first bicoastal burlesque show ever (running weekly in NYC and San Francisco), Miss Astrid and The Va Va Voom Room have performed all over Europe and the U.S. including the annual productions of The New York Burlesque Festival and The Burlesque Hall of Fame in Las Vegas.

THE HIVE is an expansion of my goals as an artist.  I am excited to have received funding this year from the Brooklyn Arts Council to take my work in new and deeper directions. However, the funding has only gotten us 1/6 of what we need to present. 

You can find clips of THE HIVE (regularly updated) and other work on my vimeo site:www.vimeo.com/katevalentine and blogspot www.thehiveplay.blogspot.com

 

HOW WILL WE SPEND THE MONEY? Now we need the funds to finance the rest of our production. 

PRE-PRODUCTION (aerial consultant/rigger/videographer/rehearsal space/fees/set designer:  $3200

SET (materials/transport/build/storage): $3500

PUBLICITY (advertisement materials/programs): $1000

PRODUCTION (cast/tech crew/costumes/props/performance space): $4400

SUBTOTAL:  $12,100
less B.A.C. Grant: $2,100.00

TOTAL SOUGHT: $10,000.00

PRODUCTION DATE: October 24 & 25, Galapagos *Brooklyn, NYC

If we do not meet our financial goal, we will still present our show in a scaled down production.  If we gain more money, that’s more pay for our wonderful team of performers!  Our particpants include:

Dimitri Chatzipetros (set design), Taro Baugham (sound), David Quinn (costumes/sets), Matthew Mohr (additional choreography) Lianne Arnold (video) and performers Kate Valentine, Autum Kioti, Peekaboo Pointe, Robert C. Shryock, Francis Stallings and Ted Caine.

CAN I HELP/PARTICIPATE IN OTHER WAYS?

YES! We will be offering a free matinee performance for students under 21.  If you would like your kids or your class to see THE HIVE for free please let us know!  (Recommended for 14 and up) Would like to volunteer to be a worker bee at THE HIVE?  We would happily take your assistance!

story:
The Revelation of June Paul is a live storytelling event. Stories have power to show us who we are and to remind us what matters most in life. The power of this story will be leveraged to combat slavery, as 100% of the proceeds from each performance will be given to fight human trafficking (see below).

Performances:

January 6: River Valley Church, Mishawaka, IN

January 16: The Community, Ada, MI tickets

January 20: Dawn Theater, Hillsdale, MI tickets

January 25: Jackson Symphony Orchestra, Jackson, MI tickets

January 27: The People's Church, East Lansing, MI tickets

January 29: The Ark, Ann Arbor, MI tickets

All performances are at 6:30 p.m. Visit TheRevelationOfJunePaul.com for more information, including production blogs and media.

Your contributions will cover:

  • Props and set design
  • Film production and duplication
  • Original artwork, writing, and editing
  • Venue rental
  • Printing and distribution costs
  • Advertising

We believe God's future plans will heal the world, and part of that healing includes freedom for those sold into slavery. Proceeds will be donated to:

  • Children's Hope Chest, a national organization that partners primarily with churches, businesses and Christian communities to provide help, training, and discipleship to orphans across the globe.
  • Sari Bari, which offers women exploited in the sex trade in India alternative employment and healing.
  • Michigan Human Trafficking Task Force, which works to facilitate a collaborative effort between law enforcement and social service agencies to prevent human trafficking in Michigan.
  • Southern Michigan Regional Human Rights Task Force, a regional branch of Michigan Human Trafficking Task Force, based in the Hillsdale area. 
  • Michigan Human Trafficking Clinic, a clinical law program at the University of Michigan, which provides legal services to victims of human trafficking.
  • The Manasseh Project, which provides support for victims of human trafficking through community education and collaboration in West Michigan.

CORPORATE SPONSORSHIP

For corporate sponsorship options, please contact Amy Gafkjen (amy.gafkjen@westwinds.org). 

We hope you choose to support The Revelation of June Paul. This powerful story will make a difference in the lives of hurting people forever.

 

STORY SYNOPSIS

Three men have the power to save the world or pull the pin on a planetary grenade.

Three timelines pit the supernatural against the technological, the past against the future, and blind faith against critical engagement.

Their contest centers on a man with no name who wakes in a hospital without his memories. He is sickened by the hypocrisy of our shallow, bigoted, and falsely sweet earth and begins a crusade to return the world to its senses. But some prefer the fraud, and this charming revolutionary hero must expose the forces of falsehood in order for humanity to be liberated from ignorance.

One wants to remake the world, one wants to heal it, and one wants to set it free. What will happen when everything must change or be destroyed?

 

A production of Westwinds Community Church.

story:
MISSION


Lively Productions is committed to presenting new works of emerging theater artists on stage, while actively seeking creative opportunities in a world increasingly defined by real time interactions and new technologies. Through the development of new work, the initiation of projects based on current events and trends, and the exploring of new media, we are expanding the possibilities of what defines performance today, without disregarding the value of more traditional theater.

NEXT UP

Alli and Jen submitted a proposal which has progressed past the initial stage of review for a MAP grant; this support would allow them to travel the country crafting a theater piece around the concept of "Emerging Adulthood".  Past recipients of this grant include Merce Cunningham, Yale Repertory Theater, Mabou Mines, Nuyorican Poets' Cafe and the Wooster Group. 
 
PROJECTS

Our most recent works include Diplomatic Relations, a comedy by Greg Edwards, that ran in the Strawberry One-Act Festival in August, and a developmental reading of the new musical, The Rivals, by Greg Edwards and Jonathan Breit.  These shows were well received, and Alli and Jen teamed up once again with Greg Edwards for a larger theater project that will begin to take shape in late winter/early spring -- with your help.

Additionally, Alli and Jen maintain a vlog, Why Are You On My Train? where they interview strangers on the NYC subway weekly.  They’ve already received coverage in The New York Times and NY1, among others.  With additional funding, they are hoping to expand this project into a citywide “happening” that will encourage generosity of spirit underground. 

OUR STORY

Lively Productions was founded by Lisa Siciliano and Allison in December of 2007. We're at a critical moment in the growth of our theater company, now under the artistic direction of Allison and Jen Jamula. We're embarking on new projects, refining our artistic mission, and filing our 501(c)(3) application.

With a small nest egg for our company, we know that we can accomplish miracles and see many of our dreams through.  Thank you for your support, and we promise to keep you updated every step of the way.


YOUR DONATIONS

Cost of an average, mid-sized rehearsal studio in Manhattan: $35
x 3 nights/week for 3 hours for 4 weeks: $1,260
One weekend of 4 shows in a 45 seat theater downtown: $1000
Volunteer Accident Insurance for one year: $600
*needed to rent theater
Props for one low budget show? $300

Copies of full length script for 10 actors = $100

501(c)(3) filing: $400
Other expenses: programs, marketing, sets/costumers... paying the actors?


THANK YOU


Michael Rehfield for the production of this video and to him and his wife Kori Rehfield for allowing us into their home to abuse their daughter, Chloe Rehfield. (Thank you, Chloe!) To our co-founder, Lisa Siciliano and her web-designer man, Charles Riffenburg. To our legal counsel, Minda and Stephen . To our fiscal sponsor, Artistic New Directions. To our lovely and talented writers and performers, especially those featured in the video: Jonathan Breit, Greg Edwards (resident playwright), Amanda Dieli, Ethan Heard, David Hilder, Eric Johnson, Aaron Lambert, Sue Mathys, Julia Meinwald, Megan Stern, Chris Stetson.


And a special thanks to all of you for your kindly donations.

story:
OUR STORY

(re)discover theatre is a Chicago based company that was formed at 2:00am on a January night with nothing but the realization that many artists spend their most foolhardy, energetic years observing, dreaming and waiting, and in that time waste great potential and opportunity. After spending all night rehearsing Shakespeare’s longest play in a freezing rehearsal room (that we were technically squatting in) we realized there was nowhere else we wanted to be and that we were done waiting.

Since that fateful January night we have stopped squatting, producing 3 full length shows, a fringe show, and a massive theatrically immersive event. We might be a little insane, but we’re so proud to have featured the work of over 50 phenomenal young artists taking risks like sword fighting two inches from the audience’s faces, ushering them through interactive checkpoints and rocking out to live music in church halls, theatres, backyards and basements. Our next production is a new play based on the Medea myth, written by ensemble member Jessica Shoemaker and directed by ensemble member Janet Howe. Jason and Medea isn’t your grandmother's formal greek tragedy.  Jessica and Janet are ripping the myth apart to explore things like sex, gender, love and power through a modern and timeless  context. Our risk this time?  We are going to do Jason and (Medea) for free. We are totally and completely depending on you to make this show happen. Because to be honest, despite our best efforts, we weren’t making any money on ticket sales anyway.  You tell us what you think this project is worth, and give accordingly.  Simple as that. 

THE IMPACT

You don’t need to have a Ph.D in economics to know that times are hard for everyone.  Seeing theatre is a luxury many can’t afford, and theatres are struggling too. We wanna see what happens when we flip that model, we want to explore new ways to share the art we love, the art we think is important, with as many people as possible.  

WHAT WE NEED AND WHAT YOU GET

To produce this play we need $7,000. Your contribution will be funneled directly into virtually every aspect of this production. Costumes, props, live music, marketing materials, lights, and compensating our team of artists.  We want to use your money to make the art happen! We have 588 fans on facebook.  If every one of those people donated $15 we would exceed our goal.  So whatever you can do, please DO! We have a variety of fantastic perks on our campaign page.  Check them out!

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

If you can’t give us money right now, we get it. Like us on facebook, follow us on twitter, and share this campaign on YOUR facebook page.  Or just send us an email at info@rediscovertheatre.com with your karmic support.  We dig your kind words and thoughtful vibes. Thank you for your time, your love, and your support. 

 

We are totally excited to (re)discover with you. 

 

**Please note that we have applied for Non-Profit status, and if you donate with a credit card to our campaign your donation will not be tax deductible once our status comes through.

story:
Lenora Lee Dance is fiscally sponsored by Asian Pacific Islander Cultural Center, a non-profit tax-exempt organization. All donations to Lenora Lee Dance are fully deductible to the extent allowed by law.

DEAR FRIENDS,

We are in the process of creating a new interdisciplinary performance piece "Rescued Memories: New York Stories" which will premiere along with its companion piece "The Escape" November 8 & 9 at the de Young Museum in San Francisco and in the Spring of 2014 in New York City. It is inspired by stories of women who sought refuge from human trafficking in the early 20th Century in New York City's Chinatown, shedding light on the experiences of women in the context of the struggles and achievements of the 20th Century Women’s Movement. The project will connect these experiences with today’s fabric of organizations listed below & individuals that are on the front line of the contemporary struggle against the exploitation of women in our communities. 

YOU CAN BE PART OF THE TEAM!

As part of this project, we will be flying 12 dancers, collaborating artists, and crew to New York City this July to take part in a week of film shoots in key historic locations within Manhattan Chinatown and to record music for the sound score of the piece. The site-specific video mapped and projected on various surfaces during the premiere performances plays a crucial part in the sharing of these stories.

WE ARE TRYING TO RAISE $8,000 IN 30 DAYS AND WE NEED YOUR HELP! 

I am here to ask for your support in creating these projects as our scale and scope become larger and more integrated into various communities and major venues throughout the country. 

WE ARE IN CRITICAL NEED OF FUNDING to create this new interdisciplinary work in which dance, martial arts, multi-screen video projection, text & music collide in a visual and aural landscape, a meditation on women being propelled into the unknown by courage and faith to risk their lives and everything they have for freedom.

WHY AM I DOING THIS?

My hope is to share these stories in innovative ways providing insight into the experiences, challenges, and triumphs of the people in the various Chinese American communities over the years. What inherently has come with this process is the research and education and ultimately sharing with the audiences the issues of human trafficking and repercussions of the 1882 Chinese Exclusion Act. 

For both pieces I have done research and interviews at Donaldina Cameron House, Asian Women’s Shelter, Asian Pacific Islander Legal Outreach, Chinese Historical Society of America Museum, New York Asian Women’s Center, Asian/Pacific/American Institute at New York University, and Museum of Chinese in America.

I would like the stories to act as a catalyst for dialogue and sparking interest in understanding the deeper issues and providing a voice for those who could not share the challenges of their experiences. These stories can also serve as an avenue to rejoice in the courage, strength and resilience of the Chinese and Chinese Americans who built vibrant communities throughout the United States and pushed forth tremendous contributions to American Society.

WHAT WE NEED

WE ARE TRYING TO RAISE $8,000 IN 30 DAYS 

I have been able to raise a portion of the money needed through individual donations, grants and sponsorships and have been working day in and day out to develop and plan this new project. We have hit a critical point and I am reaching out to you and the community for support.

The minimum we are trying to raise is $8,000 in 30 days to support the development of Phase 2 in New York City this July. This is cutting some corners, but will allow us to:

-       Pay for roundtrip airfare for 12 collaborating artists to fly to New York City for a week of film shoots in key historic locations and to do the music recording for the piece

-       Cover some of the artist fees for the dancers, musicians, filmmaker and cinematographers

If we exceed the goal and make our way to the $15,000 needed for Phase 2 of the project, you will be helping to:

-       Cover the costs the music recording engineer and recording space

-       Pay for the lighting and camera equipment rental

-       Cover the costs of renting a van to transport all the equipment and crew everyday

-       Pay for the remaining artist fees for the 12 collaborating artists

-       Cover the costs of a photographer and rehearsal space rental

ADDITIONAL WAYS TO SUPPORT

-       If your company has a Matching Gifts Program, your donation can go twice as far.  Please contact me at Lenora@asianimprov.org to inquire about the details

-       If you have airline miles you can donate, we would greatly appreciate the contribution!!  Please email Lenora@asianimprov.org

-       YOU CAN HELP SPREAD THE WORD TO YOUR FRIENDS, COLLEGUES, AND NETWORKS ABOUT THIS PROJECT AND OUR REQUEST FOR SUPPORT! 

Audiences have been deeply touched by "The Escape". We hope to bring forth more compelling stories and perspectives to you through "Rescued Memories: New York Stories". 

When you contribute at any of the following levels, you will receive special perks and gifts!! 

We are greatly appreciative of your generosity and for being part of the team. Please help spread the word.

In gratitude,

Lenora

Photos in the video are by Lei Chen, Robbie Sweeny, and courtesy of Cameron House

www.LenoraLeeDance.com
story_txt:
Lenora Lee Dance is fiscally sponsored by Asian Pacific Islander Cultural Center, a non-profit tax-exempt organization. All donations to Lenora Lee Dance are fully deductible to the extent allowed by law.
DEAR FRIENDS,
We are in the process of creating a new interdisciplinary performance piece "Rescued Memories: New York Stories" which will premiere along with its companion piece "The Escape" November 8 & 9 at the de Young Museum in San Francisco and in the Spring of 2014 in New York City. It is inspired by stories of women who sought refuge from human trafficking in the early 20th Century in New York City's Chinatown, shedding light on the experiences of women in the context of the struggles and achievements of the 20th Century Women’s Movement. The project will connect these experiences with today’s fabric of organizations listed below & individuals that are on the front line of the contemporary struggle against the exploitation of women in our communities. 
YOU CAN BE PART OF THE TEAM!
As part of this project, we will be flying 12 dancers, collaborating artists, and crew to New York City this July to take part in a week of film shoots in key historic locations within Manhattan Chinatown and to record music for the sound score of the piece. The site-specific video mapped and projected on various surfaces during the premiere performances plays a crucial part in the sharing of these stories.
WE ARE TRYING TO RAISE $8,000 IN 30 DAYS AND WE NEED YOUR HELP! 
I am here to ask for your support in creating these projects as our scale and scope become larger and more integrated into various communities and major venues throughout the country. 
WE ARE IN CRITICAL NEED OF FUNDING to create this new interdisciplinary work in which dance, martial arts, multi-screen video projection, text & music collide in a visual and aural landscape, a meditation on women being propelled into the unknown by courage and faith to risk their lives and everything they have for freedom.


WHY AM I DOING THIS?
My hope is to share these stories in innovative ways providing insight into the experiences, challenges, and triumphs of the people in the various Chinese American communities over the years. What inherently has come with this process is the research and education and ultimately sharing with the audiences the issues of human trafficking and repercussions of the 1882 Chinese Exclusion Act. 
For both pieces I have done research and interviews at Donaldina Cameron House, Asian Women’s Shelter, Asian Pacific Islander Legal Outreach, Chinese Historical Society of America Museum, New York Asian Women’s Center, Asian/Pacific/American Institute at New York University, and Museum of Chinese in America.
I would like the stories to act as a catalyst for dialogue and sparking interest in understanding the deeper issues and providing a voice for those who could not share the challenges of their experiences. These stories can also serve as an avenue to rejoice in the courage, strength and resilience of the Chinese and Chinese Americans who built vibrant communities throughout the United States and pushed forth tremendous contributions to American Society.


WHAT WE NEED
WE ARE TRYING TO RAISE $8,000 IN 30 DAYS 
I have been able to raise a portion of the money needed through individual donations, grants and sponsorships and have been working day in and day out to develop and plan this new project. We have hit a critical point and I am reaching out to you and the community for support.
The minimum we are trying to raise is $8,000 in 30 days to support the development of Phase 2 in New York City this July. This is cutting some corners, but will allow us to:
-       Pay for roundtrip airfare for 12 collaborating artists to fly to New York City for a week of film shoots in key historic locations and to do the music recording for the piece
-       Cover some of the artist fees for the dancers, musicians, filmmaker and cinematographers
If we exceed the goal and make our way to the $15,000 needed for Phase 2 of the project, you will be helping to:
-       Cover the costs the music recording engineer and recording space
-       Pay for the lighting and camera equipment rental
-       Cover the costs of renting a van to transport all the equipment and crew everyday
-       Pay for the remaining artist fees for the 12 collaborating artists
-       Cover the costs of a photographer and rehearsal space rental


ADDITIONAL WAYS TO SUPPORT
-       If your company has a Matching Gifts Program, your donation can go twice as far.  Please contact me at Lenora@asianimprov.org to inquire about the details
-       If you have airline miles you can donate, we would greatly appreciate the contribution!!  Please email Lenora@asianimprov.org
-       YOU CAN HELP SPREAD THE WORD TO YOUR FRIENDS, COLLEGUES, AND NETWORKS ABOUT THIS PROJECT AND OUR REQUEST FOR SUPPORT! 
Audiences have been deeply touched by "The Escape". We hope to bring forth more compelling stories and perspectives to you through "Rescued Memories: New York Stories". 
When you contribute at any of the following levels, you will receive special perks and gifts!! 
We are greatly appreciative of your generosity and for being part of the team. Please help spread the word.
In gratitude,
Lenora
Photos in the video are by Lei Chen, Robbie Sweeny, and courtesy of Cameron House

story:
Après la pièce documentaire Grains de sable présentée à Espace Libre en mars dernier, Milena Buziak investi l’univers poétique de La femme corbeau de l’auteur belge Marcel Cremer. C’est la première fois qu’un de ses textes est porté à la scène au Canada.

3 au 14 décembre 2013

Salle intime du théâtre Prospero

Mardi, jeudi et vendredi à 20h15 | Mercredi à 19h15 | Samedi à 16h15


Une fille raconte la vie de la mère qu’elle n’a pas connue.

Son héritage : un étrange oiseau, à la fois cadeau et fardeau, qui devient son compagnon.

Sur scène, la comédienne Valérie Dumas accompagnée en direct par la musicienne Diane Labrosse. Dans un décor en noir et blanc conçu par Julie Vallée-Léger, les gestes posés deviennent irréversibles. Métaphore d’une société dite civilisée, de la marginalité et de l’exclusion, ce texte traduit une profonde quête de liberté.

Aidez-nous à habiller la scène!

Notre décor fait d’une grande feuille de papier est éphémère. Après chaque représentation, nous devons « refaire » le décor. Nous réutilisons le papier, peint par la comédienne, pour en faire d’autres œuvres d’art (affiches, bijoux, etc). Ce qui n’est pas réutilisable artistiquement est recyclé. 

Aidez-nous à habiller la scène ! Chaque représentation nous coûte 60$ en papier… et il y en a 10 !

À votre droite, vous voyez les possibilités de nous aider.

En vous associant à ce projet, vous démontrez votre soutien à la relève artistique et à la diversité culturelle montréalaise.

« Les oiseaux en cage chantent la liberté. Les oiseaux libres volent. »

LA FEMME CORBEAU

Texte Marcel Cremer | Traduction Pierre Doome | Mise en scène Milena Buziak | Interprétation Valérie Dumas et Diane Labrosse | Son Diane Labrosse | Scénographie et costumes Julie Vallée-Léger | Éclairages David Perreault-Ninacs | Illustration de l’affiche Lavinia Manea | Relations de presse Marie Marais

FAQ

J’AI ENVIE DE DONNER 38 DOLLARS, MAIS CE MONTANT N’EST PAS AFFICHÉ. EST-CE QUE JE PEUX DONNER QUAND MÊME?

OUI!

Si les montants affichés ne vous conviennent pas, vous pouvez donner à votre discrétion. (Dans ce cas, notre contre partie reste aussi à notre discrétion!)


J’AI ENVIE D’AIDER, MAIS JE N’AI PAS DE SOUS… QUE FAIRE???

Pas de problème!

Même si vous ne pouvez pas contribuer financièrement, nous vous invitons à passer le mot, à partager cette campagne sur les réseaux sociaux, à nous donner vos commentaires, à venir voir le spectacle et à prendre un verre avec nous après!

Toute forme d’aide et de partage est très appréciée.


J’AI ENVIE DE MIEUX VOUS CONNAÎTRE!

Voyageurs Immobiles est une compagnie de création qui regroupe des artistes de diverses cultures autour de projets théâtraux contemporains. La femme corbeau est le quatrième projet de cette compagnie cofondée en 2009 par Milena Buziak, jeune metteure en scène issue de la communauté polonaise.

www.voyageursimmobiles.ca

Vous pouvez aussi aimer notre page Facebook, nous suivre sur Twitter ou nous écrire!

story:
SAVE THE MOOSE!

Hudson NY Moose Lodge 1184 is a fraternal organization dedicated to community service.

In June, the Building Inspector closed our lodge due to many building code and fire code violations by the landlord.

With our lodge closed during the important summer months, we have been unable to host the many community events that we usually do, including our softball tournaments, our community senior BBQs, and other fund raising events.  These funds we normally raise during the summer go towards providing holiday meals for needy families at Thanksgiving, a Christmas party for underprivileged children, as well as the day to day expenses of operating our lodge and many other community service projects.

The landlord has almost completed the necessary repairs to bring the building into compliance with the codes, and we are getting ready to reopen the lodge.  But after 4 months with no income at all, our bills have piled up and our bank account has been depleted.  We are in desperate need of funds to catch up with our utility bills and to order food and beverage items to get the kitchen and social quarters ready to reopen so we can continue to generate revenue for our community projects.

https://www.facebook.com/groups/183507245079240/members/

What We Need & What You Get

Justin Weaver, AKA Girlgantua, has graciously organized GIRLGANTUA'S DRAG RACE.

GIRLGANTUA'S DRAG RACE is a one lap race around Hudson's 7th St Park... in heels!  Straight, gay, queens, kings, all welcome!  Wear some drag attire and heels and race with us!  Performances in the park, a falafel ball eating contest all culminating in the most anticipated race in Hudson history!  Proceeds go to the Hudson Moose Lodge renovation and reopening and to Hudson Pride Foundation.  $25 gets you in the race and it also allows you or your business to sponsor a runner!

 

Even if you cannot enter the race or sponsor a runner, any contribution you make can help.  Every dollar counts!  Any proceeds above the amount needed by the Moose Lodge to reopen will go to the Hudson Pride Foundation.  http://www.hudsonpridefoundation.org/

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to participate or support us financially, won't you please share this on your Facebook wall and help spread the word?

story:
Our Story

We are a group of New Mexican playwrights. Our group is made up of national award winners, students & artists of color. 

We are planning to go to the 2012 NOPE Conference in Tempe, Arizona.

"The theme for the 2012 conference is “Re:Connecting -- Translocalities in Performance,” where we consider how the movements of peoples and ideas, metaphorically and literally in border-crossings of many kinds, have worked to shape the contemporary moment for theatre makers, producers, and audiences."

We'd love for New Mexico to have a voice in this discussion. We need your help getting there!

The Impact

This conference is very important right now. In a recent interview Rudolfo Anaya said "Arizona doesn’t exist in a vacuum, Anaya says, and we have to be concerned about close-mindedness cropping up within our state lines, too. “Quite frankly, they’re bigots, and they exist everywhere,” he says. “We have to be vigilant, and we always have to fight against censorship, any kind of censorship.”---http://alibi.com/news/40600/Fired-Up.html

The 2012 NOPE Conference is held annually by the NoPassport playwrighting network. The group was founded by  Caridad Svich and it continues to be a powerful voice for American playwrights, especially minority writers. With your help, a delegation of New Mexican playwrights will be able to attend the conference. We'll be able to make professional connections and share our ideas about the state of theatre and play writing.  

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $1500. This money will be spent on conference fees, gas to caravan to Tempe, and it will pay for our lodging for the weekend of the conference. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Anything that you can donate would be greatly appreciated. If you can't donate as much as you wish, please help spread the word about our fundraiser. It would be ever so helpful.

story:
We need your help to make the New York premiere of LADY HAN a reality! This ambitious project includes the work of sixteen independent and talented collaborators, who are devoting their time and energy to the first full-scale Katherine Brook / TELE-VIOLET production.

What you'll be supporting when you give ...

The Show:
Lady Han is a distinctly American take on a classic Noh drama about a prostitue who goes mad with lonliness. In a time of manic, maximalist, fast and furious entertainment, we are venturing down an alternate path to use the theatre as a place of contemplation and focus, attempting to slow down our minds and explore the beauty and sadness in contemporary American popular culture.

The Artists:
The Lady Han creative team includes Katherine Brook (director), Taylor Brook
(composer), Hannah Johnson-Walsh (stage-manager), Katie Rose McLaughlin
(choreograoher), Tom O'Neil (assistant director) Ryan Park (costume designer), Josh
Smith (scenic designer), Ken Wills (lighting designer). The cast: Louisa Bradshaw,
Andrew Dinwiddie, Ethan Fishbane, David Gould, Brighid Greene, Lena Moy-Borgen,
Nicolas Norena, and Jessie Shelton.

The Company:
With a wink to Tennessee Williams’s diva Violet Venable from Suddenly, Last
Summer, TELE-VIOLET is a theatre company led by director Katherine Brook that
uses dramatic texts as well as found content to experiment with acting and
dramatic form. Upcoming pieces include Lady Han (Incubator Arts, New York,
February 2013) and Transcripts, an ongoing audio-archive-scripting project in
collaboration with playwright Liza Birkenmeier (American Realism, Pittsburgh, New
York, Los Angeles, 2011–12 and All My Sons, 2013).

story:
Our Story

Step It Up LLC was established by professional dancers and actors, who understand the difficulties of the entertainment industry. They were inspired to use the wisdom that they have gained over the years and are now happy to be able to pass it on to those lucky students that get this "once in a lifetime" opportunity. The SIU Directors all traveled from around the world to LA and have made their mark in the entertainment capital of the world. These entrepreneurs and mentors saw a void in programs that didn’t educate the important business end of the industry. So they sought out ways to integrate talent cultivation and self marketing for artists to have more control of their own success. With their diverse experience and talent, SIU teaches the cutting edge dance techniques, styles and professional skills to help you start and sustain a career!

The Impact

When we moved to the Entertainment Capital of the world, all we had was a dream and our passion to work in the entertainment industry. We had no family in Los Angeles and only knew a couple of people and often at times felt like a small fish in a big pond.  We all took different paths and worked our way up in the fitness, dance and film/television industry. Although we took different paths it was inevitable that 3 hard working diverse women would end up meeting each other with a common purpose to mentor.  As a testimony of our hardships we know there is a need for a program like STEP IT UP!

What We Need & What You Get

When you donate your money, it is going towards sponsoring students to attend our workshop, which with help them reach goals and to not only dream.. but to LIVE their dreams.  Each student will receive the following:

The Step It Up Experience:

  • Understanding Entertainment Business/Industry

  • Dance Choreography Workshop

  • Commercial/Acting Workshop

  • Fitness/Nutrition

  • Agent Meetings

The Step It Up Self Marketing Package:

  • Professional Headshots

  • Personalized Resume

  • Customized Reel

  • Exhibit Video

  • SIU Contact Booklet of our Network Agents, Managers, & Casting Directors

All of the things listed above are necessary tools to becoming successful in the entertainment industry.  And through your contributions we will be able to accept students who can't afford the program.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help in any way you can, by spreading the word of our cause by tweeting, mass emailing, facebook, and any other forms of contact and ways of influencing people to contribute to this great mentorship program.  Any donations and help is truly appreciated!  Also, feel free to contact us directly about any collaborative efforts, questions, and comments regarding Step It Up LLC.  Thank you for your love and support in helping others' attaining their dream.  We appreciate you! :)

story:
Hi, I'm Madeleine Reber.

I am a Chicago-based choreographer and dance educator. I have been performing, choreographing, and teaching for over 15 years in Massachusetts, North Carolina, and now Chicago. This year I formed Salty Lark Dance, a company committed to socially relevant, artistically compelling dance theater.

WHO WE ARE:

Salty Lark Dance is a Chicago-based company established in 2012, performing original work by Artistic Director, Madeleine Reber. We draw from contemporary dance and dance theater traditions of lush physicality and the drama of the stage. Our work is motivated by a drive to embody internal questions and to respond to the world around us. Choreography serves as a medium through which to explore ideas (intellectual, physical, emotional), a place where contradictions may exist in unresolved complexity. Employing distinct movement vocabularies and dramatic imagery, Salty Lark Dance evokes the vulnerability and fallibility of human experience.

ABOUT THE SHOW:

Our production at the Minnesota Fringe Festival will include two works: Collisions and Souvenirs and Lighthouse.

Collisions and Souvenirs was originally created through a 2012 DanceBridge grant from the Chicago Department of Cultural Affairs and Special Events. This work explores awkwardness and distortion with an interest in how these movement qualities fill expressive gaps left by strict social ideals of body presentation and appearance. Performers seem at times caught in their own inner dialogues, their struggles manifesting in urgent, idiosyncratic gestures. At other moments they seek connection through aggressive collisions and tender invitations. Collisions and Souvenirs explores metaphorical and literal manifestations of the awkward, vulnerable, imperfect moments of our humanness.

Lighthouse, which I choreographed in 2009, deals with the juxtaposition of chaos and quiet (or storm and calm) – the tensions between voyaging and finding home, places of safety, places to which we return or look for familiar ground. Light, music and movement, together evoke a strangely familiar journey in a dream-like world. Thematically, this piece contemplates the comforts we seek in order to traverse difficult terrain, and examines what sustains us individually and collectively. The creation of this work is, in part, a personal response to habits of disconnection and aggressiveness that I perceive in our culture. How does larger social disconnection manifest in oneself, in community, even in political policy?

HOW YOU CAN SUPPORT SALTY LARK DANCE:

1. Contribute to our campaign and receive a great perk!

2. Come to our Chicago fundraiser: “A Night of Salty Larks: Comedy, Music, Magic, and More” at the Horseshoe Bar, 4115 N. Lincoln Ave., Chicago, IL.

Monday, June 11th, 7pm-Midmight.

3. Low on funds? Please share this campaign with other folks in any way you can: through facebook, email, casual conversation, dancing, shouting, singing...

HERE IS WHERE THE MONEY GOES:

Dancer fees: $750.00

Travel: $450.00

Studio Rental: $100.00

Minnesota Fringe Festival Registration: $450.00

Marketing: $125.00

Props/set: $100.00

Costumes: $250.00

TOTAL =   $2,225.00

* ANY ADDITIONAL MONEY WILL GO TOWARD FOOD AND HOUSING IN MINNEAPOLIS! THANK YOU!

IMPACT:

Your contribution will support the growth of a contemporary dance company, committed to meaningful art-making that is socially relevant and aesthetically compelling. Salty Lark Dance is in its beginning stages. This tour is an important next step toward increased visibility. The festival is an opportunity to share our work with new audiences and to connect with artists from across the country.

Minnesota Fringe Festival is one of the biggest fringe festivals in North America, producing theater and dance from around the world. This wonderful opportunity brings with it increased costs, and as a growing dance company, we do not have financial backers to support travel, production, promotion, or payment of dancers. Ticket sales at the festival will cover a portion of our expenses; we are fundraising to cover the rest! Any amount we make over our goal will go toward food and housing expenses in Minnesota! THANK YOU!

SALTY LARK DANCE UPCOMING PERFORMANCES:

Salty Lark Dance will perform in Going Dutch (a showcase of women artists) at Links Hall Chicago, June 28th-30th.  Next, we head to the Minnesota Fringe Festival in Minneapolis, August 2nd-12th.
story_txt:
Hi, I'm Madeleine Reber.
I am a Chicago-based choreographer and dance educator. I have been performing, choreographing, and teaching for over 15 years in Massachusetts, North Carolina, and now Chicago. This year I formed Salty Lark Dance, a company committed to socially relevant, artistically compelling dance theater.
WHO WE ARE:
Salty Lark Dance is a Chicago-based company established in 2012, performing original work by Artistic Director, Madeleine Reber. We draw from contemporary dance and dance theater traditions of lush physicality and the drama of the stage. Our work is motivated by a drive to embody internal questions and to respond to the world around us. Choreography serves as a medium through which to explore ideas (intellectual, physical, emotional), a place where contradictions may exist in unresolved complexity. Employing distinct movement vocabularies and dramatic imagery, Salty Lark Dance evokes the vulnerability and fallibility of human experience.

At other moments they seek connection through aggressive collisions and tender invitations. story:
Short Summary

My name is David Herrera and I am the artistic director of David Herrera Performance Company in San Francisco.  Our company is at the forefront of emerging dance/theater companies shaping the SF/Bay Area artistic landscape.  DHPCo is currently marking its 5th season through the creation of our newest work "Slumber". Slumber is a marriage of modern dance and theater which digs deep into cultural perspectives on Death and Living.  Inspired by Dia de los Muertos celebrations and the Greek Orpheus myth, Slumber is a transcendent journey in which Death and Life meet and interact.

 

I have gathered a phenomenal team of artist and collaborators for this unique program: 1 Theatrical director, 7 dancers, 1 actress, 5 designers, and myself as choreographer/artistic director.  For the past 8 months these artists have been working hard and efficiently to bring to life a concept larger than any one of us, a concept that both challenges us and hopefully leaves an imprint on our audience.  At the moment our funds only afford us rehearsal space and down payment on our theater rental; thus we still need financial assistance to give our artists a fair living wage. We are requesting your assistance to help us bring  "Slumber" to fruition.  

 

To make a dance theater production takes hundreds of hours of manpower: training, rehearsing, taking classes, building sets, composing an original musical score, technical and electrical work, constructing costumes; in short, physical and intellectual labor which shouldn't go unacknowledged or unpaid. Your help will directly support a member of our team in the creation of this project.  Each perk you see to your right is named in honor of each of our performers and our theatrical director. 

     

To learn more about each of the artist and the company we urge you to visit our homepage at www.dhperformance.org


 

What We Need & What You Get

We would like your help in raising $4,000 which will directly assist in paying each of our performers and collaborators.  If you are reading this, you understand that the arts are an integral part of our history and communities.  Sadly they are the least funded of all programs both in schools and in the larger context of society. However, even as government and foundation support has recently decreased, individual sponsors like you are stepping up to the plate, as illustrated by the recent surge in donations through sites such as this one.  YOU have the power to make great art accessible. 

 

In addition to helping us produce timely and exciting works of art, you will be the recipient of some exclusive perks, such as:  backstage passes, tickets to our home season, credit in the show program, a lunch date with the cast, our undying appreciation, and much more!  

 

The Impact

Immediately, your donation will result in a tangible product that we hope you will see for yourself! 

Our company has been growing exponentially since its inception in 2007.  Each year our productions supersede the success of the previous season in support, income, visibility and audience attendance.  The growth of DHPCo in all these areas tells us that we are creating work that resonates with people, in particular with people who had never had a prior relationship to modern dance. Your donation helps further the impact we are able to have on our communities, both locally and nationally, as we continue to create, perform, and tour.  

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that times are financially difficult for everyone but please know that even the smallest contribution makes a big difference. 

If you are unable to help financially, you can still help us out by distributing this campaign to your friends and family, by posting it on facebook, or by volunteering during performances.  We appreciate any form of aid you can give! 

 

THANK YOU, David Herrera

story:
Dearest Friends & Family,

        

For my undergraduate senior thesis at Purchase College, I am adapting and directing A Children's Tragedy, a performance experiment based on Frank Wedekind's Spring Awakening, the 1890 play that has served as a poetic critique on youth, education, and humanity for the past 123 years. 

 

In collaboration with my fellow seniors Jacob Louchheim and Madeline Moss, along with a passionate force of actors and designers from the Theatre Design/Technology and Theatre & Performance programs at Purchase College, I have worked extensively in classes and rehearsals to turn a simple idea into a living, breathing piece of work. My intent is not only to satisfy the requirements of the Theatre & Performance Directing concentration, but also to truly experience the collaborative, creative, and intellectual challenges that theatre offers.

 

As with any major project, production costs are inevitable and in order that we achieve the most dynamic set and costume construction possible we ask for a kind donation that will help us raise $600 for this project. In an effort to thank you for your contributions, we have several rewards that will deepen your connection with all of those involved in creating this piece. I am incredibly grateful for this opportunity and hope to see you at the show!

 

Thank you for your graciousness,

 

Sincerely,

 

Dena Kopolovich 

 -----

7:30pm March 7 & 8

1:30pm & 7:30pm March 9

@ the UnderGround!

Performing Arts Center at Purchase College 

Free Admission

story:
The Share Shakespeare Project by Arden Kelly 

Hi, I am Arden Kelly, a teaching artist in the performing arts in NYC.  I am a graduate of Juilliard and have been a professional actress/singer/dancer for many years.  

The Share Shakespeare Project’s goal is to teach students and teachers Shakespeare in The Philippines, and document the experience in a short film.  Recently, I have been on a journey to find my voice - what I have to say as an artist.  I came up with this project because of inspiration from my students to whom I introduced the story and text of Shakespeare’s Romeo and Juliet. 

This incredible project will allow me to introduce these students and teachers to the text, poetry and images Shakespeare conjures up for the first time in their lives and from a performing arts point of view.  With your help, I can bring joy and encourage imagination into the lives of these students and teachers, who otherwise may not have a creative outlet available to them.

The pledge goal of $2700.00 will be used in the following ways: $1800.00 for transportation, $550.00 for camera equipment and editing, $150.00 for teaching materials and supplies, and $200.00 to host a viewing party! 

As a contributor, you may receive one or all of the following perks: a mini-tutorial (this is a video where you learn about iambic-pentameter), sneak-peak footage of a class, an email video thank you from a student or teacher in my class or workshop, enjoy the launch party in NYC!

Whatever funds are raised will be used! Extra funds can and will be used to provide the students with materials such as books and other learning materials and further online lessons for the teachers and students.

Art changes people for the better. This is why I am an artist! I believe it makes people think about their actions and therefore, learn compassion.  Art inspires people to help others and shed light on those in the dark.  Your donation shines light on these students, so they can help their family, community, and their world.  You can help the teachers incorporate Shakespeare into their curriculum and therefore inspire students for many generations to come!

For those of you who know me, you know the passion I have for life is matched in my passion for performing and teaching!  For those who are not familiar with my work, I give 100% of my ability, creativity and effort in everything I do. 

Let me express my gratitude for you’re even taking the time to view and read about this project!  Thank you. 

I ask, that you please “share” this project and/or link to your friends and use the Indigogo share tools to help.

Salamat, which means thank you, spoken by the people of The Philippines!

story:
WE DID IT!

We made our initial goal of $3500 for our production of Salome! Thank you! Because of your generosity we have actually exceeded our goal and if we stretch the campaign goal to $5000 you can help us fund more essential production needs.

The masks and projector will be covered by the contributions made so far to the campaign but there are still a lot of costs associated with making this a great show that you can help us cover.

New "Stretch" Goal & New Perk!

We are setting a “stretch” goal of $5000. The additional money will go toward two major parts of the production. 1) The costumes, designed by our brilliant resident costume designer Liz Martin. 2) Now that we have money for the projector, we can focus funds on what will be projected. Creating a digital presentation of Salome’s dance as a digital film will involve a serious budget.

 Costume Budget = $500

 Creation of Salome’s dance for digital projection = $500

 $1000+ $4000ish (already raised) = $5000

To thank you for helping us continue this campaign we have a NEW PERK to offer. If you can help by donating at the $75 level we’ll reward you with an invitation to a private event for an exclusive viewing of masks before the show opens!

Other Ways You Can Help

Spreading the word is key. Don’t forget to tweet, share, post and even talk to people about the campaign. Anything you can do helps!

Thank you for believing in us and becoming a part of the magic of live theatre.

story:
We are the Brown University / Trinity Repertory Company MFA Class of 2014.  We are a diverse, talented, and committed group of actors from all different walks of life who share a passion for becoming superior theater artists. Through the course of our training, we’ve collaborated together, supported and pushed each other, and become a family. 

After three years of hard work under the careful guidance of some of the best teachers in the nation, we’re ready to meet the industry! Our class will cross the country—first to New York City, then to Los Angeles, where we will perform a showcase for agents, casting directors and managers. 

Each actor must pay his/her own way, and with 17 of us, flying to the West Coast is no small feat. We are raising funds in order to offset the cost of our trip.  With your contributions, you will help lighten the financial burden of these starving artists and help support the next generation of artists. We want to move toward this next step with our best foot forward, and support from friends, family, and patrons will mean the world to us!
