story:
Our New Musical

日本語ページはこちらから

 About MITF　

This year, Midtown International Theater Festival (MITF) will be held for the 14th time. It is a worldwide festival held in Midtown, NY.Last year, 19 companies performed on Off Off Broadway, 5 of which were companies from foreign countries.

Our original musical "Color of Life" passed this year, making us the first Japanese company to perform at MITF.

 


About us　

　Sachiko Ishimaru
　(Original Japanese Book/Lyrics/Director)


　

Graduated Waseda University(Faculty of Letters,Play major).
After experience as an actor, shifted to stage director. Worked as assistant director 　with directors such as Yukio Ninagawa, who often directs performances outside Japan. In 2008, became independent director. 

In 2006, launched Chichibu citizen musical at the request of Chichibu(Saitama Prefecture)
In 2009, opened a private acting school POLYPHONIC for the actor.
In 2010, launched own production company, Theatre Polyphonic.

Currently, counted four times private school performance, four times Theatre Polyphonic performance. From classic to contemporary, original musicals to straight plays, has created a wide range of work.

 

Yasuhiro Ito（Compose/Arrange/Actor）

Born in Yamagata Zao Onsen. Affected by his mother, started to sing a song from childhood.
From 10 years old, he started taking private lessons to learn the basics of a full-fledged song singing & acting, across a variety of genres. 
From 11years old, started composing ,piano,& solfeggioFrom 13 years old,started marimba and percussion.
From 15 years old, started composing.

In 2003 while attending the second year of high school, junior class of Marimba Competition in Japan ,he was awarded encouragement award and third place.
2004 He won the tournament in the Northeast music festival of high school with songs and poetry of his own.
Started songwriting in the wake of this, the current stock is more than 100. After graduating from high school, enrolled as a scholarship student at Showa University of Music.
While in school, appeared in many concerts inside and outside the university. Song, percussion, piano, composition, and guidance, after graduation, he is working in many ways.


Shino Frances
（Book Translation/English Lyrics/Actress）

 

A NYC based bicultural Singer-Actor-Dancer, originally from Connecticut and Japan. She has had continuous training/experience in theatre since the age of 6, starting with dance, and has carried with her a great passion for performing ever since.Shino is a graduate of Showa University of Music, Musical Theatre, 2005.

Off Broadway/Off-Off Broadway credits: Hisseli Harikalar Kumpanyasi, Beacon Theatre (Dancer/English Voiceover); From Broadway With Love (Maria, exerts from The Sound of Music); Wait For Hope (Mary Magdalene); 24Hour Play Fun, acting improve (Gina, Benefit for Pro-TV); Lulla’s Birthday Show (Dancer/Choreo.).Tour/Regional credits: ArtsPower National Touring Theatre; A Chorus Line, Crown Uptown Theatre (Connie Wong); Anything Goes (Mrs. Harcourt/Dance Cap.); Carousel (Ensemble).

Shino also holds the title of Co-artistic Dir./Performer, for the NYC based dance company, SUNPROJECT and is a Substitute Teacher at Steps on Broadway (Ettlin Floor Technique) and Ballet Arts (Theatre Dance).

Theatre Polyphonic　

A theatrical art is a composite art that is born with the cooperation of many artists. In order to produce such a creative company, We have named our own production team, ‘Theatre Polyphonic’. In order to resonate, to interact.

-Archives

　“ The Book of Devil”
　by Kenichi Tani　Directed Sachiko Ishimaru (October,2010)　

　Performed at wedding banquet “Three Sisters”
　by A.Chekhov  Directed by Sachiko Ishimaru (July,2012)
　
　Musical “Peer Gynt”
　by H.Ibsen Directed by Sachiko Ishimaru
　Composed by Yasuhiro Ito(December,2012)


　“The Woman in Tennessee Williams”
　by Tennessee Williams  Directed by Sachiko Ishimaru (March,2012)

　　Official Web Site

 

About "Color of Life"　　

 There are only two characters in our musical.

A man: a japanese rising painter, and a woman: a half-Japanese half American actress who moved from Japan to NY.  The two meet when they are seated next to each other on the plane to NY. It was a meeting that filled the hole of the woman’s broken heart. They sympathize with each other as two human beings, and love each other as a woman and a man.

However, the woman was a lesbian. Unsure why she suddenly fell in love with the other sex, the woman starts living with the man in her own apartment in NY.

In the limited time of 90 days that their visas allow them, the two touch each other, start to love, hesitate, meet walls, crash, care for each other, and learn to lean against one another. They explore an unexpected world of their own.　 After the three months are over – they meet an unchangable ending.

　"Color of Life" Official Web Site

What We Need & What You Get　

 In order to participate in the festival, we will create our work in NY with our actress who currently lives there.

Four of our company members: director (playwright), actor (composer) , Stage manager,and lighting technician、will fly to NY, stay for one month(Stage manager and Lighting technician-only 10days), hire studios for rehearsals, and pay the theater usage fee for participation.

At the lowest estimate, we need $20,000. We would like to ask you to help us raise $10,000 out of the $20,000 that is needed.

 Whatever the story, audiences should step into the dream, be intoxicated by the beauty, and forget about time when watching a musical. In order to create such a time that colors life, money is needed as much as talent, love, and hard work.

Although musicals are popular in Japan, most of them are translations of Broadway or West End pieces, and are produced on a commercial basis. We, a director/playwright and composer/actor, have stepped forward to create a musical that can match the world. Participating in MITF is a big chance for us. We believe that this summer’s success will lead us to a new stage as musical creators.

The Impact　　

A musical is a composite art that is born with the cooperation of many artists. In order to produce such a creative company, we have named our own production team, ‘Theatre Polyphonic’. When artists luckily meet up and start to create, it is very difficult to cover the costs with only ticket income. However, lack of subsidy for theatrical arts is a growing problem not only in Japan, but all around the world. We have continued to create without subsidy, just by using our love and time. 

On March 11th 2011, a large earthquake hit Japan and took the precious lives of many people. This experience made many artists wonder: what can we do in the field of ‘art’? Who am I? With the fear of the nuclear accident now in our daily lives, we are living in a new time that can never return to what it was before that fateful day. Many artists in Japan have stood still for a whaile, to think about the power and meaning of art. Now they are beginning to step forward once again. It must be that people have started to realize how much ‘art’ is necessary in our lives in many ways. It is amazing how music, stories, and laughter can save people and heal their wounds.

As for myself, I stopped all activities of Theatre Polyphonic in 2011 and produced some charity shows. After one year, I started to create just as before, with a new feeling in mind; with artists who changed for the better after the incident. My new days of expression have begun.

This summer, we will leap across the ocean with our own original musical, in order to show the world what we have.From Japan, to the city of musicals… to our dream, New York. We cannot leap only with love and time. Please lend us a hand to leap over this very tall wall.

Other Ways You Can Help　

Thank you for reading. Even if you cannot participate in the funding, there are still ways that you can help!

  • Post this link to your twitter, facebook, or blog.
  • Introduce this campaign to people who are interested in art, people who enjoy drama, musicals and song.
  • Come to our show!

　　　　　 Date　 Tue. July 16th at 8:00PM
                       Fri. July 19th at 9:45PM
                       Sat. July 20th at 8:30PM
                       Sun. July 21st at 7:00PM

              Venue   Abingdon Arts Complex　1st floor 
                         Dorothy Strelsin Theatre , 312 W. 36th Street, 1st floor, NYC


               Show information at http://midtownfestival.org/

　　　　　  Tickets can be purchased here　https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/cal/27845
story_txt:
Our New Musical
日本語ページはこちらから

 About MITF　

This year, Midtown International Theater Festival (MITF) will be held for the 14th time. It is a worldwide festival held in Midtown, NY.Last year, 19 companies performed on Off Off Broadway, 5 of which were companies from foreign countries.
Our original musical "Color of Life" passed this year, making us the first Japanese company to perform at MITF.
 

About us　
　Sachiko Ishimaru　(Original Japanese Book/Lyrics/Director)
　
Graduated Waseda University(Faculty of Letters,Play major).After experience as an actor, shifted to stage director. Worked as assistant director 　with directors such as Yukio Ninagawa, who often directs performances outside Japan. In 2008, became independent director. 
In 2006, launched Chichibu citizen musical at the request of Chichibu(Saitama Prefecture)In 2009, opened a private acting school POLYPHONIC for the actor.In 2010, launched own production company, Theatre Polyphonic.
Currently, counted four times private school performance, four times Theatre Polyphonic performance. From classic to contemporary, original musicals to straight plays, has created a wide range of work.
 

Yasuhiro Ito（Compose/Arrange/Actor）


Born in Yamagata Zao Onsen. Affected by his mother, started to sing a song from childhood.From 10 years old, he started taking private lessons to learn the basics of a full-fledged song singing & acting, across a variety of genres. From 11years old, started composing ,piano,& solfeggioFrom 13 years old,started marimba and percussion.From 15 years old, started composing.
In 2003 while attending the second year of high school, junior class of Marimba Competition in Japan ,he was awarded encouragement award and third place.2004 He won the tournament in the Northeast music festival of high school with songs and poetry of his own.Started songwriting in the wake of this, the current stock is more than 100. After graduating from high school, enrolled as a scholarship student at Showa University of Music.While in school, appeared in many concerts inside and outside the university. Song, percussion, piano, composition, and guidance, after graduation, he is working in many ways.

Shino Frances（Book Translation/English Lyrics/Actress）

 
A NYC based bicultural Singer-Actor-Dancer, originally from Connecticut and Japan. She has had continuous training/experience in theatre since the age of 6, starting with dance, and has carried with her a great passion for performing ever since.Shino is a graduate of Showa University of Music, Musical Theatre, 2005.
Off Broadway/Off-Off Broadway credits: Hisseli Harikalar Kumpanyasi, Beacon Theatre (Dancer/English Voiceover); From Broadway With Love (Maria, exerts from The Sound of Music); Wait For Hope (Mary Magdalene); 24Hour Play Fun, acting improve (Gina, Benefit for Pro-TV); Lulla’s Birthday Show (Dancer/Choreo.).Tour/Regional credits: ArtsPower National Touring Theatre; A Chorus Line, Crown Uptown Theatre (Connie Wong); Anything Goes (Mrs. Harcourt/Dance Cap.); Carousel (Ensemble).
Shino also holds the title of Co-artistic Dir./Performer, for the NYC based dance company, SUNPROJECT and is a Substitute Teacher at Steps on Broadway (Ettlin Floor Technique) and Ballet Arts (Theatre Dance).
Theatre Polyphonic　
A theatrical art is a composite art that is born with the cooperation of many artists. In order to produce such a creative company, We have named our own production team, ‘Theatre Polyphonic’. In order to resonate, to interact.
-Archives　“ The Book of Devil”　by Kenichi Tani　Directed Sachiko Ishimaru (October,2010)　
　Performed at wedding banquet “Three Sisters”　by A.Chekhov  Directed by Sachiko Ishimaru (July,2012)　　Musical “Peer Gynt”　by H.Ibsen Directed by Sachiko Ishimaru　Composed by Yasuhiro Ito(December,2012)
　“The Woman in Tennessee Williams”　by Tennessee Williams  Directed by Sachiko Ishimaru (March,2012)　　Official Web Site

story:
What is Loser Slam?

  • Every year, Loser Slam sends a team to a national competition where they face off against the best talent the nation, and sometimes the world, has to offer
  • The team is composed of four individuals who write, edit, and polish poems, and then perform them in preliminary slam competitions through out the year to make one final Grand Slam.
  • The top four poets in that final grand slam go to nationals. 

What Ya Can Do & What Ya Do It For

We need more than $2,000 to afford travel, hotel stay, and other expenses

  • The bulk of the $2,000 is used to fund the cost of

          1. Travel

          2. Hotel Accomodations

          3. Meals

  • We are giving away unique rewards for your contributions, such as:

          1. CD's
          2. Posters
          3. T-Shirts
          4. Chapbooks & Complilations
          5. Body Massages
          6. Kung-Fu Lessons
          7. Paintings
          8. Performances
          9. Dates

  • If we don't reach our entire goal, we'll still get a majority of what you donate to help foot the cost, but then the team members will have to work doubles and triples at work and sell of belongings and body parts to make up the difference

Here's The Deal...

These four people have never experienced anything like this. It is important to help these young artists get out into the world and get their art heard. They will be representing the better part of New Jersey, and they need every bit of help to ensure they can practice their summer away and be excellent representations of this great state.

  • Poetry is art. Art makes the world a better place
  • Last year, everyone helped Loser Slam raise over $1,400 and the team made it to Group Finals, how excellent to know you could be a part of something like that again!!

Non-Monetary Contributors

We know not everyone has fresh dough flow to kick in, so here's how you can do us a solid:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Copy & paste that link everywhere you possibly can.
  • Tell your wealthy relatives how this will get them into a good afterlife, if they believe in that sort of thing!

That's it! Just spread the word, my good people.

story:
Who are we?

This Is Water Theatre is the first professional theatre company in Bryan/College Station, founded by a former Texas A&M student with the goal of raising the national artistic profile of Bryan/College Station.  If you think that sounds cool, you can read more about us here and check out what we need below!

It's Simple: We're asking for $10

Well, not $10 total, that would be a waste of time.  I could probably find $10 in change beneath the seats of my car, if I was desperate enough (Update: I went and looked.  $3.21).

No, we're asking for ten bucks from each of you reading this to help raise the start-up funds for This Is Water Theatre, the first professional, ensemble theatre company in Bryan/College Station, TX.  

This might be the point at which some people would list things that cost around $10, like "two drinks at Starbucks" or "a meal out" or "a bunch of extra lives in Candy Crush Saga," but somehow reminding you of the things you could otherwise be doing with that $10 sounds counterproductive.

But then again, theatre is more than just lunch at Chili's, and your $10 isn't a handout.  It's an investment in the foundation of the first professional theatre company in this city.

What do you need my $10 for?

You know that phrase, "You need money to make money"?  Well, that's a real thing.  Except we don't really want to "make money" as an organization since we are operating on a non-profit model.  So for us it's more like "You need money to raise money."  

Getting off of the ground takes a lot of time and money.  Stamps, letterhead and printed marketing materials, graphic design work...all of those are super important and cost money to do well.  We need to be able to, at the very least, help pay for the utility cost of the facility where we hold auditions, and perhaps even rental costs if we can't get space donated for the later stages.

In addition, we have monthly expenses like web hosting, liability insurance (kind of important), a PO Box and initial marketing for auditions, among others.

Why did you start this if you don't have the $$?

There's a reason lots of actors work a second job...cause the one they love doesn't pay real well.  ;-)

More important than the money that our Founding Investors donate is their vote of confidence in our mission. After all, theatre is about community, even professional theatre. Artists rely on their communities to help support them, and in turn they give back by creating well-made art that has an impact on those communities. But before you can impact a community you need to build the tools to do so. Together.

What do I get for my $10?

Basically, you're making a bet.  You're betting $10 that This Is Water Theatre will make a difference in this community.  You're saying that you believe in the ideals of what we're doing (you can read all about our mission here) and that you're willing to help give us a chance to prove you right.  You're betting on the transformative power of theatre.  And you'll get a nifty spot on our list of "Founding Investors."

I know your mother may have told you not to gamble, but I think even she'd agree this isn't what she meant.  

I don't live anywhere near you. Why should I care?

First, let's not be so confrontational with the tone!  We're all friends here! Friends that are asking you for $10, but still friends!

You should care because This Is Water Theatre doesn't want to stay in Bryan/College Station.  We want to engage theatre artists around the country in the "back room" that is the internet.  To this end, our Artistic Director will be blogging about the first year of This Is Water for the national theatre website, HowlRound.com.  Additionally, we want to travel. Whether through fringe festivals, more formal touring productions, or online streaming, we want to make our work available outside of our immediate geographical area. 

Now before you get too excited, traveling probably isn't going to happen this year.  But we can't get to year two or year five or year ten without getting through year one...which brings us back to asking for $10.

Is that $10 tax deductible?

A person after my own heart.  You and I can be deduction-finding buddies!  

Thanks to our awesome fiscal sponsor, Fractured Atlas, all of your donations to this campaign are in fact tax deductible!

What the hell is water?

...that's kinda what we're trying to figure out here.  Got $10?

A person after my own heart.  You and I can be deduction-finding buddies!

What the hell is water?
...that's kinda what we're trying to figure out here.  Got $10?

story:
"Any live wire is a dead one without good connections..."

Who is LiveWire Chicago?

LiveWire Chicago is a collective of artists who produce original contemporary voices of American theatre in Chicago. We have come a long way from our humble beginnings as Visiting Artists at the Side Project to producing downtown at the Chicago DCA Storefront Theater and establishing our unique annual short play festival, VisionFest, now in its fourth year.


LiveWire began our current 6th season in the fall with the Chicago premiere of A Bright New Boise by 2011 Obie Award-winning playwright, Samuel D. Hunter. We are excited to continue this season with the Chicago premiere of Oohrah! by Bekah Brunstetter at Steppenwolf Theatre's Garage Rep as part of their 2012 season devoted to the theme "Dispatches from the Homefront."


Oohrah! is the comedic tale of a soldier's homecoming gone awry. More info about our production at Steppenwolf can be found here.


Your Impact

LiveWire is making our biggest leap to date with the production at Steppenwolf and we need your support. Your gift today will go towards stipends paid to our talented artists, marketing materials that help us get pepole in the seats and running costs such as purchasing cookies, tater tots and nuts used on stage.


LiveWire has also committed to donating 10% of the funds we raise through this campaign to the Vet Art Project. The Vet Art Project provides opportunities for veterans and their families to work in collaboration with artists to create art about war and service, and to foster discussion about how war and service affect us all.


Every dollar makes a difference to both organizations.


What You Get

Funding this project will provide you with the knowledge that you did something generous and awesome with your day! We're also offering some additional perks that you can review here. LiveWire Chicago Theatre is a 501(c)3 not for profit organization, so all donations made are tax-deductible.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us spread the word by sharing our story on Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, etc. Word of mouth is our best friend, so the next time you are telling someone about your day, let them know that you made a difference and show them how they can do the same!


More info about LiveWire Chicago Theatre can be found at www.livewirechicago.com.


Thank you for your consideration.

story:
Our Rhythm

An artist whether dancer, musician, actor or singer uses his or her body to communicate. 

TREES joins these languages in innovative collaborations performed throughout New York City.We seek to bring together these individuals and create connections of artistic communication while establishing opportunities for artists to speak their voices, in any form, to any audience.  

How you can join

Your money makes our music stronger in these ways:

  • Supporting the artists monetarily.
  • Providing for costs of production.
  • Publicity needs such as postcards and fliers. 

Our premiere performance, Pairs, was on August 28th at Spike Hill Brooklyn, New York, and it was only the first note in the beginning of a beautiful song. We are excited to bring you, Current at the Bowery Electric, which will include excerpts from Pairs and new works with new artists that have joined us.

Your donation will not only support this performance, but it will also create a foundation for TREES to further our artistic endeavors to have more performances throughout 2014 and 2015. Share this link with friends and family everywhere so they too can join the rhythm and feel the music. 

Photography credits: Julia Discenza, Pearce Pachuta, and Lisa Pachuta
story_txt:
Our Rhythm
An artist whether dancer, musician, actor or singer uses his or her body to communicate. 
TREES joins these languages in innovative collaborations performed throughout New York City.We seek to bring together these individuals and create connections of artistic communication while establishing opportunities for artists to speak their voices, in any form, to any audience.  
How you can join
Your money makes our music stronger in these ways:
Supporting the artists monetarily.
Providing for costs of production.
Publicity needs such as postcards and fliers. 
Our premiere performance, Pairs, was on August 28th at Spike Hill Brooklyn, New York, and it was only the first note in the beginning of a beautiful song. We are excited to bring you, Current at the Bowery Electric, which will include excerpts from Pairs and new works with new artists that have joined us.Your donation will not only support this performance, but it will also create a foundation for TREES to further our artistic endeavors to have more performances throughout 2014 and 2015. Share this link with friends and family everywhere so they too can join the rhythm and feel the music. Photography credits: Julia Discenza, Pearce Pachuta, and Lisa Pachuta

story:
The Project

Welcome to my Wake is a LIVE bucket list show.

What have you always wanted to do before you die? Do you have a bucket list? Join me, Ingrid Nilson, for an unexpected and enlighgtening evening in the Emily Carr parking garage on Granville Island.

This inspired project has been in the works for many years and I'm thrilled to see it come alive. Welcome to my wake was born from a vulnerable place. From the darkness of a parking garage, this show celebrates life in all its sparkle!

It may seem like an unlikely spot for dreams to come true but why not try? A living, breathing experiment with surprises, twists and a sprinkle of Shakespeare.

Producing a theatre show takes a whole lotta energy, time, and money. And PEOPLE to achieve dreams. This is where you can be a part of dreams coming true! Your support today help will produce a show that shines.

This live performance is part of Vancouver International Fringe Festival happening September 6-16, 2012. To see the exact DATES & TIMES and TO BUY TICKETS, visit:

http://www.vancouverfringe.com/event-details/?show=12PO4

 

Who We Are

To cover the cost of creating dreams come true, including compensation to a creative dream team who have offered a lot of heart, please support.

Be inspired to support the project! Meet my talented team:

Chris Robson, director. His dream is to write a magical musical!

Tanille Geib, creative producer. Tanille's deepest desire is to bike across Canada before leaving Earth.

Ryan Caron, creative manager/ genius. Ryan wants to rock out on the radio!

Jessica Nelson, creative manager/ adventurer. Jessica is living her dream. She is currently traveling Europe!

Ingrid Nislon, creator & performer. Ingrid's desire is to compensate the colossal crew helping this dream to come true.

 

Perky Perks

To your right there are many options to be involved and be delighted! Take a look to see what perk makes you twinkle.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have cash support, here are ways can lend a hand.

We are currently seeking volunteer support for the day on Sunday September 2nd for 3 hour intervals between 10-1 & 1-4. Let us know if you can: welcometomywake@gmail.com


Also, you can blitz this on your social media by providing our link:

indiegogo.com/welcomewake

story:
WIN TICKETS TO SEE FLUFFY BUNNIES!!!

 
The Fluffy Bunnies Indiegogo prize drawing is here! One lucky supporter will receive a $100 VIP Package for Two - all you have to do is make a contribution to our indiegogo campaign in any dollar amount (yes, even just $1) by Thursday, May 31, and your name will be placed in a hat, where you could win the VIP Package. BONUS: if your donation exceeds $30 and you win our drawing, we will either give you the $100 VIP package or upgrade you to the $250 Ultimate Superstar Date Night Package.
 
Here's the fine print:
Limit one entry per person.
People who have already contributed to the campaign ARE automatically eligible and will be included in the drawing. 
No purchase necessary. To enter the drawing without making a contribution, simply send an email with your name and contact information, using the subject line "I'm too cheap to give the Bunnies a dollar," to FluffyBunniesLA@gmail.com
________________________________________________________________________

"Absurdly Hilarious!" – LA Times
"Screamingly Funny!" – Variety
"The Perfect Show!" – Backstage
"BEST IN FRINGE" – Theatre Mania

We're going to tell you a story....

It's a history story.... But, LISTEN... You don't have to read all of this if you don't want to. Just pick your reward from the menu over there to the right and click on one of those pink "CLAIM THIS PERK>" buttons. THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

But hey, if you're still interested in our story, here it goes:

ONCE UPON A TIME, there were Bunnies…

One summer not too long ago, a brand-spanking-new play opened at a modest 40-seat theater in Hollywood: an eight-character romantic comedy that was funny, smart, and entertaining.  Like most such productions, the original run was attended by friends and family of the cast, plus a few enterprising theatre-goers entranced by the title, or the postcard, or both…

But then reviews started rolling in… and they were really GOOD! Thus a hit was born. When we thought the play had run its course, we announced a closing date and threw a blow-out closing night party…. only to wake up the next morning to an answering machine full of requests for reservations.  We reopened, and kept going, and going, and going… Big, fancy producers came calling, talking about a New York run and a national tour… but could the play just be rewritten a bit… to cut out a few characters… or maybe make it a one-act… or, actually, could you maybe turn it into a one-person show, with puppets…?  And after much due deliberation, we decided, that no, we actually really liked the play the way it was: an eight-character romantic comedy that was funny, smart, and entertaining.  

And so the bunnies rode quietly off into the sunset… UNTIL NOW.

A few years have passed and while all of us have gone on do to many other shows, this is the one everyone still asks about…. Not only that, but there’s now an entire generation (in Los Angeles, a few years constitutes a generation) of new people who haven’t even heard of the show… or rather, haven’t heard of it yet…

AND SO… we are very pleased to announce the triumphant return of Fluffy Bunnies in a Field of Daisies… with a BRAND NEW CAST of incredibly talented performers…. I mean UNBELIEVABLY talented... seriously, you should see them, they're amazing... Opening JUNE 7, 2012 at the historic Arena Stage in Hollywood... which just happens to be 10 years TO THE DAY of the original opening.   Fancy.

...BUT... here's the deal... 

Putting on good quality live theater is EXPENSIVE... even doing almost all of the work - from building and painting the set to running the box office to handing out postcards to the tourists right there on Hollywood boulevard - ourselves, our costs will still run well north of $20,000... now there are some clever ways to reduce costs... and our producer is a hell of a negotiator... but at the end of the day, even after saving our pennies to make this dream come true, we are still dependent on the support of people like you to make this work.

In order to do this right, we want to tell EVERYONE about this show... and to do that, we've done some VERY precise calculations and determined that we need to raise an additional $5624 by June 1 to cover our marketing and publicity expenses.

What We Need & What You Get

Fluffy Bunnies In A Field of Daisies runs from June 7 - July 28, 2012, at The Arena Stage @ Theater of Arts in Hollywood. With less than a month until opening, we need to raise some funds to kick us off with a bang!

While $5624 isn't a huge budget to promote a show in Los Angeles - especially in this neighborhood (we're across the street from Cirque du Soleil's IRIS at Hollywood & Highland), it represents a HUGE sum for us... and we are exceptionally good at doing a lot with very little. YOUR GENEROUS DONATION can make the difference between an entertaining show performed for a smattering of those forutnate few who stumble upon us, and a MONSTER HIT SHOW, playing to packed houses of amazed theater-goers, doubled over with laughter and weeping with tears of joy.

But to make that happen, we need your help. Please click one of the "CLAIM THIS PERK>" buttons now!

We are deeply grateful for anything you can donate, but, hey, it's not all about us... WE want to reward YOU for helping bring this amazing show to the world. Some donation levels include an actual ticket to see the play... which YOU were probably seriously considering doing anyway... For our supporters from out of town, we have signed postcards or posters or even genuine official FLUFFY BUNNIES t-shirts for you. Of course, ALL of our donors will receive our everlasting gratitute.

Wait... you're STILL reading...? What...? 

Oh... What's the show about, you ask....?  Well... 

Fluffy Bunnies in a Field of Daisies is an upbeat comedy of sexual politics, exploring meeting, getting fixed up, and dating, as a group of friends undertakes minute investigations and categorizing of their experiences. The result is a happy interaction of stories, sophisticated on-target writing, and impeccable comic acting with perfect timing. It's audience tested yet fresh as a daisy. Throw in a full-cast dance number and the bonus that there's actually a message – something about consideration and finally getting real – and Fluffy Bunnies is ready to rock this town.

THANK YOU FOR YOUR HELP AND SUPPORT!

Sincerely, 

The Bunnies:

Drew, Matt, Aimee, Amy, Bobbi, Cynthia, Dean, Joey, Karolin, Kip, Lyndsey, Lynsey, Matthew, Meredith, Mike, Samantha, Steffinnie, Stephanie, and Stephen

story:
What is Knitting Pattern?

Inspired by an old book of knitting instructions, Deborah Nash has written a new play that explores patterns – those we live, and those we knit. On a lonely mountain top, Three Fates make, measure and cut yarn, click-clacking the shapes of other people’s lives – until their knitting is interrupted by the arrival of the enigmatic Purl. See Knitting Pattern at the inaugural Words Over Waltham Forest Festival at Walthamstow Central Library (16th November, 11am and 2pm) and Leytonstone Library (22nd November, 4.30 and 6.00pm).

Project History & Creative Team

Knitting Pattern was presented as a staged reading in March 2013 as part of Goldsmiths Plays new writing series at Goldsmiths, University of London. Despite the staged reading format, we approached the text through movement and objects (including giant knitting needles!) from the beginning. Knitting Pattern is directed by Becka McFadden with movement direction by Scheherazaad Cooper and performed by Alexandra Draghici, Barbora Hanusova, Lara Parmiani and Eliza Soroga. Design by Karen Mayor. We are an international team of performance and cross-arts practitioners hailing from six different countries. Goldsmiths was our primary common denominator – until we all learned how to knit together!

Impact

Our WOWF performances will be provided free of charge to the community. It’s our hope that they will stimulate a discussion about the role of knitting in the lives of individuals and groups. This has already begun through Deborah’s on-going research and meetings with local North London knitters, whose stories have already found their way into the play. After our November performances, we’ll be pursuing opportunities to present our work in textile museums, gallery and theatres across the UK and Europe.

Where do you come in?

Funds raised will cover expenses related to costume design and construction, which are new (knitted!) elements for this production. While this project is a labour of love for us all, we also believe in fair payment for artists. Funds raised will allow us to cover travel expenses and basic honorariums. All donors will be entered in a prize draw to win a bespoke knitted scarf in the colour of their choice. If you’d like to support us with a donation of knitting talent and make an item for the show, please do get in touch.

story:
Short Summary

"What if all your dreams came true... for your best friend?"

Ryerson Theatre School graduates Ellis Rockburn and Noah Spitzer have decided enough is enough. They have given their notice at their restaurant jobs, picked a play, and are packing their bags to tour a play to their hometown of Ottawa for the holidays. The play is The Four of Us by Itamar Moses, an American playwright whose dramatic comedy about friendship between two struggling young writers is sure to delight Ottawa theatre-goers when it is performed December 18, 19, and 20 at Ottawa's Arts Court Theatre. 

The play begins when a budding novelist, Ben (played by Rockburn), reveals to his best friend David, a struggling playwright (played by Spitzer), that he has signed his first book deal for $2 million. In non-chronological order, the play explores how fame and fortune can cause a friendship to crumble. The New York Times calls it "a clever comic drama with a nifty twist... a touching, appealing play." 

Contributors will help pay for the rights to the show, the theatre rental, props, costumes, and time in a rehearsal studio!


What We Need & What You Get

We need approximately $800 just to get to the point where we can even think about paying people with the box office revenue. Here's how the funds will be used:

$234: Cost of the Samuel French License in US dollars.

$548: The cost of the theatre rental for 3 performances.

$125: Studio Rental Cost for the Fringe Creation Lab.

$75: Budget for set, props, and costume pieces. 

BREAK-EVEN POINT: $982.

Anything above that can go to publicity and marketing costs, honorariums for the technical and artistic support on the show, and extra time in rehearsal!

See a description of our perks for what you get for your support! We offer everything from a personal thank-you online to gift-wrapping your presents in your home!

The Impact

With every contribution, you will be supporting indie theatre in Canada and helping young artists grow and learn. You will be investing in artistic development, and most importantly, ensuring that "the show must go on!"

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, we can always use your support in other ways! Tell your friends and family about the show, tweet and Facebook about it, and share our page with 5 people who you think would find it interesting!

story:
WHO WE ARE

Theater Alpha, a historical place in the heart of Athens, founded in 1958 – as historical as the center of the city itself – has always been up to today, a place of artistic expression, contemplation and spring of ideas, for every artist who approached its stage.

In 1971 it houses the 'Contemporary Greek Theater', a new organization that even though was in just its first year of operation (founded in 30 August 1970), already counted 5 theatrical plays!

Its founders, two critically acclaimed actors of Greek theater and cinema, Stefanos Linaios and Ellie Fotiou, who decided to operate the Theater after 4 years, bringing in new theatrical acts from England and Athens. They established an alternate repertoire and enriched their program with concurrent festivities.

WE NEED YOUR HELP


A BIG HISTORY

In 1958 the Theater's stage was inaugurated with a play written by Alekos Sakellarios, titled "The 6th American Fleet".

Until 1967 it housed various artists and repertories.

From 1971 to 1974 during the same difficult years that Greece was taken over by a dictatorship regime, they turned the Theater into a place of political activism, and a coordinating meeting ground for artistic and political action against the dictators. All this action culminated in the events of the Polytechneio uprising, in 17 November 1973, another historical place, located just across the street from Theater Alpha.

Meanwhile, it was during this period that the Greek Company for the Study of Greek Problems (Ε.Μ.Ε.Π.) was founded and housed in the Theater, and its goal was to condemn the reign of the Greek dictatorship through various talks and speeches. It was there at 1972, when a major speech was held by the Nobel laureate novelist and playwright Günter W.Grass, titled “A speech concerning Habit”, while at the same time police forces were surrounding the Theater.


In 1977, another event marks its history. A destructive flood in Athens, was cause of major damage inside the Theater and almost led to its complete destruction. A big part of the Theater's archives up to that day, was destroyed and the whole event came close to claiming human lives.

The Theater was never compensated by the Greek state for the effects of this disaster.

In the years that followed, the Contemporary Greek Theater saw significant growth and development. More than 40 plays were staged there, most notably Milan Kundera's 'The Owner of the Keys', Dario Fo's 'Accidental Death of an Anarchist', Alexander Mirodan's 'Famous 702' and Henrik Ibsen's 'The Lady from the Sea'. They also cooperated with critically-acclaimed artists like Mikis Theodorakis, James Rouse-Evans, George Michailidis, Vasilis Dimitriou and others.

Many of these plays (and in particular the contemporary ones, like Kostas Mourselas's 'Dangerous Cargo', Gerasimos Stavros's 'Goodnight Margarita', James Rouse-Evans's 'Oedipus in Athens') were performed only a handful of times, having being deemed as 'radical' and 'provoking' from the dictators's regime and banned, leading to the Theater's closure for many days in a row, a closure that almost became a permanent one.

In the years that followed, not only theatrical plays were staged at the Theater. In 1981, an LP album was recorded and published (a first for the Theater), featuring songs from various theatrical performances that were staged there through the years. The Theater also housed many music concerts and tributes dedicated to domestic and international writers and novelists, like Dimitris Hatzis, Gerasimos Stavrou, Dario Fo and others.

Dario Fo in particular (alongside his wife Franca Rame), has been a personal friend to Stefanos Linaios and a supporter of Theater Alpha. Fo entrusted on Linaios two of his most important works, 'Accidental Death of an Anarchist' and 'Can't Pay? Won't Pay!', two plays that reached the milestone of having been performed more than 1.700 times world-wide, while being staged at the Theater during the 2011-2012 season.

It was at the Theater that the first Artists Chess Tournaments were housed during the 1970's, a tradition that follows to today, now under a new roof.

The Theater has always had (and continues to have) an active participation in various political and humanitarian advocacy groups. It was at the Theater where the Greek-Turkish friendship Committee was founded in 1987 (its founders being Stefanos Linaios and Mikis Theodorakis), and the 'Stop the War' Alliance in 2003 that advocated for the end the then-ongoing war in Iraq. 

THE 'CONTEMPORARY GREEK THEATER' TODAY:

Since 2010, Stefanos Linaios fully resumes his theatrical activities, staging Dario Fo's great success 'Can't Pay? Won't Pay!' and with a new team of young artists is leading an effort to bridge the older generation's knowledge and experience with the new one.

Last winter he presented Henrik Ibsen's classic 'An Enemy of the People', which turned out to be a great artistic success but not a commercial one, since the ongoing Greek debt crisis had a huge effect on Athens's theaters, with most of them going out of business.

The new season this year will open with a series of festivities:

- Theatrical plays

- Paintings exhibitions

- Photography exhibitions

- Book sales bazaars

- musical concerts

- dancing presentations

- Talks and seminars

- Other public talks

In addition, a full list of classical and contemporary theatrical plays as the Theater's repertoire, remains our main goal. This could lead to even more people of any age to be able to watch plays that are relevant to them, as well as other productions of importance. This has always been the goal of the Contemporary Greek Theater and remains one till today.

In 2008, the full renovation of the Theater took place, signaling the beginning of a new era.

The Theater's Stage, with a capacity of 400+ seats, carries a full set of audio and visual equipment, a video projector suitable for video presentations and the ability for scene alternations among other things.

The Central Foyer-Bar, with a 100-person hosting capacity, houses various talks, speeches and seminars.

The new 'Area for Arts & Culture' that was founded in 2012, can house individual, small exhibitions (e.g. art or photography), that are displayed concurrently with the Theater's theatrical performances.

In the 'Small Foyer', an exhibition will be displayed soon, celebrating 43 years of the Contemporary Greek Theater's activities.


WHAT IF I CAN'T HELP FINANCIALLY?

No problem! We would be very happy if you could share our campaign with as many people as you can. The Internet is the best means for that! This way, everyone would be able to be informed through our web pages not only for this campaign, but also for all of the Theater's new activities and performances as well.

Sharing, is the best reward for us!

A BIG 'THANK YOU' TO ALL OF YOU!
story_txt:
WHO WE ARE 
Theater
Alpha, a historical place in the heart of Athens, founded in 1958 – as
historical as the center of the city itself – has always been up to today, a
place of artistic expression, contemplation and spring of ideas, for every
artist who approached its stage.
In 1971 it
houses the 'Contemporary Greek Theater', a new organization that even though
was in just its first year of operation (founded in 30 August 1970), already
counted 5 theatrical plays!


Its
founders, two critically acclaimed actors of Greek theater and cinema, Stefanos
Linaios and Ellie Fotiou, who decided to operate the Theater after 4 years,
bringing in new theatrical acts from England and Athens. They established an
alternate repertoire and enriched their program with concurrent festivities. 
WE NEED YOUR HELP





A BIG HISTORY
In 1958 the Theater's stage was inaugurated with a play written by Alekos Sakellarios, titled "The 6th American Fleet".
Until 1967 it housed various artists and repertories. From 1971
to 1974 during the same difficult years that Greece was taken over by a
dictatorship regime, they turned the Theater into a place of political
activism, and a coordinating meeting ground for artistic and political action
against the dictators. All this action culminated in the events of the Polytechneio
uprising, in 17 November 1973, another historical place, located just across
the street from Theater Alpha.
Meanwhile,
it was during this period that the Greek Company for the Study of Greek
Problems (Ε.Μ.Ε.Π.) was
founded and housed in the Theater, and its goal was to condemn the reign of the
Greek dictatorship through various talks and speeches. It was there at 1972,
when a major speech was held by the Nobel laureate novelist and playwright
Günter W.Grass,
titled “A
speech concerning Habit”, while at the same time police forces were surrounding
the Theater.

In 1977,
another event marks its history. A destructive flood in Athens, was cause of major damage inside the
Theater and almost led to its complete destruction. A big part of the Theater's
archives up to that day, was destroyed and the whole event came close to
claiming human lives. 

The Theater
was never compensated by the Greek state for the effects of this disaster.
In the
years that followed, the Contemporary Greek Theater saw significant growth and
development. More than 40 plays were staged there, most notably Milan Kundera's
'The Owner of the Keys', Dario Fo's 'Accidental Death of an Anarchist', Alexander Mirodan's 'Famous 702' and Henrik Ibsen's 'The Lady from the Sea'. They also
cooperated with critically-acclaimed artists like Mikis Theodorakis, James
Rouse-Evans, George Michailidis, Vasilis Dimitriou and others.
Many
of these plays (and in particular the contemporary ones, like Kostas Mourselas's
'Dangerous Cargo', Gerasimos Stavros's 'Goodnight Margarita',
James Rouse-Evans's 'Oedipus in Athens') were performed only a
handful of times, having being deemed as 'radical' and 'provoking' from the
dictators's regime and banned, leading to the Theater's closure for many days
in a row, a closure that almost became a permanent one. 
In
the years that followed, not only theatrical plays were staged at the Theater.
In 1981, an LP album was recorded and published (a first for the Theater),
featuring songs from various theatrical performances that were staged there
through the years. The Theater also housed many music concerts and tributes
dedicated to domestic and international writers and novelists, like Dimitris
Hatzis, Gerasimos Stavrou, Dario Fo and others.
Dario
Fo in particular (alongside his wife Franca Rame), has been a personal friend
to Stefanos Linaios and a supporter of Theater Alpha. Fo entrusted on Linaios
two of his most important works, 'Accidental Death of an Anarchist' and
'Can't Pay? Won't Pay!', two plays
that reached the milestone of having been performed more than 1.700 times
world-wide, while being staged at the Theater during the 2011-2012 season. 
It
was at the Theater that the first Artists Chess Tournaments were housed during
the 1970's, a tradition that follows to today, now under a new roof. 
The
Theater has always had (and continues to have) an active participation in
various political and humanitarian advocacy groups. It was at the Theater where
the Greek-Turkish friendship Committee was founded in 1987 (its founders being
Stefanos Linaios and Mikis Theodorakis), and the 'Stop the War' Alliance in
2003 that advocated for the end the then-ongoing war in Iraq. 


THE 'CONTEMPORARY GREEK THEATER' TODAY:
Since 2010,
Stefanos Linaios fully resumes his theatrical activities, staging Dario Fo's
great success 'Can't Pay?
Won't Pay!' and with a new team of young artists is leading an effort to bridge
the older generation's knowledge and experience with the new one. 

Last winter
he presented Henrik Ibsen's classic 'An Enemy of the People', which turned out
to be a great artistic success but not a commercial one, since the ongoing
Greek debt crisis had a huge effect on Athens's theaters, with most of them
going out of business. 
The new
season this year will open with a series of festivities:
-
Theatrical plays
- Paintings
exhibitions
-
Photography exhibitions
- Book
sales bazaars
- musical
concerts
- dancing
presentations
- Talks and
seminars
- Other
public talks
In
addition, a full list of classical and contemporary theatrical plays as the
Theater's repertoire, remains our main goal. This could lead to even more
people of any age to be able to watch plays that are relevant to them, as well
as other productions of importance. This has always been the goal of the
Contemporary Greek Theater and remains one till today.
In
2008, the full renovation of the Theater took place, signaling the beginning of
a new era. 
The
Theater's Stage, with a capacity of 400+ seats, carries a full set of
audio and visual equipment, a video projector suitable for video presentations
and the ability for scene alternations among other things.
The
Central Foyer-Bar, with a 100-person hosting capacity, houses various
talks, speeches and seminars. 
The
new 'Area for Arts & Culture' that was founded in 2012, can house
individual, small exhibitions (e.g. art or photography), that are displayed
concurrently with the Theater's theatrical performances. 
In
the 'Small Foyer', an exhibition will be displayed soon, celebrating 43
years of the Contemporary Greek Theater's activities. 



WHAT IF I CAN'T HELP FINANCIALLY?

No
problem! We would be very happy if you could share our campaign with as many
people as you can. The Internet is the best means for that! This way, everyone
would be able to be informed through our web pages not only for this campaign,
but also for all of the Theater's new activities and performances as well.
Sharing,
is the best reward for us!
A BIG 'THANK YOU' TO ALL OF YOU!

story:
Support Caribbean theater, music, storytelling, dance and film. The folkloric traditions of all of the Caribbean must be preserved. The newest play, "Callaloo: A Jazz Folktale" honors and celebrates the stories of Trinidad and Tobago through jazz music, dance, film, costuming and storytelling. 

We plan to premiere this show in OCTOBER 2012 in Washington, DC. Help us bring this show to the nation's couple by becoming an official CALLALOO SPONSOR!

All funds will go towards: costuming, props, rehearsal rentals, transportation fees, marketing, graphic design, sound design and artist fees. 

 We also plan to take it on a world tour in 2013-2014 to some of the following venues/festivals:

LA Caribbean Festival (Los Angeles, CA), Miami Caribbean Festival (Miami, FL),     DC Jazz Festival (Washington, DC), The Heritage Festival (Tobago, West Indies), Gimistory Festival (Cayman Islands, West Indies), Harlem Stage (New York, NY), Ouro Preto Jazz Festival (Brazil, South America), Baranquilla Jazz Festival (Colombia, South America), Stax Music Academy (Memphis, Tennesse), Hostos Community College (Bronx, NY), Jazz-Reggae Festival (Los Angeles, CA), Black Sea Jazz Festival (Batumi, GA), Vittoria Jazz Festival (Vittoria, Spain), The Caribbean Cultural Center (New York, NY), The University of the West Indies (Port of Spain, Trinidad, West Indies). 

 

cal·la·loo/ˌkaləˈlo͞o/

 
Noun:
  1. The spinachlike leaves of a tropical American plant (genus Xanthosoma) of the arum family, widely used in Caribbean cooking.
  2. A soup or stew made with such leaves.
 
"I decided to name the play, 'Callaloo' because Trinidad and Tobago have unique histories where the mixing of peoples created new stories, cultures and customs. Without the mixing, these islands would have a very different cultural identity"
-Marjuan Canady (playwright/actress) 
 
 
THE STORY:
Callaloo: A Jazz Folktale is a jazz, dance play full of Caribbean sensibilities. Underscored by Etienne Charles, Folklore album, this is a story of a young boy who travels to the islands of Trinidad and Tobago, West Indies where his grandmother teaches him a lesson about balance in life. On this mystical Caribbean island, dreams, magic and reality fuse together as the little boy becomes entrapped by mythical characters: Soucouyant, Dwen, La Diablesse, Papa Bois, Lagahoo and Mama D’lo. He must fight his way out of this haunting paradise to make it home alive. With the use of carnival costuming and visual film images of the islands of Trinidad and Tobago, this show will excite your entire family and celebrate the historical folkloric legacy of Trinidad and Tobago. Visit us: www.callalootheplay.com

The Callaloo Creative Team:

Written by: Marjuan Canady
Starring Marjuan Canady & Vanessa Evans
Directed by: Natalie Carter
Music by: Etienne Charles

Choreography by: Maresa D’Amore Morrison

Costuming by: Winston Black 

Cinematography by: Shadae Lamar Smith
Sound by: Devin Parker
Graphic Design by: Annysa Lamantia
Executive Producer: Carol Jagdeo

story:
Final Savage Land 

Final Savage Land is the most recent full-length installation/performance work created by Toronto based company Sore for Punching You - Artistic Director, Allison Cummings

The piece premiered in January 2013 at Oz Studios in Toronto and was met with much excitement and critical acclaim. Yay! Our hard work up to that point certainly seemed to have paid off.

The piece is a macabre yet humourous look at survival through co-dependancy and explores the complicated relationship between the simultaneous brutality and beauty of nature.

Here are a couple of press quotes!

"I was never quite sure what was going to happen but I was excited to get to be there for it." -Mooney on Theatre

"the proceedings are wrapped in layers of metaphor and control" - NOW magazine

Shortly after our run, we were approached by the Summerworks festival and invited to be presented as an off-site piece. What a great opportunity to be able to ride the wave and remount the work so closely after its premiere!

Being included in this popular festival will open up the show to a broader audience, giving it the chance to be seen by some peeps who may be able to help expand the life. This is a rare thing in hybrid performance work and an opportunity we cannot refuse! Another great perk to this is that because of limited seating in the first run, many a would be patron were not able to see the show....now, they can. Whoop!

Why we need to raise funds

Here's the deal with why we need to campaign.

SummerWorks has generously offered to provide some crucial elements for this remount, such as the cost of the space and front of house during the festival.

BUT, right at the moment, there are no Artist fees in place. The collaborators working on this project are absolutely hands-down exceptional. They have poured everything  into the making of this piece and need to be compensated appropriately.

The performing team is

Luke Garwood - Dancer/Performer

Linnea Swan - Dancer/Performer

Lyon Smith - Live Composition

Gabriel Cropley - Production Design / Live Lighting

-with the addition of Jolyane Langlois as Stage Manager/assistant and general all round go to gal for this production as I, Allison Cummings, will be giving birth around the same time as the festival. Eiyiyi.

All funds from this campaign raised will go directly to the above Artists. All other costs regarding the production such as publicity, bbq'd ducks etc. will be covered by hopeful box office intake.

If you choose to help us, you will be impacting the project in the following ways.

-You will be making a statement of the importance of hard-working talented artists being  properly compensated for their thoughts, skills and time.

-You will be supporting the work of Sore for Punching You, allowing the company to make progess towards a larger audience and potential longevity for this particular work.

-You will be saying YES to independant theatre production!

-You will be helping make sure these talented artists are paying their rent doing what they were put on this earth to do.

Other Ways You Can Help

We're smart cookies and are totally aware that not everyone who wants to support this show are able to so in a financial way.

If this is the case, there are other things you can do to help get the word out.

-You can reshare this campaign through all your preferred mediums, such as facebook and twitter.

-If you saw the show in its first run, you can talk it up big to all your friends and encourage them to help us out. You can also do this by guiding them towards the Sore for Punching You website at www.soreforpunchingyou.com where they can see more pictures of the piece and gather info on the team.

-You can be sure to come see the show at the SummerWorks Festival in Toronto from August 8-18th!!!

Thanks so much for reading!

Please Please Please help us remount this piece by giving the creatve team the integrity they deserve!

story:
Short Summary

  • Greetings, my name is Anton Engelbrecht, former Professional ballet dancer. In 2001 I lost 100% of my eyesight in the left hemi-field of both eyes, caused by a brain haemorrhage as a result of a spider bite.
    Despite doctors saying I would never walk or talk again,  two and half years later I performed again for the first time.
  • I travelled to the US in 2007 and 2009 to present master ballet classes and choreographed a production of The Nutcracker for a youth company in Ohio. 
  •  I am determined to perform on stage again and after much research found the AXIS Dance Company in Oakland, California (a fully integrated dance company comprising  dancers with and without physical disabilities - www.axixdance.org)

  • I applied to attend their 2014 Summer Intensive as an avenue that will hopefully lead to performing with the company in the future. My application was successful and I have been awarded a full scholarship. (all costs except airfare and accommodation are covered) Attending this programme will open doors for future employment as a performing artist.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Airfare is currently quoted at ZAR 26000. At the current exchange rate I am asking for $3000, allowing for a small contingency should the price and or exchange rates fluctuate.

  • A further $1000 is needed for accommodations for the two weeks

  • With your assistance I will again reach the heights of Principal Dancer with a renowned company.

The Impact

  • My long term goal is to establish my own company – TRANSCEND - above and beyond the limits of a disability - for dancers with disabilities in South Africa, thus creating employment for fellow dancers in my home country. I want to show the world how the arts enrich lives first-hand,and share my passion for the performing arts as a unique bridge between able bodied and persons with disabilities. My sight may be impaired but my vision lacks nothing….

Other Ways You Can Help

I am open to accepting a host offer of accommodation. If you are able or know of someone willing to host a blind male and guide dog for the summer break in Oakland CA, please contact me.
I have passed USCIS clearance for an O visa (Alien with extraordinary ability). 

So please spread this by word of mouth or the share options on this site.

I thank you for your interest and may you be blessed by your blessing.

story:
Do you like scary…uh…musicals?  

Oh, hey!  My name is Dane Whitlock and I like to create stuff.  Usually it's live theatrical productions - mashups of various pop culture mainstays to create something original, hilarious and thoroughly satisfying.

My recent runaway hit productions of "Are You There God? It's Me Karen Carpenter" and "(Little House on the) Prairie-oke!" played to packed houses in various theatres in both Los Angeles and Palm Springs and now I'm gearing up for my next endeavor - 

With my brilliant writing partner Amy Procacci and my fabulous choreographer Joseph Corella, we are slated to go into rehearsals soon for a May premiere at the Cavern Club Celebrity Theatre in Silverlake and need YOUR help to make this happen!

What we have discovered with our previous productions is that our audience is part of our family and creative journey.  These shows, while highly successful, have been self produced on a shoestring budget. To take it to the next level (better sets, costumes, wigs, special effects), it just seems to be the right moment to get our fans involved so that we are serving up the most kick ass musical parody of the horror movies you loved from the 90's mashed up with the hits from the Disco Queen you loved from the 70's!

Wanna get involved?  Check out the various goodies we are offering (images below!) and support us if you can.  Also, help us spread the word!  As always, we are grateful for your generosity and hope to see you soon!

story:
Who We Are

*Miles Mandwelle, director/producer
*Sarah Summerwell, co/producer
*Nicole Green, Stage Manager
*Simoné Elizabeth Bart, assistant director
*Matthew Stephens, Music director
 *Sarah Whicker, costume designer
*Ben Demarest, lighting designer
*Ryan Pater, movement consultant
*Julie Edwards, Alexander Technique
*Catherine Diane Miller, dramaturg

CAST LIST!

ANDREA LYNN GREEN (Monica) 

ALEJANDRO LA ROSA (Toby)

ELEONORE THOMAS (Baba)

TANYA ROBERTS (Mrs. Gobineau)

ALISON TAYLOR CHEESEMAN (Mrs. Nolan) 

STEPHANIE GRAY (Baba Cover)

JOHN KOWNACKI (Mr. Gobineau)

HANNAH FUERST (Monica Cover)

Taksu Theatre Company was founded in December 2013 with a sold-out run of "The Ugly One" by Marius Von Mayenberg. Seeking to grow, we produced a Valentine's Day Cabaret, "Songs of Love, Songs of Disdain," hosted by cellist/performer Anthime Miller ("The Mountain" at CTNY). With "The Medium," we bridge the gap between story and audience in an immersive production at the West End Cabaret & Lounge.
story_txt:
Who We Are 
 *Miles Mandwelle, director/producer*Sarah Summerwell, co/producer*Nicole Green, Stage Manager*Simoné Elizabeth Bart, assistant director*Matthew Stephens, Music director *Sarah Whicker, costume designer*Ben Demarest, lighting designer*Ryan Pater, movement consultant*Julie Edwards, Alexander Technique*Catherine Diane Miller, dramaturgCAST LIST!ANDREA LYNN GREEN (Monica) ALEJANDRO LA ROSA (Toby)ELEONORE THOMAS (Baba)TANYA ROBERTS (Mrs. Gobineau)ALISON TAYLOR CHEESEMAN (Mrs. Nolan) STEPHANIE GRAY (Baba Cover)JOHN KOWNACKI (Mr. Gobineau)HANNAH FUERST (Monica Cover)Taksu Theatre Company was founded in December 2013 with a sold-out run of "The Ugly One" by Marius Von Mayenberg. Seeking to grow, we produced a Valentine's Day Cabaret, "Songs of Love, Songs of Disdain," hosted by cellist/performer Anthime Miller ("The Mountain" at CTNY). With "The Medium," we bridge the gap between story and audience in an immersive production at the West End Cabaret & Lounge.

story:
here is why you should do this:

we are SMC (shakespeare's motley crew), a not for profit chicago theatre company that has been telling shakespeare stories (and sometimes webster, dekker and middleton) since 1992.

we don't have any plans to change the world.  or revolutionize theatre.  or reveal FACTS the mainstream media won't tell you. 

we just want to do some kickass shakespeare in the park, pay our actors and buy liability insurance.  (so if that one kid trips on a sword we can pay for his broken toe...).

this is our second year performing Midsummer Mayhem.  last year our attendance was over 200 with four shows.  this year we have six shows and hope to double attendance.  all of this is free to the public.  and really really fun . 

help us keep shakespeare mayhem free and in winnemac park!


here is the plan:

  • 45 minutes of shakespeare:  celebrating things Weird, Fierce, Twisted, Tragic, Magic, Dizzy, Drunk.
  • 3 weekends in august:  august 9, 10, august 16, 17 and august 23, 24
  • winnemac park in chicago:  under the trees, under the stars
  • 8 actors, 1 director, 1 stage manager
  • 8 flashlights, 1 medievally laundry cart
  • FREE FREE FREE


here is where the money goes:

$400 for actors

$200 for director and stage manager

$900 for insurance (for that one kid's toe)


here is our website and some of the things we have done since 1992:

http://www.smcplays.org/


here are some other things:

  • come to the show!
  • tell people about us!
  • visit us as smcplays.org
  • like us on FB (smc plays)
  • follow us on twitter (smc plays)
  • give us flashlights!

story:
The Copenhagen International Choreography Competition aims to discover and promote the next generation of contemporary choreographers. 

Now in it’s 7th year, the competition has grown to be an internationally recognized event and one of the top competitions for contemporary dance in the world. During the past 6 years the competition has presented works by more than 60 choreographers from around the world and has helped launch the careers of many talented artists. 

A record 211 candidates from over 25 countries applied to this year's competition from which 10 finalists were selected. 

Much of our budget is covered by the generous support of Danish foundations that have made it possible for us to organize the competition for the past 6 years. However, this season we find ourselves needing an additional $15,000 to help visiting artists with accommodation, subsistence during their stay in Copenhagen and prize money. 

The 7th Copenhagen International Choreography Competition will be held in the Stærekassen Theater at 7:30pm Friday April 18th.On April 19th there will be a gala performance featuring this season’s winners alongside new works by past winners from Isreal, Spain and the USA. 

The event will be live streamed online for those outside Denmark who wish to watch the performances. 

A new production award has been added this year! The Royal Danish Ballet wishes to support the success of CICC by honoring one lucky choreographer with the “Royal Danish Ballet Production Award” giving the opportunity to choreograph a piece for the Royal Danish Ballet's upcoming 2014/15 season.

The 2014 panel of judges includes: Bryan Arias, 1st place winner 6th CICC, USA. Nikolaj Hübbe, Artistic Director of the Royal Danish Ballet, Denmark. Kathleen McNurney, Artistic Director of Tanz Luzerner Theater, Switzerland. Gabriel Smeets, Artistic Director of Cullberg Ballet, Sweden and Darrel Toulon, Artistic Director of Oper Graz Tanzkompanie, Austria

Finalists Include: Judith Argomaniz (Spain), Korhan Basaran (Turkey), Martin Harriague (France), Sebastian Kloborg (Denmark), Dimo Kirilov Milev (Bulgaria/France), Shumpei Nemoto (Japan), Shintaro Oue (Japan), Idan Sharabi (Israel), Francesco Vecchione (Italy), Nadav Zelner (Israel)

More Information available at: www.cph-icc.dk

Competition tickets: http://billetten.dk/event/42548

Gala tickets: http://billetten.dk/event/42549

story:
After the success of Medea we are now looking to produce After Miss Julie by Patrick Marber. Updated to being set on the eve of the scottish independance vote. In a country house. Celebrations for the Labour Party's victory are in full swing. The lady of the house, Miss Julie, descends into the servants kitchen to seek out John, her father's chauffeur. A passionate midsummer night turns to tregedy as they test the limits of their new freedom.

Your contributions will ensure first and foremost everyone involved is earning a living wage. Too often actors, directors, artist are asked to work for free. Starting from the very beginning your contributions will allow us to have a longer audition process allowing us to see people who may not usually be seen by directors in Scotland. It will allow us a decent rehearsal period, a full production and design team and allow us to market the play and get the word out to audiences.

story:
Who We Are:  

Jim Bunting Dance Company is a novelty jazz-based dance company working and performing in the greater Philadelphia area. Our mission is to celebrate the triumphant nature of the human spirit through the joy of dance. We believe that the human body and its incredible facility for expression is the ultimate tool for communication. Because of this belief, we strive to create movement that is simultaneously entertaining and thought-provoking. We operate from a philosophy of positive energy and collaboration which allows our artists the opportunity to showcase, nurture and expand their various talents and abilities. It is our ultimate goal to become a vibrant new addition to the already rich fabric of the Philly arts community.

What We Are Doing:

Our first full length production will be a lively and theatrical tribute to story-telling and mythology. Themes of conflict, growth and celebration underlay a performance style that is a nostalgic nod to "dance as entertainment". As all of our company dancers come from a wide variety of dance styles and backgrounds, the movement and choreography throughout the performance simultaneously combines and showcases all of these unique talents. Whether an audience member would like to appreciate the emotional and cultural themes within a particular piece or simply wants to enjoy positive, uplifting entertainment, this appropriate-for-all-ages performance will have it all! 

Why We Need Your Help:

As this is our premiere season, we are kindly asking that you help us reach our goal of funding our first production! We have secured a performance date and venue (Saturday, May 2nd at Drexel University's Mandell Theater) and are now faced with the task of raising the money needed to make the show go on! If you are able to help, please know that 100% of all donations received with be used for:

1.) Compensating our artists for their hard work

2.) Purchasing costumes to help make our characters come alive

3.) Marketing and promotional costs

Our dancers, director, collaborative artists and technical support have all been working extremely hard to make sure we put on a performance which showcases both our love of dance and our diverse community. A donation of any amount is appreciated no matter how large or how small!

story:
The Fire This Time Festival set the theatre world ablaze when we launched our programming 6 years ago at Horse Trade Theater.  Founded in 2009 as a platform for early career playwrights of African American and other African Diaspora playwrights, we grown exponentially year after year.  Here are just some of the things we have done as a theatre community:

-Produced noted playwrights such as Katori Hall (Olivier Award Winner, writer The Mountaintop); Dominique Morrisseau (2014 Kennedy Prize Winner, 2014 Sky Cooper Prize Winner, writer, Detroit '67 ); Marcus Gardley (writer, The House That Will Not Stand); Josh Wilder (2014 Jerome Fellow); Kevin R. Free (2014 Recipient of the Doric A. Wilson Independent Playwright Award) - among many others.

-Won the NYTheatre.com's 2013 "Person of the Year" and was inducted into Indie Theatre Hall of Fame

-Published all 5 years of The Fire This Time ten minute plays on Indie Theatre Now.

-Embarked on our first national tour to Boston's Hibernian Hall in 2014, playing to sold out audiences.

-Produced the workshop productions of 3 new full-length plays, Pia Wilson's The Flower Thief, Camille Darby's Lord's Resistance, and this year, Nathan Yungerberg's Pousada Azul.

-Have been awarded numerous grants from The Lower Manhattan Cultural Council

-Have been featured in NYtimes, The Boston Globe, American Theatre Magazine, and were listed by CBS as one of the best things to do in NYC.

-Provided pay and opportunities outside of the ten minute showcase for all artists involved in the festival.


The success of The Fire This Time could not have happened without your support.  When you donate you are supporting the voices of artists that may not otherwise be heard in the larger conversation of our society.

story:
SCHIZO: The Story

Photo credit: Pat Moran

"Since you ask, most days I cannot remember.
I walk in my clothes, unmarked by that voyage, 
Then the almost unnameable lust returns." 

-Anne Sexton, "Wanting to Die"

Schizophrenia doesn’t only live in the mind; it pervades every aspect of reality. My younger brother was diagnosed with schizophrenia at age 11, a mental disorder that usually presents itself in early adulthood. For this 11-year-old and his family, schizophrenia became a waking nightmare. Between hospital stints and balancing medications, high school and every day life, my brother strove to maintain some semblance of normalcy. From the outside, few could suspect the daily internal chaos he was working so hard to handle and hide. 

SCHIZO, an original solo performance, provides an insight into the normalcy and mundanity of that life as my little brother battled the chaos in his mind. This show, part documentary and part movement-based theatre will include simulated auditory hallucinations, songs, poetry, and movement-based representations of the disorder. 

My brother continues to live with schizophrenia, but he does live. This show will stand as a testament to his strength, while providing a glimpse into what I saw him experience. Whether you have a schizophrenic family member, a bipolar friend, or if you are living with anxiety or depression, these stories deserve to be shared.  

Read a preview of the show featured in The Oregonian: Click here. 

"Watkins is an excellent physical performer, her movements as precise and expressive as a dancer." - Jonathan Frochtzwajg, The Oregonian

"...affecting, expressionistic... haunting, thoughtful... Watkins is a captivating performer." - Leela Ginelle, PQ Monthly

"[Watkins's] short but provocative performance proves an effective vehicle for illustrating a topic that is often ignored." - Penelope Bass, Willamette Week

"Through this short, but powerful piece, she is able to express in often non-verbal and non-linear ways, the struggles of an individual attempting to deal with the 'windmills of the mind.'" - Dennis Sparks, Dennis Sparks Reviews

Tickets can be found here: schizo.brownpapertickets.com

Photo credit: Pat Moran

Yeah... But Why??

I’ve had numerous conversations with family and friends who either live with schizophrenia or share lives with those who do. It is clear that there is a need to examine and share these stories. Recently, a friend whose father is living with schizophrenia sent me this message:

"I had to commit my dad to a hospital again last Tuesday. Your piece and your experience with your brother helped rekindle a perspective and inspiration that I think I had lost. Thank you for unearthing beauty from that kind of pain. More than a support group or counselor, it gives this experience benevolent gravity." 

It has never been clearer to me that I have to create this show; If not for me, for others who go through similar life experiences. Each performance will be followed by a talkback, allowing the audience to ask questions and begin a dialogue about the events they have just witnessed and their own experiences with mental health disorders and the stigmas these disorders bear. 

Who Am I?

I'm Katie Watkins. I've been a theatre artist in Portland, OR, since 2011, creating, performing, directing, and helping to produce theatre and contemporary performance. For years, I have been unable to shake this particular story from my mind and body. I watched my little brother go through this as a child while I was a child myself. I never gave myself the time or space to really process what happened to him. This show is the culmination of over two years of work. I'm so thrilled to finally share it. 

Following this premiere, I hope to tour this show to schools, hospitals, and mental health organizations; Throughout the spring, a 13-minute version of this piece toured to Portland-area schools and youth organizations through Portland Playhouse's Mind Over Matter education program (pictured below).


Mind Over Matter tour. Photo credit: Nikki Weaver

Where Will Your Money Go?

This project is being produced in part with the generous contribution of a grant from the Regional Arts and Culture Council. However, this grant will only cover a portion of the production budget. That’s where you come in! 

What will your contribution pay for?

  • Scenic elements for the show (wood for building the set, labor costs)
  • Lighting equipment (lamps - lots of lamps, and lots of light bulbs!)
  • Artist fees (for the director, designers, and technicians)
  • Marketing costs (promotional images, postcards, archival video)

With your generous contribution, SCHIZO will be a fully realized, immersive experience. Funds over the amount needed to produce SCHIZO will go towards future touring costs to schools, universities, and youth organizations following the August run of the show. Thank you so much for your contribution to SCHIZO and for supporting new work.


SCHIZO in rehearsal. Photo credit: Jeph Norman Fox

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have the means to contribute financially, don't worry! Here are some other ways you can help: 

  • Make noise! Share this campaign on Facebook, or whatever social media outlet you prefer. 
  • Donate any old lamps you may have, with or without lampshades (table, floor, small, big, hanging). I need SO MANY! 
  • Send me a message (katie@katiewatkinspdx.com) if you would like to volunteer at set builds, strikes, etc. 
  • Share your experiences with me! I'm always open to hearing what you have to say, particularly if this is a topic that intrigues or speaks to you on a personal level. 
Thank you again. And see you at the show! 

SCHIZO
Premiering August 14-29, 2015 
Shaking the Tree Theatre & Studio
823 SE Grant St, Portland OR 97214
Shaking the Tree Theatre
www.katiewatkinspdx.com
