story:
Stage Against the Machine is a super-group of artists, brought together to save Los Angeles theatre-goers from the villain known as complacency.  We have been acting and writing together for over a decade and are ready to create the much needed space for LA audiences to be ravaged, ruined, entertained and amazed. SAtM was created by renegade artists who believe they can raise the bar on the LA theater scene. In a town this awesome, good theater (accessible and satisfying) should be easier to come by!!

We're using this campaign to raise seed money for our Non-Profit Theater Company (SAtM). We need $25,000 to get started on our mission of bringing excellent live theater experiences to the good people of the Southland. Your contribution can help us become a beacon of hope for weary LA theater-goers and establish a place of freedom for our artists to share fantastic work!

This fundraising platform will empower us to:

  • Secure the rights to our 1st plays
  • Pay for Marketing and PR
  • Pay venue fees
  • Pay Actors
  • Pay  Directors
  • Secure Non-Profit status

We at Stage Against the Machine are committed to paying the talent who work for us!! (Actors will start at $30 a show and be promised an average of 18 shows.)

This campaign is just the beginning for Stage Against the Machine! We will be applying for government grants, teaming up with other non-profits (like LA River Project and City of Hope :-), and raising lots of money all over So Cal this summer. So stay tuned! If you liked our campaign video, there's plenty more shameless, self-promotional hilarity where that came from. And if you've donated anything to our campaign you will automatically be notified whenever we make a new brilliant piece of art!

In addition to $$, spreading the word about us helps So Much! Please use the Indiegogo share tools to make some noise about Stage Against the Machine!!

THANK YOU!

(Actors will start at $30 a show and be promised an average of 18 shows.)This campaign is just the beginning for Stage Against the Machine! We will be applying for government grants, teaming up with other non-profits (like LA River Project and City of Hope :-), and raising lots of money all over So Cal this summer. So stay tuned! If you liked our campaign video, there's plenty more shameless, self-promotional hilarity where that came from. And if you've donated anything to our campaign you will automatically be notified whenever we make a new brilliant piece of art!In addition to $$, spreading the word about us helps So Much! Please use the Indiegogo share tools to make some noise about Stage Against the Machine!!THANK YOU!

story:
Dear Friends, Family, and Supporters of Sylvani,

Sylvani is so grateful for all your ongoing support, and some of you are now clicking on this campaign after receiving an update from me. 

We have been truly touched by the way Sylvani has been supported to continue her training for a career in dance, as this is very expensive training I simply cannot afford to fully provide on my own. With your help, we are a community raising a touching and beautiful dancer who truly gives her soul on the stage, and wants to use dance to share her message with the world. 

Thank you! 

Last year, you helped send Sylvani to Joffrey Ballet, where she hopes to dance professionally one day. It was an incredible experience for her to dance in the Joffrey Tower, meet the Artistic Director, be in Chicago, and really be immersed in the caliber of dance that she not only aspires to, but that they apparently believe she has a chance at achieving!  

This year, at age 17, she has decided, very wisely and maturely, rather than return immediately to Joffrey--though she did audition and was accepted in a very competitive process--it would be better for her to develop her skill more finely tuned in the smaller program at Oregon Ballet Theater. OBT is just a couple hours from our home, in Portland, OR, and is an up and coming excellent company with an Artistic Director who loves to take pre-professional students and bring them up through the ranks into the company!  Sylvani learned, in OBT's top level last summer for a short 2-week intensive, that if she dances there for 4-6 weeks, she will be considered for OBT2, the second company that is often called on to dance with the main company in their larger productions, as well as having their own performance schedule! Sylvani feels that, with the smaller class size and more personal attention from truly excellent faculty, all of them also professional top dancers from OBT and around the world, and also the fact that she is placed in their highest level already, with company members at the barre alongside her taking class, THIS is the place to get that high level personal attention to truly "finish" her so that she can return to Joffrey in a year and really be ready for them! 

You have contributed to Sylvani in the past, and we ask you once again, please Help Sylvani Dance--this time to Oregon Ballet Theater, where she is nearly at the point of being that professional dancer she has always dreamed of, and where she will get the last things she needs to launch to Joffrey when she is 18! 

Here is the link to her new campaign: Help Sylvani Dance Towards Her Future!

Above All, Sylvani is a Dancer...and she Dreams

"Dancer" -- It's simply who she is. Sylvani is always dancing. When Sylvani is onstage, something flows out of her that is so true, so intrinsically "her", that people watching catch her spark, and can't take their eyes off her. People who don't even know her have come up to her after a performance to tell her that SHE is what they come to ballet for-her energy, her passion, and yes, her transparent beauty. Whether it's classical ballet, comical, theatrical, or especially contemporary, when Sylvani dances, she gives herself to you.  

 "If someone asks you “where does the universe end?” it goes on forever. Dancing is the same thing. Dancing is very cosmic. People pray by dancing in some religions. For me, dancing is my religion. It’s needed for life.  It’s not that I wouldn’t survive without it, it’s that I couldn’t live without it. " -Sylvani

                      

Dreaming of Dancing All Summer...

The Synopsis:

Sylvani has auditioned for, and been accepted to, several summer ballet intensives designed for young aspiring pre-professional dancers. After careful consideration, Sylvani has chosen Texas Ballet Theater's 5-week intensive as her next important step. TBT has offered her a 90% tuition scholarship! That is so rare for girls, as ballet's scholarships are often saved for boys. This indicates that the program's Principal, Ms. Kathryn Warakomsky, believes in Sylvani's potential. 

But even with 90% of the tuition covered, there are still many expenses, including Room and Board, travel from Eugene, Oregon to Dallas/Ft. Worth, additional fees, several pairs of pointe shoes, etc. We have very limited means, and Sylvani needs your help to fulfill her dream!

We are asking you to help us reach our goal of $4200, which would Help Sylvani Dance!

                                                                                        Ladies and Gentlemen, the Full Ballet...

  • What is the Dream?
  • Where did it Come From?
  • What is an Intensive?
  • Why is it Important?
  • Why Texas Ballet Theater?
  • What can You Do?
  • What will Sylvani Give back?.

Please, read on...Our Story:

Dreams DO come true!

When Sylvani was 3, she saw "The Nutcracker" and dreamed of being the Sugar Plum Fairy.  Her grandma (a dancer herself) and grandpa said they'd pay for ballet lessons...they didn't know what they were getting into!  So many little girls start ballet lessons with big dreams of wearing tutus and being a ballerina...and then move on to other things. 

                              

For a few, though, the dance goes on...Sylvani has never waivered. She has trained at one of the top academies in Eugene, OR, for 11 years--now she's nearly 15 years old and dances most days, up to 20 hours, every week, after school and on weekends. We don't push her...SHE pushes US! And this past holiday season, her first dance dream came true...Sylvani was one of three in a triple cast in her ballet studio's production of "The Nutcracker" to dance the Sugar Plum Fairy! 

       

Dreaming Bigger!

There is so much farther to go! Sylvani's dream is to have a ballet career, and many people who know the dance world have told her she has that potential. She's been told she has "it"--a special combination of dance talent and ability, musicality, stage presence, work ethic, passion, even her beautiful Romanian look. She wants to make a difference, have a voice. She comes from a deep place of thinking about her world. Sylvani has much to say to the world through dance.

                                    

The Biggest Dream of All

When she was 6, Sylvani announced that she was going to be a professional ballet dancer. She has grown a long way since that conversation, through aching muscles, blistered toes, long hours, and "costume malfunctions", and once in awhile, I ask her if she still wants this. She says "of course". 

"If you love something so much, you want to be able to share it. Being a professional provides the opportunity to share it with as many people as possible. They always say not to bring your outside drama into a performance, but that’s not completely true. You can harness your feelings onstage and that’s what makes a performer truly wonderful to watch. What an intensive can do is teach you how to get the technique down and into your memory as natural movements. To be a professional means you have these techniques down, so you can then show your emotions instead of worrying about your technique.  The technique of ballet isn’t natural movements...but we want to be able to push the limits, and that opens you up to any movement you feel."  --Sylvani

Pre-professional Training-Summer Intensive

Training to be a professional dancer is all year long. There is no summer "off". Sylvani gets her foundation in her home studio here in Eugene, with her primary teachers. But there is always something else competing--school, homework, family obligations, friends who she wants to spend time with, but who don't dance. 

Summer intensives are essential. Each summer, many ballet companies and top training programs around the world offer 2-6 week intensives for serious students wishing to improve their form, round out their training, and maybe find their way into a company one day. This really is necessary in today's world, if you wish to go professional. It is not a "summer camp", but important training. Students who attend these gain so much from taking class all day, every day, for several weeks with other serious ballet students. They are exposed to other ballet styles, other types of training, gain physical strength, learn their limits and how to push through them, make contacts in the dance world that can last a lifetime, get seen by professionals who can help them later, and get a rare opportunity to just spend time with others who live, eat, and breathe--DANCE!!!

"You get more exposure, you get more technique, the more practice you get--more teachers, more time in the studio. Summer intensives are unique because everyone in the world is different and everyone can teach you different things--not just technique, which is important, but also sharing their personal stories of what they used, what emotions they harnessed" --Sylvani

Audition tours are held all over the country, with often over a thousand students auditioning for each intensive--and maybe a tenth chosen in this selective process. This year, Sylvani auditioned for Texas Ballet Theater, Boston Ballet Theatre, Oregon Ballet Theatre, and Whitman Summer Dance Lab at in-person auditions. We also created a video audition for Joffrey Ballet Company, as we could not make it to a live audition, and Sylvani dreams of dancing with Joffrey one day. Sylvani was accepted to every one of the intensives she auditioned for and offered partial scholarships to three of them! 

Where She's Been--Whitman Summer Dance Lab--and YOU took her there!

For the past two years, Sylvani has attended Whitman Summer Dance Lab in Walla Walla, WA. This has been a wonderful experience for her! She gained so much, the faculty coming from all over, and with many dance styles, she was exposed to many methods of teaching, and many new people in the dance world. Sylvani came back more confident, stronger, and much improved in her level of technique and maturity as a dancer.

She was honored to be chosen by audition for an "extra" apprenticeship with ODC Dance of San Francisco a professional modern dance company the directors of SDL brought in for their end of summer Walla Walla Dance Festival! ODC chose 10 of the SDL students to have a new work choreographed on them, which they performed in the festival alongside three professional companies.

Sylvani's experiences at Summer Dance Lab the past two summers have been wonderful. She gained new dance experience, made lifelong connections in the dance world, and found herself not only capable of dancing 8 hours a day, every day, but LOVING it! 

Summer Dance Lab loved her, too...and has offered her a merit tuition scholarship if she returns, but Sylvani feels it's time to branch out and see what other intensives have to offer. 

Next Dance Step? Texas Ballet Theater!

The decision process has been difficult..After much consideration, Sylvani has chosen Texas Ballet Theater, where she feels she will get lots of personal attention, and which is so highly recommended by her teacher here, for her next step. She feels this is exactly what she needs at this point in her training. 

Texas Ballet Theater Dallas, has been led by Artistic Director, Ben Stevenson since 2003, after he brought Houston Ballet to international renown in the 80's and 90's. Kathryn Warakomsky TBT's School and Summer Program Principal, and Li Anlin, TBT's Assistant Artistic Director, both former Principals with Houston Ballet, have taught Sylvani as guest faculty here at ballet academy. 

Both are excellent teachers and Sylvani looks forward to learning more from them. She hopes to take class with Ben Stevenson, who teaches the upper levels. All the faculty are or have been dancers, often principals, with TBT or Houston Ballet, or both. Sylvani's primary teacher recommends TBT's program for it's training. Texas Ballet Theater first offered Sylvani a 50% tuition merit scholarship! It is rare for scholarships to be offered to girls, as they are usually reserved for boys to try to increase the balance of male dancers. Then Ms. Warakomsky, learning of our financial challenges, offered another 40% off tuition! A total of 90% tuition scholarship!!! 

That is like saying to her "We believe you have potential"!

What Got Her to This "Pointe"?

Two years ago, we came to you, our community of friends, family, and performing artists. Sylvani was 12, and had just been accepted to her very first summer intensives. We needed help and you ALL pooled your resources with ours and together, we got her to Summer Dance Lab for their two-week intensive!

See the story and remind yourself how great you were by checking out "Help Sylvani Dance"  here.

                             

Because you were so active, contributing and sharing Sylvani's campaign, you also helped an "'angel" sponsor find Sylvani...who gave her the rest of what she needed that year, covered her return to Whitman Summer Dance Lab for their 5-week program last year,  and helped with many other expenses we've had for her!

We don't know what we would have done without him, and more...he has become a friend, though we've never met in person. We exchanged many emails, and he was always very encouraging, telling us his family's story of hardship, loss, and then great fortune. He believes in family and wanted to "pay it forward" to help others with dreams who couldn't make it on their own resources.

But something has happened...It has been nearly 4 months since we have heard from him. We are very worried...it is not like him to simply stop communicating, as he has many times expressed that he would never "let a kid down". We are afraid something must have happened to him, and he is in our prayers and thoughts every day.  So, in addition to great worry and care about him, we also must quickly raise the funds for her to go to her intensive.

Sylvani needs you!

Our Biggest Challenge...$$$

Sylvani has the attention of TBT.  They are offering her a 90% tuition scholarship, but her dream still hangs in the balance...there are still significant costs for room and board, travel, and dance shoes/clothing she will need for dancing all day every day for 5 weeks. 

My job as a full-time enrollment services/financial aid advisor at our local community college barely supports our family, and two of our family members have disabling conditions with high medical costs I also manage. Sylvani's older sister is in college, on full scholarship, but there are ways I support her as well. 

Sylvani's grandparents, my wonderful mom and dad, love ballet and dance of all forms, and have paid for Sylvani's year-round ballet lessons. They will continue to do so, but cannot do more, as my father is hoping to retire in a few years (he is 75). 

Sylvani has worked so hard to achieve her dream and shows so much promise! Dance is the most important thing in her life. I don't want to see her miss this chance because I am unable to afford it. 

So, we are turning to you, our friends and family, patrons of dance and the performing arts, and supporters of dreams of all kinds!

The Goal=$4200

All money contributed will go towards Sylvani's needs this summer. Though the actual costs add up to over $4470, we have set our goal lower to make it easier to reach. 

  • Remaining tuition = $195(after $975 merit scholarship and $780 additional aid)
  • Room and Board = $2200
  • Staff/Activities Fee=$275
  • Airfare = $800 (I take Sylvani there, she flies back alone. If we raise more, her dad and I could go see the performance at the end and bring her back)
  • Car rental =$200
  • Airbnb room= $200 (for two days prior to beginning of program, check-in day, and a day for me to help her get settled)
  • 4-5 pairs of pointe shoes ($60-90 each), 4-5 new leotards ($25-40 each), 5 pairs of tights ($20 each) = $600 or more

There will be so many incidental expenses, and if we reach more than our goal, it will be put in a dedicated fund for later dance costs. All will go to Sylvani's dance education! (If we don't meet the goal, all money contributed will go to smaller programs closer to home)

What You Get...So Much Gratitude!

Think how wonderful you will feel when you see Sylvani onstage one day and you helped her get there! 

                                      

And Sylvani offers a bit of herself back to you! 

Any contribution is a "Step in her Dance", so she and we are grateful for any help you can give.  If 850 of our Facebook friends give Sylvani $5 each, she's on her way!  And you receive a personalized "Thank you!" on Facebook and a smile that lasts all week!

If you contribute $15-$29, Sylvani will write you a beautiful "Thank you" card by hand, expressing how much this means to her.

When Sylvani danced for her godfather and godmother's wedding, their photographer, Roots, took this beautiful photo of her. Sylvani's Uncle Lawrence, a graphic designer, made it into an 11"x17" poster. (Printing services donated by Premier Press, in Portland, OR). 

This perk was one of the favorites from Sylvani's campaign two years ago, and we have a limited edition of only 58 of these left! 

If you contribute $30-$49, Sylvani will send you one of these signed by her...a future star!

When Sylvani danced in "The Nutcracker" this past fall, we were allowed to take the costume for a photo shoot with Tiffany Grey of Mamalove Photography. Tiffany has a special connection with Sylvani, and got so many beautiful shots! 

If you contribute $50-$99, Sylvani will send your choice of one of these beautiful photos signed by her! You can see all of them on her "gallery" page.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               

One of the things Sylvani is very good at, and has received training in, is choreography...she would love to choreograph something just for you!  

Two years ago, after she came back from her first Summer Dance Lab intensive, Sylvani choreographed this to say "Thank You!" for all the contributors from the Oregon Country Fair..she performed this at "The Midnight Show"--imagine what she might choreograph for you after this summer at Texas Ballet Theater!


If you contribute $100 or more, Sylvani will choreograph for you...1 minute for $100 (well, a minute and a half), 2 minutes for $200, 3 minutes for $300, 4 minutes for $400, and 5 minutes for $500!  You choose the style...the music. We will video it for you, and send you either a Youtube link or a DVD!  For this perk, Sylvani will want to wait until after her intensive, so she has all the training you helped provide...so these will begin in August. 


The Impact- Making a Dancer! 

Sylvani has so much to give the world...and YOUR voice can be part of that. Sylvani's dream, like anyone's needs nurturing to grow into a reality.  Even a small contribution can add up like individual steps--hundreds of them--make a dance, and eventually an entire ballet! 

                                                                           

Other Ways You Can Help

We know there may not be money in your pocket right now. We ask that you consider just $5 to help Sylvani--because truly, if every one of our friends and family contributed just $5, she would have all she needs!  

But if you simply cannot right now, there are other ways you can be part of the "Help Sylvani Dance" team, and we will appreciate it so much!

A campaign like this is only as good as it's sharing--Let's make Sylvani go viral!

Share with EVERYONE you can think of--and Share OFTEN!!!  If you use the sharing tools at the top of the page, once a day, letting everyone know how much you support Sylvani, that will really help!  Indiegogo uses it's "GoGo Factor" to determine who gets to be on the home page, and at the top of the searches for different categories. That is how Sylvani's "angel sponsor" found her and that impacted a whole year!

Airfare Frequent Flyer Miles:

If you don't have money, but you DO have frequent flyer miles you could donate, please let us know here on the "Comments" section. We need round-trip tickets to get Sylvani there and back, and to get me there and back at the beginning to settle her in.  Even better would be if we had two more round-trip tickets for her Daddy and I to be able to go at the end and see the performance she will do! 

We have a special perk for donated air miles--a DVD of the final showcase performance plus a signed photograph! 

Thank you. --Sylvani and Fiora

She gained new dance experience, made lifelong connections in the dance world, and found herself not only capable of dancing 8 hours a day, every day, but LOVING it! Summer Dance Lab loved her, too...and has offered her a merit tuition scholarship if she returns, but Sylvani feels it's time to branch out and see what other intensives have to offer. Next Dance Step? Texas Ballet Theater!The decision process has been difficult..After much consideration, Sylvani has chosen Texas Ballet Theater, where she feels she will get lots of personal attention, and which is so highly recommended by her teacher here, for her next step. She feels this is exactly what she needs at this point in her training. Texas Ballet Theater Dallas, has been led by Artistic Director, Ben Stevenson since 2003, after he brought Houston Ballet to international renown in the 80's and 90's. Kathryn Warakomsky TBT's School and Summer Program Principal, and Li Anlin, TBT's Assistant Artistic Director, both former Principals with Houston Ballet, have taught Sylvani as guest faculty here at ballet academy. Both are excellent teachers and Sylvani looks forward to learning more from them. She hopes to take class with Ben Stevenson, who teaches the upper levels. All the faculty are or have been dancers, often principals, with TBT or Houston Ballet, or both. Sylvani's primary teacher recommends TBT's program for it's training. Texas Ballet Theater first offered Sylvani a 50% tuition merit scholarship! It is rare for scholarships to be offered to girls, as they are usually reserved for boys to try to increase the balance of male dancers. Then Ms. Warakomsky, learning of our financial challenges, offered another 40% off tuition! A total of 90% tuition scholarship!!! That is like saying to her "We believe you have potential"!What Got Her to This "Pointe"?Two years ago, we came to you, our community of friends, family, and performing artists. Sylvani was 12, and had just been accepted to her very first summer intensives. We needed help and you ALL pooled your resources with ours and together, we got her to Summer Dance Lab for their two-week intensive!See the story and remind yourself how great you were by checking out "Help Sylvani Dance"  here.                             Because you were so active, contributing and sharing Sylvani's campaign, you also helped an "'angel" sponsor find Sylvani...who gave her the rest of what she needed that year, covered her return to Whitman Summer Dance Lab for their 5-week program last year,  and helped with many other expenses we've had for her!We don't know what we would have done without him, and more...he has become a friend, though we've never met in person. We exchanged many emails, and he was always very encouraging, telling us his family's story of hardship, loss, and then great fortune. He believes in family and wanted to "pay it forward" to help others with dreams who couldn't make it on their own resources.But something has happened...It has been nearly 4 months since we have heard from him. We are very worried...it is not like him to simply stop communicating, as he has many times expressed that he would never "let a kid down". We are afraid something must have happened to him, and he is in our prayers and thoughts every day.  So, in addition to great worry and care about him, we also must quickly raise the funds for her to go to her intensive.Sylvani needs you!Our Biggest Challenge...$$$Sylvani has the attention of TBT.  They are offering her a 90% tuition scholarship, but her dream still hangs in the balance...there are still significant costs for room and board, travel, and dance shoes/clothing she will need for dancing all day every day for 5 weeks. My job as a full-time enrollment services/financial aid advisor at our local community college barely supports our family, and two of our family members have disabling conditions with high medical costs I also manage. Sylvani's older sister is in college, on full scholarship, but there are ways I support her as well. Sylvani's grandparents, my wonderful mom and dad, love ballet and dance of all forms, and have paid for Sylvani's year-round ballet lessons. They will continue to do so, but cannot do more, as my father is hoping to retire in a few years (he is 75). Sylvani has worked so hard to achieve her dream and shows so much promise! Dance is the most important thing in her life. I don't want to see her miss this chance because I am unable to afford it. So, we are turning to you, our friends and family, patrons of dance and the performing arts, and supporters of dreams of all kinds!The Goal=$4200All money contributed will go towards Sylvani's needs this summer. Though the actual costs add up to over $4470, we have set our goal lower to make it easier to reach. 
Remaining tuition = $195(after $975 merit scholarship and $780 additional aid)
Room and Board = $2200
Staff/Activities Fee=$275
Airfare = $800 (I take Sylvani there, she flies back alone. If we raise more, her dad and I could go see the performance at the end and bring her back)
Car rental =$200
Airbnb room= $200 (for two days prior to beginning of program, check-in day, and a day for me to help her get settled)
4-5 pairs of pointe shoes ($60-90 each), 4-5 new leotards ($25-40 each), 5 pairs of tights ($20 each) = $600 or more
There will be so many incidental expenses, and if we reach more than our goal, it will be put in a dedicated fund for later dance costs. All will go to Sylvani's dance education! (If we don't meet the goal, all money contributed will go to smaller programs closer to home)What You Get...So Much Gratitude!Think how wonderful you will feel when you see Sylvani onstage one day and you helped her get there! 
                                      And Sylvani offers a bit of herself back to you! Any contribution is a "Step in her Dance", so she and we are grateful for any help you can give.  If 850 of our Facebook friends give Sylvani $5 each, she's on her way!  And you receive a personalized "Thank you!" on Facebook and a smile that lasts all week!If you contribute $15-$29, Sylvani will write you a beautiful "Thank you" card by hand, expressing how much this means to her.When Sylvani danced for her godfather and godmother's wedding, their photographer, Roots, took this beautiful photo of her. Sylvani's Uncle Lawrence, a graphic designer, made it into an 11"x17" poster. (Printing services donated by Premier Press, in Portland, OR). This perk was one of the favorites from Sylvani's campaign two years ago, and we have a limited edition of only 58 of these left! If you contribute $30-$49, Sylvani will send you one of these signed by her...a future star!When Sylvani danced in "The Nutcracker" this past fall, we were allowed to take the costume for a photo shoot with Tiffany Grey of Mamalove Photography. Tiffany has a special connection with Sylvani, and got so many beautiful shots! If you contribute $50-$99, Sylvani will send your choice of one of these beautiful photos signed by her! You can see all of them on her "gallery" page.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               One of the things Sylvani is very good at, and has received training in, is choreography...she would love to choreograph something just for you!  Two years ago, after she came back from her first Summer Dance Lab intensive, Sylvani choreographed this to say "Thank You!" for all the contributors from the Oregon Country Fair..she performed this at "The Midnight Show"--imagine what she might choreograph for you after this summer at Texas Ballet Theater!If you contribute $100 or more, Sylvani will choreograph for you...1 minute for $100 (well, a minute and a half), 2 minutes for $200, 3 minutes for $300, 4 minutes for $400, and 5 minutes for $500!  You choose the style...the music. We will video it for you, and send you either a Youtube link or a DVD!  For this perk, Sylvani will want to wait until after her intensive, so she has all the training you helped provide...so these will begin in August. The Impact- Making a Dancer! Sylvani has so much to give the world...and YOUR voice can be part of that. Sylvani's dream, like anyone's needs nurturing to grow into a reality.  Even a small contribution can add up like individual steps--hundreds of them--make a dance, and eventually an entire ballet!                                                                            Other Ways You Can HelpWe know there may not be money in your pocket right now. We ask that you consider just $5 to help Sylvani--because truly, if every one of our friends and family contributed just $5, she would have all she needs!  But if you simply cannot right now, there are other ways you can be part of the "Help Sylvani Dance" team, and we will appreciate it so much!A campaign like this is only as good as it's sharing--Let's make Sylvani go viral!Share with EVERYONE you can think of--and Share OFTEN!!!  If you use the sharing tools at the top of the page, once a day, letting everyone know how much you support Sylvani, that will really help!  Indiegogo uses it's "GoGo Factor" to determine who gets to be on the home page, and at the top of the searches for different categories. That is how Sylvani's "angel sponsor" found her and that impacted a whole year!Airfare Frequent Flyer Miles:If you don't have money, but you DO have frequent flyer miles you could donate, please let us know here on the "Comments" section. We need round-trip tickets to get Sylvani there and back, and to get me there and back at the beginning to settle her in.  Even better would be if we had two more round-trip tickets for her Daddy and I to be able to go at the end and see the performance she will do! We have a special perk for donated air miles--a DVD of the final showcase performance plus a signed photograph! Thank you. --Sylvani and Fiora

story:
My name is Mariel Mitton and I am a Senior, Dance Performance major at the University of South Carolina. I have been accepted into the LINES Ballet summer program in San Francisco, California, which will take place this summer, July thru August. The program is for 5 weeks at the LINES Ballet facility and dancers train approximately 9 hours a day, with classes in a variety of styles including ballet, modern, pointe, improvisation, Gyrotonics, and LINES Ballet repertoire.  

Attending the LINES Ballet summer program has been a dream of mine since I was 11 years old when I was first introduced to the LINES Ballet repertoire. Now 10 years later I am determined to make this dream a reality. This program is not just like any other, it will push me farther to my potential and will give me opportunities to network and connect with dancers and faculty from all over the country. This prestigious program is connected to the professional ballet company, LINES Ballet, which is recognized as one of the leading contemporary ballet companies in the world. I feel honored to have been accepted and I am thrilled to take on this next adventure in my life!

Fundraising Goal:  $2,500

Tuition:         $2,500

I am raising money to pay for the tuition thru this campaign, but there are also the costs of travel and living to consider (approximately $2,000). For these other expenses I will be doing other forms of fundraising. The total expense of living in San Francisco and attending the program will be at least $4,500 total.

What am I doing to financially support myself?

As a full time student I pick up as many shifts as my schedule allows working as a server, and during the months of May and June I will be starting two more part time jobs.

The expense of this program is too great for my family to support me, but I am venturing out on my own and need some help getting started. I have supported myself during college thru dance and academic scholarships and doing part time work as a server, and teaching dance. After paying for tuition and rent, my paychecks go towards my food and pointe shoes. I live pretty frugally; anything leftover goes directly into my savings to help for my dance career.

After my acceptance into the program I was unfortunately denied any financial aid assistance. As soon as my friends heard of this they immediately began to plan multiple fundraisers such as selling flowers before spring dance recitals, a yard sale, and a bake sale. We are going to go thru with these other fundraisers, which will go towards the living and traveling expenses (approximately $2,000). I feel so blessed to have such supportive friends who know just how much attending this program means to me, and who gave me the courage to ask for help.


Why this program means so much to me:

Two of the critical components of being a dancer are technique and artistry. I have been training for 14 years to refine my technique, but now I need to find my own sense of self as an artist. The program at LINES Ballet has a different approach to dance, which provides a safe environment that encourages artistic risk-taking and independent thinking. One of the hardest parts about being a dancer is that there are a million of us out there. I need to discover what makes me unique and what I can contribute to the dance world. There are numerous technically proficient dancers in the world, but we need more dancers who are intelligent and able to articulate the importance of this art form. At the LINES Ballet summer program I will become stronger not only as a dancer, but more knowledgeable and fulfilled as a human being.

Exposing myself to various art forms and people has always been very important to me because I believe that it helps shape who I am as a person and as an artist. When I was 18 years old I broadened my scope as a dancer by learning ballroom dance styles and began teaching adults private lessons. As I worked with individual adults who had various motives for learning how to dance, I watched as they not only overcame their fears and insecurities of movement but also dealt with issues in their lives that had nothing to do with dance. These experiences reminded me that dance is able to reach everyone and influence all people; dance has the ability to break down barriers and limitations and set you free. My hope is to continue to discover myself as an artist so that I can help others do the same.

story:
Penguin Rep is a small theatre … with BIG dreams.

We produce new plays in Stony Point, NY that then find life beyond the walls of our intimate barn theatre -- on stages across the country and around the world, as movies and on TV.

For example, we originally presented Angelo Parra’s THE DEVIL’S MUSIC: THE LIFE & BLUES OF BESSIE SMITH, which moved to Off Broadway for more than a year and was nominated for Drama Desk, Lucille Lortel and Audelco Awards. Since then, thousands at the Montreal Jazz Festival and at theatres throughout the U.S. and Canada have enjoyed the show. Come this January, the show will hit the Seven Seas as featured entertainment on the Blues Cruise!

FINDING NEVERLAND, the movie (and upcoming Broadway musical), is based on Allan Knee’s play THE MAN WHO WAS PETER PAN, which Penguin commissioned and premiered.

Since Penguin presented Tom Dudzick’s THE MIRACLE ON SOUTH DIVISION STREET in 2009, the play has been produced Off Broadway, in 20 states and Canada.

Other plays developed by Penguin that moved to NYC include Lee Blessing’s COBB (produced by Kevin Spacey at the Lucille Lortel), Karoline Leach’s TRYST (Promenade), Warren Leight’s GLIMMER GLIMMER AND SHINE (Manhattan Theater Club),  James Sherman’s FROM DOOR TO DOOR (Westside Theatre), Charles Smith’s FREED (59e59), and Richard Vetere’s ONE SHOT, ONE KILL (Primary Stages).

Now, we’re excited to announce that DROP DEAD PERFECT, the outrageous comedy starring the legendary Everett Quinton that premiered last summer, will be moving to Off Broadway’s Theatre at St. Clements starting July 15. www.dropdeadperfect.com

PLEASE HELP THE PENGUIN CONTINUE TO TAKE OFF.  Support our efforts to present exciting and thought-provoking new works and then see them take off -- to stages and screens far beyond our wildest dreams.

About Penguin Rep

Under the dynamic leadership of founding Artistic Director Joe Brancato and executive director Andrew M. Horn, Penguin Rep Theatre has grown in 35 years from a summer theatre in a converted 1880's hay to become one of the Hudson Valley's most influential nonprofit cultural institutions.

Founded in 1977, Penguin now reaches tens of thousands at its home theatre in Stony Point (Rockland County), New York, in New York City, and beyond.

Hailed by The New York Times as "the gutsiest little theatre" and by Lohud.com for its "wondrous productions", Penguin Rep is Rockland's only professional theatre employing members of Actors' Equity Association.

Over the years, Penguin Rep has produced nearly 150 celebrated shows  including premieres by such playwrights as: Warren Leight, Arthur Laurents James Sherman, Elizabeth Swados, Lee Blessing, William Mastrosimone , and Ronald Harwood, starring such artists as Celeste Holm, Andrew McCarthy, Robert Klein, Lainie Kazan, David Canary, Joy Behar, Tovah Feldshuh, Michele Pawk, Barbara Feldon, Regina Carter, Beth Fowler, Tony Award winner Karen Ziemba and Drama Desk Award winners Gregg Edelman and Jim Brochu. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Join the Penguin mailing list -- email your email and/or snail mail addresses to: info@penguinrep.org.
  • Find out more about Penguin Rep Theatre: www.penguinrep.org

story:
Who I Am:

My name is Samantha Zaddack and I am a junior BFA Theatre Performance major at the University of Wisconsin-Whitewater in Whitewater, WI. 

Theatre is my passion and I am striving to gain the best education possbile in this field before I become a professional theatre practicioner. William Shakespeare is my absolute favorite playwright and his works have inspired me in many ways to follow my dreams in being an actress. 

I have been accepted to study at Shakespeare's Globe in London, England this summer and this is the trip of a lifetime for a theatre student like myself.

What I Need:

I am trying to raise $3,000 in 30 days to help pay for some of my trips expenses:

  • airfare: $1,440
  • Globe Theatre Programs, room & board, and meal allowance: $5,495
As you can see, I am not asking for the entire cost to attend merely a portion to help make it reasonable. As a college student paying for her own schooling, this opportunity is difficult to afford but worth every penny in experience. 

What You Get:
  • Gratitude - $1 (and at all other levels!)
  • Thank you letter - $5
  • Personalized thank you letter - $20
  • T-shirt - $40
  • Handwritten postcard 4" x 6" - $50
  • Gift from London - $100

The Impact:

Your contribution will make a huge difference in the life of a very dedicated and determined student.

  • It can be very difficult for students in the Midwest to find opportunities in the fine arts fields. 
  • This is a chance of a lifetime to advance my education and gain worldly opportunities that I can carry with me the rest of my life. 
  • This trip has inspired me to always pursue my dreams because they can lead you to extraordinary places. 

Other Ways You Can Help:

Times are tough everywhere and I understand that you might not be able to make a financial contribution. You can still help! Please share my campaign in any way you can: Facebook, Twitter, and word of mouth are all very powerful tools!

story:
Who We Are

We are the Senior BFA Acting Class of 2015 at Elon University: 

Nick Cook, Ryan Cooper, Jenna Hokanson, Kimmi Johnson, Sam Walt Jones, Maggie Kittner, Mercer Linquist, Meg Machonis, Benedetto Michael Robinson, Ariadne Vickers-Davis, and Anna Weis

We are ready and enthusiastic to graduate this May and pursue careers in the entertainment industry...but we need your help!

Why We Are Fundraising 

In the entertainment world, networking is everything.

Over the last four years we have sharpened our abilities and skills in order to excel in our craft. With our acting toolboxes stocked, we are ready to start our journeys in the professional world.

In order to gain mobility, it is imperative for us to make connections with established professionals in the entertainment industry. So, we are raising money to bring Casting Directors and Agents from New York, Los Angeles, and elsewhere to Elon University!

All money will go towards necessary accommodations for the professionals including:

· Airfare

· Lodging

· And their TIME

Cumulatively, it costs about $2000 per professional we decide to bring to Elon.

We will take classes and work intimately with these people, as well as perform our showcase material for them, providing us an invaluable experience.

We have worked very hard to fundraise at Elon and continue to do so, but our cherished community is quite small. That’s why we are reaching out and asking for your help!

Impact

Any donation would make a huge impact in reaching our goal. Every cent matters!

If money is tight, no worries! Sharing this link on your Facebook and email with your friends, family, coworkers, etc. would help us out substantially.

Every person who sees this video helps us to get one step closer.

We all want to thank you for your time and donations.

We can’t wait until we can share we love to do with the rest of the world.


Sincerely,

The Elon BFA Acting Majors of 2015

· And their TIME
Cumulatively, it costs about $2000 per professional we decide to bring to Elon.
We will take classes and work intimately with these people, as well as perform our showcase material for them, providing us an invaluable experience.
We have worked very hard to fundraise at Elon and continue to do so, but our cherished community is quite small. That’s why we are reaching out and asking for your help!


Impact


Any donation would make a huge impact in reaching our goal. Every cent matters!
If money is tight, no worries! Sharing this link on your Facebook and email with your friends, family, coworkers, etc. would help us out substantially.
Every person who sees this video helps us to get one step closer.
We all want to thank you for your time and donations.
We can’t wait until we can share we love to do with the rest of the world.

Sincerely,
The Elon BFA Acting Majors of 2015

story:
Short Summary

Love British sitcoms and wish you could see them live in San Francisco? Well now you can as brought to you by the zany actors of the new Royal British Comedy Theatre. Our mission is to stage popular British TV and stage comedies starring American actors who relish speaking the Queen's English in Received Pronunciation. You will relish listening to them. We have begun an Indiegogo campaign in order to cover basic production costs, such as venue rental and actor pay. Your financial gifts will help us establish our new theater in the heart of San Francisco's Mission District in the charming Stage Werx black box. 

Foto: Jon Bauer (c) 2014 All Rights Reserved: Shown: Edina and Patsy

What We Need & What You Get

We are a troupe of actors and singers who have performed in the Bay Area for groups like The Cockettes, Thrillpeddlers, SF Gay Mens Chorus. We are led by veteran stage director Christian Heppinstall ...

Foto: Jon Bauer (c) 2014 All Rights Reserved: Shown: left is Christian Heppinstall whose ZsaZsa Lufthansa stars as Patsy Stone; with makeup artist Diego Gomez.

... whose English family hails from Yorkshire. We have an actual Brit in our cast playing Saffy. And we all love AbFab and really want you to. We are seeking $8,000 in start-up revenue to cover venue rental for the rehearsals and shows, cast and crew pay, costumes, wigs, props, printing of PR materials, etc. If we don't reach our entire goal we'll still spend your generous funds on the start-up cost

We are offering Zany Perks in recognition of your gracious donations. Want Gran to feed you like she did to Eddie? Buy her gift basket. Want to be Bubble? Have Raya Light make you over! Need your fortune told by the Great Chukhani? Want to dress like the Queen and sit in a Royal Box? Or how about get a massage while doing yoga just like Edina? Take a look at our full line of perks we guarantee will make you chortle and be chuffed you supported AbFab!

Our Funding Needs: The majority of our budgetary expenses cover venue rental then labor pay. Other major expenses include the advertising and marketing, but also costumes, wigs and makeup. Our world needs to laugh more so we think we can help and know we need your help to get us all laughing more.

Foto: Jon Bauer (c) 2014 All Rights Reserved: Shown: Gran (Annie Larson), Edina (Terry McLaughlin) & Saffy (Dene Larson)

The Impact

There is no theater in the Bay Area exclusively dedicated to staging the wackiness of Brit sitcoms, films and plays. Nor is there a theater in which actors are actually encouraged to speak in faux Brit accents (as American actors are all inclined to do anyway). Your gifts establish our comedy-laughter mission in San Francisco. So please help local actors free their IBC or Inner British Comic. 

Foto: Jon Bauer (c) 2014 All Rights Reserved: Shown: Patsy (ZsaZsa Lufthansa), Bubble (Raya Light) & Edina (Terry McLaughlin)

Risks & Challenges

While we realize that these financial hurdles can derail theater projects we are in the capable hands of Christian Heppinstall, who has a long record in the non-profit world as an executive director, marketing director, and producer. Our business plan utilizes relevant revenue streams to finance our start-up costs, such as advance ticket sales (via EventBrite; tickets go on sale soon) and direct sponsorship appeals. We also will market the show using live appearances at local events, such as the Castro Street Fair or other public events. Please share your fundraising and marketing ideas with us! Thank you!

    Other Ways You Can Help

    While we realize that not everybody can donate funds we are seeking in-kind donations, or donations of services. We also ask that you use the Indiegogo Share Tools to spread the word which helps to sell tickets.

    Foto: Jon Bauer (c) 2014 All Rights Reserved: Shown:  Patsy (ZsaZsa Lufthansa) & Edina (Terry McLaughlin)

    About our Shows:

    SF’s newest theater—Royal British Comedy Theatre—is producing ABFAB starring an ensemble of local comic actors. Directed by Christian Heppinstall. Costume Curator: Craig Marotzke. Makeup & Wigs: Diego Gomez. Starring Terrence McLaughlin as Edina, ZsaZsa Lufthansa as Patsy, Annie Larson as Gran, Dene Larson as Saffy, and Raya Light as Bubble. Also featuring Karen Ripley, Steven Satyricon, Allison Fenner, Marie Cartier, Randy Blaustein, J. Sykes-Iness and Nick Leonard.

    What: ABFAB Season One will be staged featuring the original six episodes. In October you will see both Fat and Fashion playing each Thursday and Friday show date. In November you will see France and ISO Tank playing each Thursday and Friday show date. And in December you will see both Birthday and Magazine playing each Thursday and Friday show date. WOW, my ticket buys me two episodes nightly!

    Show Schedule:

    Curtains:
    Thursdays at 8pm and Fridays at 11pm

    Th. Oct. 2: Fat and Fashion (with Allison Fenner as Bubble)
    Fr. Oct. 3: same

    Th. Oct. 9: Fat and Fashion (with Raya Light as Bubble)
    Fr. Oct. 10: same

    Th. Nov. 6: France and ISO Tank
    Fr. Nov. 7: same

    Th. Nov. 13: France and ISO Tank
    Fr. Nov. 14: same

    Th. Dec. 4: Birthday and Magazine
    Fr. Dec. 5: same

    Th. Dec. 11: Birthday and Magazine
    Fr. Dec. 12: same

    Foto: Jon Bauer (c) 2014 All Rights Reserved: Shown: Bubble, Saffy, Edina, Gran and Patsy. Left to Right: Raya Light, Dene Larson, Terry McLaughlin, Annie Larson & ZsaZsa Lufthansa.

story:
What IS Sitting Regal by the Window?

(For show dates click below!)
http://planetconnections.org/2015-full-productions/sitting-regal-by-the-window/
Sitting Regal is a one-woman cabaret show with a storyline rooted in my upbringing as an Egyptian American in DC and New York City. When I was a little girl my father lived abroad and my mother lived in various bird labs where she worked two full time jobs as an adjunct professor and researcher. I spent a lot of time with people other than my parents. 

Much of my time was spent between Chelsea's two public housing projects. In the summer I'd visit my immigrant family in the Muslim community of Germantown, Philadelphia. Growing up I spent much of my childhood with kids who unknowingly lived on society's margins. It was only as we grew older, that these margins became painfully clear. I watched as our experiences in the world turned from shared to incommensurable. 

I had the privilege of stepping into and out of the spaces that shaped me without having to experience the consequences those spaces conferred on people who couldn't walk away. 


In Sitting Regal I use cabaret to step inside the experiences and personalities of the people that shaped me. Sitting Regal is a lively, fun spoof of a child's idiosyncratic identity. I use song, dance and comedy to revive the ridiculous narratives I grew up between. But within this celebration is a deep sadness. Writing Sitting Regal helped me confront the confusion I had felt in losing friends to prisons and systemic cruelty. 

It is our responsibility to bear witness. How can our personal experiences inform us to become better allies? What do we see when we leave our homes to become part of this city's feverish fabric? What will we do about it? 

I want this project to include your voice.

Where is your window and what do you see?

Help me bring Sitting Regal to two NYC theater festivals this summer! Here's what it'll take:

$10,000 will cover the full cost of what it will take to put on five shows for Planet Connections in June and July and five to seven shows for the Fringe Festival in August. I need your help to make sure I am covering costs and fairly compensating my talented and dedicated collaborators.

Fringe Festival NYC entrance fee $700

Planet Connections Theater Festivity entrance fee $240

Plane ticket and board for Marc Ernest, musical arranger $1000

Set design materials $200

Set designer (two festivals) $400

 Lighting designer stipend (two festivals) $400

Sound operator stipend (two festivals) $200

Costume and body mic $160

Marketing materials (fliers, post cards, posters, program) $400

Director stipend (two festivals) $400

Transportation $100

Three musician band stipend  (two festivals) $1500

Rehearsal space (two festivals) $1000

Recording EP and mix/master $1900

Videographer and editor (two festivals) $500

Photographer $200

Advertisement space $300

LED Spot light rental $400 (two festivals)

           

We need your help

My partner in this project, Marc Ernest, is a Lebanese jazz pianist based in Beirut, he is credited as the musical arranger of this show because he took my songs and ran with them. He is a musical genius and without him I'd be nowhere.

Marc Ernest and I produced Sitting Regal by the Window twice at the Metro Al Madina cabaret theater in Beirut, Lebanon. It was so successful the first time that we were invited back! We were brought onto two national TV stations for our work. Beirut loved Sitting Regal, and now we want to bring it to New York!

We can't do it without you. 

Other Ways You Can Help! DONATE RESOURCES!

We can't all donate money, so  if you can donate a minute more of time to share this campaign on your facebook page or any other social media platform you have PLEASE DO.

Help us spread the word.

Here's what to do:

Step 1: Share this indiegogo page on your facebook page!

Step 2: Like my facebook page Aya Aziz at www.facebook.com/AyaAzizMusic

Step 3: Follow me on soundcloud at soundcloud.com/aya-aziz-music-nyc

Social media platforms do wonders for artists and I can't thank you enough for contributing to those little golden "likes" and "follows". I will treasure each one. 

Also, feel free to donate resources!   

- Any advertising space

- Paper supplies

- Any means of publicity!

- And, of course, come to the show!

Thank you for your time!! I look forward to seeing your lovely face at Sitting Regal by the Window this summer!
Book tickets today!
http://planetconnections.org/2015-full-productions/sitting-regal-by-the-window/

story:
Lyricist Michael Biello and composer Dan Martin have been writing together for 40 years - full length musicals, LGBT themed works, “performance art musicals,” dance/theater pieces, and many songs.  

I'm Jeffrey Lesser, the artistic director of Center City Theatre Works.  I’ve been thrilled to be introduced to Michael and Dan's work over the past 10 years and have seen several of their musicals performed here in Philadelphia and in New York. Each show pointed out to me what amazing writers these two men are. Last winter Dan performed an intimate concert of their songs at the piano accompanied by percussion and cello. Once again I was reminded of the beauty of their music and words, the emotional impact each piece carries, and the theatricality of the work. As I was sitting there lost in the music I realized that the evening should be the seed for something bigger, a full production of “The Biello Martin Songbook.” I was actually surprised it hadn’t been done yet.

I proposed my idea to Michael and Dan and they enthusiastically agreed to put together a selection of their work highlighting songs from their musicals as well as a few stand-alone songs.  Dan agreed to share the stage with 4 talented singers, acting as not only the accompanist but the narrator of the piece – sharing stories about the inspiration and craft behind the songs - as well as about his and Michael’s life together as life-partners and collaborators.

Mounting a musical revue is an expensive endeavor with ticket sales comprising only a small part of the funds needed.  The cost to bring the show to Philadelphia for 10 performances in April 2016 is budgeted at $14,000.  This includes theater rental, performers and production staff salaries, scenery, props and costumes, insurance, printing of programs and posters, and advertising.

Last November we raised some seed money which allowed us to secure a great theatre - The Drake on Spruce Street in Philadelphia for two weeks this April.  I’ve launched this Indiegogo campaign to help raise the remaining funds needed to cover the costs of mounting this production.  I hope you’ll consider making a tax deductible contribution to help bring the Biello Martin Songbook to the stage and to celebrate the wonderful music of these two amazing men.

­­

Thank you for your support!

Sincerely - Jeffrey Lesser

story:
WHATS THE MONEY FOR?

The money you give will pay for: rehearsal space, set design, lighting design, sound design, props, costumes, theatre fees, marketing - EVERYTHING that goes into making a world premiere play.

RISKS & CHALLENGES

What are the risks.....

While we firmly believe in this project and have a great cast and crew in mind who believe in it as much as we do - there are always risks! The biggest risk right now is that we will not reach our goal. If we don't reach our goal then we receive nothing. That is the biggest risk.

story:
Help Support Refuge

Featuring an original score by Shaina Evoniuk and scenic projections by animator Buddy Giguere, this production will showcase aerial rigging designs that allow the stage to shift perspective and engage the audience in vignettes depicting various lives affected by the housing crisis. Using rope and harness technique, aerial dancers Danielle Sexton, Azraa Muhammad and Helen Wicks will tell a story of the unexpected loss of what many believe to be permanent: their home.

 

Your contributions will help cover costs... and there's something in it for  you!                                                        

An Original Musical Composition, Midnight Movie Night ... at a secret location,                        and of course T-shirts and Pre-Sale Tickets!

While our previous projects have been self funded, our goal is to move towards creating a more sustainable art making process. With your help, we aim to elevate our production level and align ourselves with further grant based and civic support for future productions. As our side jobs support our performance careers, we can't quite make every dollar needed for the scale of this production. With the generous support of Dancer's Group CA$H Grant, we were able to pay for artist fees, and now with your support we can pay for the venue and final production costs.

 

About Us

El Circo Dia is a San Francisco based performance collective. Our mission is to strengthen the working relationship between performers, musicians and technology-based artists in order to cultivate joint artistic impact and cultural influence. In doing so, we aim to maintain the rich history of subversive creativity that has influenced the compassionate and forward thinking society of San Francisco.

This production will showcase rope and harness acrobatics with a rigging design that allows the stage to shift perspective, an original score by Shaina Evoniuk, and scenic projections by animator Buddy Giguere. Aerial dancers Danielle Sexton, Azraa Muhammad, Helen Wicks and actor Travis Santell Rowland tell the story of the unexpected loss of what many believed to be certain: their home.

El Circo Dia Performance Reel

 

 

 

 

 

About Refuge

Refuge; A Ballad for the Renting Class is a site-specific aerial dance that brings the urgent conversation of San Francisco’s housing crisis to the forefront and explores what it means for the city’s long established residents to be systematically evicted and priced out. The use of the Ellis Act alone has quadrupled in the past 5 years, evicting thousands of individuals who established San Francisco’s cultural, artistic and politically diverse society. Refuge aims to honor the lives of those losing their shelter while questioning our personal relationship to home.

 

El Circo Dia needs your support!

Here is where your dollars will go:

 

The Venue 

$3,100

The venue, Project Artaud’s Studio 124, offers deep significance for this production because of its 46-year legacy of providing sustainable housing to local artists. The studio's location in the Mission District and its proximity to San Francisco’s current eviction crisis adds poignancy to the production’s content while it's physical range for site specific rigging design is paramount for our aerial staging.

The price of Studio 124 includes an unprecedented 30 day rental. This residency offers extended time at the venue that allows the El Circo Dia team to install aerial rigging and lighting design as well as create sets and choreography on-site, saving thousands of dollars in theater installation fees.

The Rest of it... 

$2,200

Professional lighting design and execution will create a compelling experience  by transforming the studio into a immersive atmosphere. We have been offered a generous discount to achieve our goal of professional lighting by long-time Artaudian resident and production master.

Rigging is a significant and essential expense to staging site specific aerial work. The professional riggers support us to design and build a safe and versatile vertical stage.                 

    $4,500 Total needed:

  • $2,300 Venue Rental
  • $2,200 Lighting and Rigging

 

 

If we don't reach our goals... 

Remember those side jobs we mentioned? Our collective, El Circo Dia consists of a doula, bartender, trapeze artist, drag queen, acrobatics instructor, dancer, and taco slinger. We know how to lose sleep and we will find a way to make every penny of your contributions count towards the completion of Refuge. oh, It's happening. We simply aim to reach our deadline rested, uninjured and out of debt. Every dollar counts!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute dollar bills, you can still help.

Get the word out and post this campaign on your social medial sites.

  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Volunteer at the show! Dec 1-3, 2016
  • Share, re-post and send this campaign to friends and family who might be interested!

thanks!

Your contributions will help cover costs... and there's something in it for  you!                                                         
An Original Musical Composition, Midnight Movie Night ... at a secret location,                        and of course T-shirts and Pre-Sale Tickets!

While our previous projects have been self funded, our goal is to move towards creating a more sustainable art making process. With your help, we aim to elevate our production level and align ourselves with further grant based and civic support for future productions. As our side jobs support our performance careers, we can't quite make every dollar needed for the scale of this production. With the generous support of Dancer's Group CA$H Grant, we were able to pay for artist fees, and now with your support we can pay for the venue and final production costs.
 
About Us
El Circo Dia is a San Francisco based performance collective. Our mission is to strengthen the working relationship between performers, musicians and technology-based artists in order to cultivate joint artistic impact and cultural influence. In doing so, we aim to maintain the rich history of subversive creativity that has influenced the compassionate and forward thinking society of San Francisco.
This production will showcase rope and harness acrobatics with a rigging design that allows the stage to shift perspective, an original score by Shaina Evoniuk, and scenic projections by animator Buddy Giguere. Aerial dancers Danielle Sexton, Azraa Muhammad, Helen Wicks and actor Travis Santell Rowland tell the story of the unexpected loss of what many believed to be certain: their home.
El Circo Dia Performance Reel

 
 
 
 
 
About Refuge

Refuge; A Ballad for the Renting Class is a site-specific aerial dance that brings the urgent conversation of San Francisco’s housing crisis to the forefront and explores what it means for the city’s long established residents to be systematically evicted and priced out. The use of the Ellis Act alone has quadrupled in the past 5 years, evicting thousands of individuals who established San Francisco’s cultural, artistic and politically diverse society. Refuge aims to honor the lives of those losing their shelter while questioning our personal relationship to home.

 

El Circo Dia needs your support! 
Here is where your dollars will go:
 

The Venue 

$3,100
The venue, Project Artaud’s Studio 124, offers deep significance for this production because of its 46-year legacy of providing sustainable housing to local artists. The studio's location in the Mission District and its proximity to San Francisco’s current eviction crisis adds poignancy to the production’s content while it's physical range for site specific rigging design is paramount for our aerial staging.
The price of Studio 124 includes an unprecedented 30 day rental. This residency offers extended time at the venue that allows the El Circo Dia team to install aerial rigging and lighting design as well as create sets and choreography on-site, saving thousands of dollars in theater installation fees.

The Rest of it...  

$2,200
Professional lighting design and execution will create a compelling experience  by transforming the studio into a immersive atmosphere. We have been offered a generous discount to achieve our goal of professional lighting by long-time Artaudian resident and production master.
Rigging is a significant and essential expense to staging site specific aerial work. The professional riggers support us to design and build a safe and versatile vertical stage.                 
    $4,500 Total needed:

$2,300 Venue Rental
$2,200 Lighting and Rigging

 
 

If we don't reach our goals...  
Remember those side jobs we mentioned? Our collective, El Circo Dia consists of a doula, bartender, trapeze artist, drag queen, acrobatics instructor, dancer, and taco slinger. We know how to lose sleep and we will find a way to make every penny of your contributions count towards the completion of Refuge. oh, It's happening. We simply aim to reach our deadline rested, uninjured and out of debt. Every dollar counts!
Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute dollar bills, you can still help.
Get the word out and post this campaign on your social medial sites.

Use the Indiegogo share tools!
Volunteer at the show! Dec 1-3, 2016
Share, re-post and send this campaign to friends and family who might be interested!

thanks!

story:
'by wing, fin, hoof or foot'

is a socially responsive piece of physical-theatre that uses the simplicity and reliability of migrating animals to explore the complex and fluctuating rules of immigration, representation,  private narratives of public spaces and vice versa. Tension and unity are collapsed and expanded at the points where these migrations intersect. This piece is directed by Producing Artistic Director Keelie Sheridan and is a collaboration between The Ume Group and scenic/costume designer Valentin Peter Eisele, to run at the Church of Grace & St. Paul on W 71st. Street in NYC from June 2nd - June 24th, 2017.

The 2016-2017 Ume Group Ensemble & Guest Artists are Andrea Aranguren, Angela Bilkić, Annie McCoy, Brantley Ivy, Clara Kundin, Efrén Sánchez, Fiamma Piacentini, Jennifer Marinelli, Jorge Luna, Karina Sindicich, Keelie Sheridan, Laura Aristovulos, Miles Butler, Raphael Anastas, Sammy DeSimone and Yokko.
 

 

The Ume Group & Valentin Peter Eisele

About The Ume Group

The Ume Group is a New York - based dance / physical theatre ensemble dedicated to sharing traditions and developing new work. We believe that a good performance artist is constantly learning, creating, teaching, and performing. We work in physical disciplines ranging from butoh dance, gymnastics, yoga and martial arts to ceíli dance, clowning and commedia. We are hailed by critics for our “commanding, physically impressive performances” (The Village Voice) and “risky physical vulnerability.” (nytheatre.com). Our work has engaged audiences across the US, from Hollywood to Brooklyn. In 2015, The Ume Group celebrated our Five Year Anniversary at The Irondale Center in Brooklyn. In 2016, The Ume Group launched our first company-wide Social Action Projects- a series of street performances inspired by the individual activism of ensemble members.

About Valentin Peter Eisele

With a BA in Information Design, years of experience in Graphic Design and collaborations with several theaters in Germany, Valentin Peter focused on Stage Design in the MFA program at The Lir, National Academy of Dramatic Art, Dublin, Ireland. With a keen interest in creating haptic and visual experiences in the theatre space, he is currently working on Set and Costume Designs for the independent dance theatre company Backsteinhaus Produktion and the production house Theater Rampe. He combines different design approaches and experiments with creative techniques in all aspects of his work.

What We Need & What You Get

CASH FLOW:

  • $4000- stipends for our cast (an ensemble of 13!), creative team and crew
  • $2500- equipment, costumes and scenic design
  • $750- the temporary migration of our designer, Valentin Eisele, from Stuttgart to NYC, plus our costumes and set pieces
  • $750- Indiegogo fees & credit card processing

RETURN ON YOUR INVESTMENT

  • You've never seen perks like these. Our incentives for supporting this project are as eclectic and fabulous as the ensemble! From tickets & show swag to a shiatsu massage to personal training to a facepaint party to flute lessons, we're thrilled to share our talents and trades (and certifications). 

 

How else can I help?

Money makes the world go round, but so do lots of other things! If you're not able to make a financial donation but would still like to help, we'd be happy to have you: 

  • Spread the word! Please share this campaign with your network!
  • Lend a hand! We always have jobs for volunteers, including ushering, bartending, house managing, etc. Email info@theumegroup.org if you'd like to volunteer (and see the show for free).

story:
LIPSTICK THEATRE: 

Lipstick Theatre is Northwestern's only theatre group dedicated to tackling women's issues through performance and providing female theatre artists with opportunities for artistic growth and expression. The objectives of Lipstick Theatre are to produce dramatic works written by female playwrights, have strong female characters, have a largely female-based ensemble, or address women's issues. 

Wildcat Excellence Award for Outstanding New Student Organization (2015)
Wildcat Excellence Award for Outstanding Theatrical Performance (For Colored Girls..., 2016)

ABOUT THE PLAY: 

Written by playwright Annie Weisman, Be Aggressive is a play set to go up at Northwestern University on November 10th through 12th. 

Originally premiered in 2001 at the La Jolla Playhouse, Be Aggressive is a dark comedy about cheerleaders, growing up, femininity, and grief. 

Life in Vista del Sol, California isn’t always as sunny as it seems. If you listen close, you can hear the whispers between the cheers− there’s blood on the asphalt and head wounds the size of bocce balls. Determined not to die like her mother, Laura and her new friend set off to discover what it means to be alive.

We will not be able to bring this show to life without your help. The production is entirely student produced and funded, independent of the University, so only with your financial support can we get this play successfully across the finish line. All donations, no matter how small, are greatly appreciated and are tax deductible! With your help, the possibilities for this show are endless.

THE BE AGGRESSIVE TEAM:

Cast:

  • Laura: Rachel Covey
  • Leslie: Marin Nass
  • Hannah: Andrea Canizares-Fernandez
  • Judy: Katy Murphy
  • Phil: Daniel Stompor
  • Ensemble: Meghan Considine, Maya Pearson, Ellen Stevens, Julian Larach

 

Crew:

  • Producer: Hale McSharry
    • Assistant Producer: Talia Waxman
  • Director: Delaney Burlingame
    • Assistant Director: Elizabeth Dickson
  • Stage Manager: Faye Oyang
  • Props Designer: Katia Podtynov
  • Costume Designer: Maria Silva-Inclan
  • Lighting Designer: Sam Van Loon
    • Assistant Lighting Designer: Benji Solomon
  • Sound Designer: Camille Michelotti
  • Publicity Director: Megan Reynolds
     

HOW YOUR DONATION HELPS:

We are putting our money towards elements of the show including:

• Set: We're building the world of Vista Del Sol in Shanley Pavilion, including a system of platforms and curtains that will create the playing space for the story.

• Lights: Our lighting designers are working hard to bring the contrast between the world of the excitable teenage cheerleaders and the jaded adults to life on stage.

• Costumes: Costume challenges include outfitting a full squad of cheerleaders in appropriate outfits!

• Publicity: We are bringing this production to as wide an audience as possible on Northwestern's campus and in Evanston, because its story and themes can reach far beyond the Lipstick community.
 

OTHER WAYS TO CONTRIBUTE:

 You can support our show in a variety of ways:

• Share the Indiegogo link on social networking sites and with family and friends.

• Come see the show! We'd love to have as many people as possible see this incredible new work.
