story:
GHOST LIGHT

Have you ever been betrayed?

              Screwed over by a friend, a boss, a lover?  

                         Do you wait for "karma" to get them? 

NO! You want revenge. NOW. 


Even if you're DEAD.

              

GHOST LIGHT - a recipe for revenge

Take one part Japan's most famous ghost story --
       Add a handful of ambitious New York actors, 
                                 Toss in a soupçon of Macbethian plot twists,
                                          Pour all into Manhattan's most notorious haunted apartment,
        Shake well, and watch it bubble!


Written by award winning playwright, Carol Fisher Sorgenfrei. 

Produced and Directed by EMMY winner Penny Bergman.

Co-conceived by Penny Bergman and Carol Fisher Sorgenfrei.

YOTSUYA GHOST TALES, the kabuki (classical Japanese theater) play based on the legend of a horribly betrayed woman named Oiwa, was our first inspiration.  A perennial favorite in Japan, it has been adapted into at least 30 films and continues to influence anime and Japanese horror movies. 

MACBETH, one of Shakespeare's greatest plays, has some surprising parallels to YOTSUYA KAIDAN. Like Oiwa's faithless husband, Macbeth is seduced into evil by unbridled ambition and tormented by the ghosts of those he murdered. The supernatural is everywhere...


GHOST LIGHT fuses elements of these masterpieces to create a completely original spine-tingling, brilliantly theatrical new work. 

   

Funded by generous grants from the UCLA Academic Senate Council on Research and the Terasaki Center for Japanese Studies, we completed Phase 1: REFINE THE SCRIPT through a series of staged readings in New York and Los Angeles. Now we need your help to fund Phase 2: an EQUITY SHOWCASE PRODUCTION in NY.


          

Our Original Story

The year is 2010. Japanese-American actress, Keiko (Kay) Tamiya, descendant of the original Oiwa, gives birth to a baby girl AND wins a Primetime Emmy all on the same day. Her husband and co-star, Bryan Eamon Quinn, also nominated, loses out to his arch rival.  Kay and Bryan are riding high as America's favorite couple with an unbreakable contract binding them together --- love, devotion, partners at home and at work ...

When both are offered the leads in MACBETH on Broadway, Bryan's thrill at playing the role of a lifetime is dashed by Keiko's disgust at the director's concept for Lady Macbeth: a stereotypical, derogatory depiction of Asian women. Keiko rejects the job and wants Bryan to stand in solidarity and give up his plum part as well.  

What ambitious actor wouldn't kill to play Macbeth???        


The Collaboration

Although La Luna's Penny Bergman (Producing Artistic Director and Emmy winner) and Carol Fisher Sorgenfrei (prize-winning playwright) have each presented international hybrid pieces in venues around the world, this is their first collaboration.  

About Us

        

Penny Bergman 

La Luna's Producing Artistic Director is an EMMY winner for ALL MY CHILDREN (on the Directing Team for 26 years). Other credits: LIVE FROM LINCOLN CENTER, SAKURA and HANA - LEGENDS OF THE BANDIT PRINCESS (Circle Rep, NYC and USA tours, Edinburgh Fringe Festival: 5 Stars, THE SCOTSMAN).  Director of THE 39 STEPS, MOONLIGHT AND MAGNOLIAS; Director/Writer of charity benefit shows; DGA Stage Manager/First AD for ABC, NBC, BRAVO, Comedy Central. Trained with Kabuki legend Nakamura Matagoro, National Living Treasure of Japan.  


            

Carol Fisher Sorgenfrei 

Award winning playwright of 16 plays, including MEDEA: A NOH CYCLE BASED ON THE GREEK MYTH; kabuki-flamenco fusion BLOOD WINE, BLOOD WEDDING, Japanese-Israeli fusion THE DYBBUK/BETWEEN TWO WORLDS (with Israeli director Zvika Serper), and the kyogen-commedia dell'arte fusion THE IMPOSTOR. Author of UNSPEAKABLE ACTS: THE AVANT-GARDE THEATRE OF TERAYAMA SHŪJI AND POSTWAR JAPAN (2005). Her translations of plays by Terayama and other contemporary Japanese playwrights have been produced in the USA and Europe, and broadcast on BBC Radio. Taught at UCLA for 31 years, and is now Professor Emerita. 

Honoring Tradition: Our Journey to Oiwa's Shrine
Tokyo 2014

Carol and Penny traveled to Oiwa's grave to offer her flowers, incense and a lovely note (in English and Japanese). We humbly requested her permission and blessing to present her story, our way.  

This ancient Japanese ritual insures all is safe and secure on stage and on set. Those who neglect it risk suffering the wrath of Oiwa's ghost.  (Yet another connection to Shakespeare: the infamous "curse of the Scottish play.")

THE PAST AND THE FUTURE:
Ghost Light/Development: Phase 1
Staged Readings, 2014

THE PROCESS 

The UCLA Academic Senate Council on Research and Terasaki Center for Japanese Studies grants funded a series of 4 developmental readings: AFTERSHOCK:  A GHOST STORY (working title) at TheaterLab NYC (January), THE FACE IN THE LANTERN (working title) at Secret Rose Theater in North Hollywood (March), GHOST LIGHT at Ryan's Daughter/NYC (September) and a further revised GHOST LIGHT at Pearl Studios NYC (December). 
At each reading, lively feedback sessions provided invaluable, candid reactions to the script. In response to comments and issues raised by audience and cast members, we revised and rewrote, revised and rewrote, revised and rewrote. 

OUR FABULOUS ACTORS

Super casts in the 3 NY readings: Mia Katigbak (OBIE winner), Elaina Erika Davis, Mark Campbell, Beth Lincks, Jody Flader, Les J.N. Mau, Tsubasa Ogawa, Maggie Low, Mel Duane Gionson, Tiffany Villarin, John Patrick Hayden,  Veronique Hurley, Sue Kim, Mariette Strauss, Mike Chin and B.H. Barry (TONY winner).  
The terrific LA cast: Lee Boek, Laura Kai Chen, Terri Ivens, Traci Kato-Kiriyama, Emily Kuroda, Trent Dawson, James Patrick Stuart.

Ghost Light/Development: Phase 2

EQUITY Showcase Production, 2015 

Immediate Goal: Actors' Equity Showcase Production in October, 2015. 
Because this is a ghost play, we selected our performance dates for the Halloween season as the best time to launch this spooky, scary tale and achieve maximum exposure.          
It's great timing and the best way to create interest/buzz/demand. 
We will position the play in an active campaign; invite all the major players in the not-for-profit theater world. We're confident that once they experience the magic for themselves, these presenters/producers/decision makers will ask us to perform GHOST LIGHT in upcoming festivals, subscription series and other prestigious venues. 


BE OUR ANGELS --- THEATER IS ART!

Imagine the ghost of Keiko/Oiwa oozing out of the lamp... a Kabuki tsunami on stage... staging with great sets, props, costumes, make-up and special effects. 

Expect the unexpected when the supernatural invades our Off-Broadway playhouse! 

Be part of the creative process. 

As you know, producing a show doesn't come cheap. 

HERE'S WHERE YOUR CONTRIBUTIONS GO:

ESTIMATED BUDGET:  $35,000 for a three week run.  

Please Note: Actors Equity Showcase Code mandates total maximum budget, number of rehearsals and performances, number of seats and ticket prices.

Primary Expenses: Theater rental, Actors, Musicians, Honoraria to Set, Costumes, Lighting, Make-Up/Hair/Special Effects Designers, Movement Consultant, Stage Manager, Technical Director, Materials and Supplies, Additional Front of House and Backstage Personnel, Marketing and Publicity, Rehearsal Studio, Legal Fees.

Help us fund this venture! 

Consider GHOST LIGHT at its current stage as a "start-up" headed by experienced, professional business and creative personnel.  Super dynamic, highly original concept and script refined by the input of hundreds of audience members made the plot/characters/dialog/theme strong, clear and daring. Production values feature classic Kabuki stage techniques.


IT'S COOL IF YOU CAN'T CONTRIBUTE MONEY.
HERE'S HOW YOU CAN HELP:

Real estate.  Do you know a theater space in Manhattan or Los Angeles we could transform into a rehearsal space and/or theater?   Think outside the box: storefront, multi-purpose room, art gallery, showroom, Japanese restaurant.  Even a late night slot could work.

Grants. We are applying to Japan Foundation New York, Sundance and UCLA. Do you know of any grants/funding sources that would be right for this project?

Volunteer. Usher. Help in the box office, set construction, painting, costume maintenance. Assist with any specials skills you have: IT, social media. Financial "brains" and great cooks especially welcome.

Spread the Word.  Use indiegogo share tools, email, call, text your friends and family. Blog.

Social Media. Like us on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram or the "next big thing"!

GHOST LIGHT IMPACT

#Shakespeare #Kabuki #j-horror #anime #ghosts #revenge  #vengeance #fukushima # tsunami #emmyawards #tonyawards #macbeth #thescottishplay #yotsuyakaidan #oiwa #manga #kurosawa #asianamericanactor #nuclearpower #anti-nuclear  #macbethonbroadway #japantripledisaster #equality #Tohoku #japanesetheater #3/11/11 #BREIKO #1ghoststoryjapan

            On the completion of our run, we will make a contribution to the Japan Society's "Japan Earthquake Relief Fund" to aid organizations that directly help victims of the March 11, 2011 disaster. 

La Luna Productions is dedicated to creating new theatre work by women featuring strong female protagonists viewed through a unique artistic lens: fusing classical Japanese performance techniques (primarily kabuki) with Western theatre. The result is powerful, stimulating, and totally amazing. 


Additional Credits:

  • Mask Creator - Michael Rizzo
  • Poster/Flyer and Program Design - Gary N. Nomura
  • Website Creators - Peter Clem, Patrick Mathis 
  • Logo Creator - Spencer Potter
  • Video Editor - Patrick Mathis
  • Videographer - Chris Allison
  • Assistant Director - Blayze Teicher
  • Assistant Producer - Jules Kourtis
Make some noise about GHOST LIGHT!

Other credits: LIVE FROM LINCOLN CENTER, SAKURA and HANA - LEGENDS OF THE BANDIT PRINCESS (Circle Rep, NYC and USA tours, Edinburgh Fringe Festival: 5 Stars, THE SCOTSMAN).  Director of THE 39 STEPS, MOONLIGHT AND MAGNOLIAS; Director/Writer of charity benefit shows; DGA Stage Manager/First AD for ABC, NBC, BRAVO, Comedy Central. Trained with Kabuki legend Nakamura Matagoro, National Living Treasure of Japan.  


            
Carol Fisher Sorgenfrei 
Award winning playwright of 16 plays, including MEDEA: A NOH CYCLE BASED ON THE GREEK MYTH; kabuki-flamenco fusion BLOOD WINE, BLOOD WEDDING, Japanese-Israeli fusion THE DYBBUK/BETWEEN TWO WORLDS (with Israeli director Zvika Serper), and the kyogen-commedia dell'arte fusion THE IMPOSTOR. Author of UNSPEAKABLE ACTS: THE AVANT-GARDE THEATRE OF TERAYAMA SHŪJI AND POSTWAR JAPAN (2005). Her translations of plays by Terayama and other contemporary Japanese playwrights have been produced in the USA and Europe, and broadcast on BBC Radio. Taught at UCLA for 31 years, and is now Professor Emerita. 



Honoring Tradition: Our Journey to
Oiwa's ShrineTokyo 2014

Carol and Penny traveled to Oiwa's grave to
offer her flowers, incense and a lovely note (in English and Japanese). We humbly requested her permission and blessing to present her story, our way.  
This
ancient Japanese ritual insures all is safe and secure on stage and on set. Those
who neglect it risk suffering the wrath of Oiwa's ghost.  (Yet another
connection to Shakespeare: the infamous "curse of the Scottish
play.")





THE PAST AND THE FUTURE:


Ghost Light/Development: Phase 1

Staged Readings, 2014

THE PROCESS 

The UCLA Academic Senate Council on Research and Terasaki Center
for Japanese Studies grants funded a series of 4 developmental readings: AFTERSHOCK:  A GHOST STORY (working title) at TheaterLab NYC (January), THE FACE IN THE LANTERN (working title) at Secret Rose Theater in North Hollywood (March), GHOST LIGHT at Ryan's Daughter/NYC (September) and a further revised GHOST LIGHT at Pearl Studios NYC (December). 

At each reading, lively feedback sessions provided invaluable, candid reactions to the script. In response to comments and issues raised by audience and cast members, we revised and rewrote, revised and rewrote, revised and rewrote. OUR FABULOUS ACTORSSuper casts in the 3 NY readings: Mia Katigbak (OBIE winner), Elaina Erika Davis, Mark Campbell, Beth Lincks, Jody Flader, Les J.N. Mau, Tsubasa Ogawa, Maggie Low, Mel Duane Gionson, Tiffany Villarin, John Patrick Hayden,  Veronique Hurley, Sue Kim, Mariette Strauss, Mike Chin and B.H. Barry (TONY winner).  The terrific LA cast: Lee
Boek, Laura Kai Chen, Terri Ivens, Traci
Kato-Kiriyama, Emily Kuroda, Trent Dawson, James Patrick Stuart.

Ghost Light/Development: Phase 2
EQUITY Showcase Production, 2015 
Immediate Goal: Actors' Equity Showcase Production in October, 2015. 
Because this is a ghost play, we selected our performance dates for the Halloween season as the best time to launch this spooky, scary tale and achieve maximum exposure.          
It's great timing and the best way to create interest/buzz/demand. We will position the play in an active campaign; invite all the major
players in the not-for-profit theater world. We're confident that once they experience the magic for themselves, these presenters/producers/decision makers will ask us to perform GHOST
LIGHT in upcoming festivals, subscription series and other prestigious venues. 


BE OUR ANGELS --- THEATER IS ART!



Imagine the ghost of Keiko/Oiwa oozing out of the lamp... a Kabuki tsunami on stage... staging with great sets, props, costumes, make-up and special effects. 


Expect the unexpected when the supernatural invades our Off-Broadway playhouse! 
Be part of the creative process. 
As you know, producing a show doesn't come cheap. 

HERE'S WHERE YOUR CONTRIBUTIONS GO:

ESTIMATED BUDGET:  $35,000 for a three week run.  

Please Note: Actors Equity Showcase Code mandates total maximum budget, number of rehearsals and performances, number of seats and ticket prices.
Primary Expenses: Theater rental, Actors, Musicians, Honoraria to Set, Costumes, Lighting, Make-Up/Hair/Special Effects Designers, Movement Consultant, Stage Manager, Technical Director, Materials and Supplies, Additional Front of House and Backstage Personnel, Marketing and Publicity, Rehearsal Studio, Legal Fees.


Help us fund this venture! 

Consider GHOST LIGHT at its current stage as a "start-up" headed by experienced, professional business and creative personnel.  Super dynamic, highly original concept and script refined 
by the input of hundreds of audience members made the plot/characters/dialog/theme strong, clear and daring. Production values feature classic Kabuki stage techniques.

IT'S COOL IF YOU CAN'T CONTRIBUTE MONEY.HERE'S HOW YOU CAN HELP:

Real estate.  Do you know a theater space in Manhattan or
Los Angeles we could transform into a rehearsal space and/or theater?  
Think outside the box: storefront, multi-purpose room, art gallery, showroom,
Japanese restaurant.  Even a late night slot could work.
Grants. We are applying to Japan
Foundation New York, Sundance and UCLA. Do you know of any grants/funding sources that
would be right for this project?
Volunteer. Usher. Help in the box office, set construction, painting, costume maintenance. Assist with any specials skills you have: IT,
social media. Financial "brains" and great cooks especially welcome.

Spread the Word.  Use indiegogo share tools, email, call, text your friends and family. Blog.
Social
Media. Like us on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram or the
"next big thing"!
GHOST LIGHT IMPACT
#Shakespeare #Kabuki #j-horror #anime #ghosts #revenge  #vengeance #fukushima # tsunami #emmyawards #tonyawards #macbeth #thescottishplay #yotsuyakaidan #oiwa #manga #kurosawa #asianamericanactor #nuclearpower #anti-nuclear  #macbethonbroadway #japantripledisaster #equality #Tohoku #japanesetheater #3/11/11 #BREIKO #1ghoststoryjapan
            On the completion of our run, we will make a contribution to the Japan Society's "Japan Earthquake Relief Fund" to aid organizations that directly help victims of the March 11, 2011 disaster. 



La Luna Productions is dedicated to creating new theatre work by women featuring strong female protagonists viewed through a unique artistic lens: fusing classical Japanese performance techniques (primarily kabuki) with Western theatre. The result is powerful, stimulating, and totally amazing. 


Additional Credits:




Mask Creator - Michael Rizzo
Poster/Flyer and Program Design - Gary N. Nomura
Website Creators - Peter Clem, Patrick Mathis 
Logo Creator - Spencer Potter
Video Editor - Patrick Mathis
Videographer - Chris Allison
Assistant Director - Blayze Teicher
Assistant Producer - Jules Kourtis

Make some noise about GHOST LIGHT!

story:
Support You Are Frogs at Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2018!!! 

 

support the production team of You Are Frogs from California Institute of the Arts traveling to Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2018!!! 

Two frogs, Mabel and Garry, are ridden with the monotony of living. Until Bill comes along… a metal puppet, full of life and in love with Mabel? Soon all three are bound together by an existential crisis. Can two frogs and a metal puppet escape the restless human condition? Absurdist mask work and puppetry highlight this surreal domestic story about sex, sickness, and survival.

 

Visit our website: www.youarefrogs.com

Facebook and Instagram: @youarefrogs 

 

Co-Directors/Writers/Designers: Bora Kyung Min Lee and Colin Yeo
Cast: Nic Prior, Xcaret Estrada-Soto, David Blindauer
Lighting Designer: Jake Maize
Stage Manager: Percent Heewon Han
Mask Constructor: Natalie Mcintyre

story:
Slideshow Fairytales: William (the snowman)

Long ago, in a time, far, far away, when magic was science and science was magic (which was science [which was magic]), William had a problem.  He was a snowman.

A dark comedy read by its author, Catfish Baruni, and presented in the ultimate timeless medium: the slideshow.  Adult-type language and topics will be present (and magical [which is scientific]).

First Tucson, Now San Diego

Slideshow Fairytales was first presented at the 2013 Tucson Fringe Festival.  It was such a hit that everyone told William that he needed to hit the road and play the myriad Vaudeville theaters that dotted this fine country. Sadly, William discovered that Vaudeville died about 90 years ago and was about to give up his dreams when someone told him about the awesome San Diego Fringe Festival! He applied and was accepted, and then swore vengeance against the talkies (for killing vaudeville.)

But now, since William doesn't have a job (thanks, Obamacare), your generous help is needed to get him down San Diego way!  Here are the costs:

  • $40 - application fee
  • $675 - venue fee
  • $125 - insurance
  • $360 - travel fees
  • $500 - housing
  • $200 - props
  • $400 - marketing (postcards and posters)
  • $200 - emergency fund (flat tires) and reward costs
Total: $2,500
If we're unable to raise the entire amount, we will first pay for the venue and insurance. William's gonna have to sleep on the beach.  Catfish is going to have to find a wealthy octogenarian and try to seduce her (it's not going to work [thanks, Obamacare].)

The Impact

Have you ever had a dream, the kind from which you don't wake up screaming?  It was pretty great, wasn't it?  Don't you wish you could go back to that magical dream world and stay there forever?  Well, tough luck, pal, you can't incept yourself!

...BUT you can help Catfish's dream come true, and what could be more rewarding than that (and a mug)?

Risks & Challenges

Obviously the biggest challenge Catfish and William face is a silent audience.  Fortunately, Catfish is well versed in dealing with crowds who don't find him to be particularly funny (thanks, Obamacare!)  

Should this fish and his snowman fail to get laughs they will resort to:

  • Stripping
  • Musical theatre
  • Re-enacting that one scene from Jerry Maguire

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • If you don't have any scratch to spare, consider sharing this campaign with your friend(s)
  • Then be sure to tell them how worthwhile this campaign is
  • And how hilarious Catfish is
  • (He's pretty easy on the eyes, too!)
  • (Why, yes, he would like to meet your daughter)

And that's all there is to it.

story:
About us

I am Roman Baca, a classical ballet dancer who became a US Marine.  In 2005, I was sent to fight a war in one of the most dangerous places in the world, Fallujah, Iraq.  I returned, wounded by what I saw, what I did, and what I didn’t do.  I turned to choreography to heal, and started Exit12 Dance Company.  

Exit12’s work shares stories of our warriors, through narration and dance, so that audiences can help ease their burden. It also aims to ease the invisible wounds of war and the struggle to be normal again. Ghosts that can be vanquished by bodies moving across space to poems and music.

The Intrepid performance will allow us to reach new audiences in a venue that is a living tribute to service.   

What We Need & What You Get

Exit12 maximizes the impact of all funds raised, and is committed to telling you how those funds are used.   Our budget for the Intrepid performance is small, and it continues to be one of our biggest performances.  Our breakdown for this performance is:

  • Intrepid Performance Fee:  $280
    • This is the fee that Exit12 pays to perform.  It encompasses the stage, lights, sound, and presentation.  
  • Performer Honorarium:  $600
    • Exit12 pays our performers an honorarium for their hard work, talents, and stories.
  • Rehearsal Space:  $40
    • We have utilized a small amount of rehearsal space and time to prepare for the performance.
  • Administrative Fees:  $80
    • This covers email marketing to tell people about the performance, and the work to get the word out about the campaign.
  • All of this comes to a modest $1000!

Exit12 also wants to thank you for your contribution.

  • If you contribute any amount under $50, you'll receive a personal note and performance photo from Exit12, as well as a special thank you posted on social media.
  • If you contribute any amount over $50, you'll receive all of the above, as well as an Exit12 Challenge Coin or Intrepid Challenge Coin, and a special donor newsletter with insights and photos from the performance.  
  • All funds, even if we do not reach our goal, will go towards the Intrepid performance.

Our Impact

According to the Suicide Data Report from the 2012 US Veterans Affairs study, an average of 22 US veterans commit suicide daily (Kemp, Bossarte, 2012). In addition, U.S. soldiers experience PTSD at rates of 21 to 29 percent. 

Exit12 has been moving with veterans, and sharing their stories for 10 years.  In that time our supporters have reported:

"I'm not somebody who easily leaves my comfort zone," she said. "As Roman says, there's no wrong answer," said a US Army Veteran. "And if I do something weird, that's my thing that's weird. And it's mine."

"All these things help me to move into another world," said a US Army Veteran, "a world that's so different than I kept inside of me for so long."

Other Ways You Can Help

Any donation helps us reach our goal, even $5!  If you cannot donate, you can help by sharing our campaign with people that want to help promote healing.

  • Share the campaign on Facebook or Twitter using the share buttons.
  • Tell your friends, and come see the performance!

story:
Who Are We...

EGM Productions was founded by Emily Gillmor Murphy. The sole company mission is to produce new plays and we need your support to get our debut production off the ground. Monster? is a brave, honest and wild new play and we have assembled a world class team to bring it from the page to the stage. Emily has once again teamed up with director Karl Shiels following on from their massively successful collaboration in 2015 on the writer's debut play A BOY CALLED NEDD which went on to be nominated for the Best New Play Award by the prestigious Stewart Parker Award Trust in 2016. The stunning cast breathing life into the characters consists of  Aisling O'Mara, Michael Glenn Murphy and Jamie O'Neill and their world will be designed by Lisa Krugel and Eoin Stapleton. EGM Productions is thrilled to partner with the home of new writing Theatre Upstairs to present the world premiere of this production.

What We Need... 

We have been fortunate to partner with the co-producing house Theatre Upstairs who will cover the venue, rehearsal and pre-production costs. However, there is a significant shortfall in the production costs. The more we can raise, the more fully we will be able to realise the unique and unsettling world of the play and we need to raise at least €1,000. We’ve put together some fantastic perks, and hope they will encourage you to support the production. We will be hugely grateful for any help you can give.

The Impact Your Donation Will Have...

We have been honoured to assemble this incredible team of artists who all have excellent track records in their own rights with theatrical projects such as this and with your support, we know we can bring a beautiful and unforgettable production to the Irish stage. Our hope is that our run in Theatre Upstairs is the seed and that Monster? will continue to grow and run for years to come. There is a saying at Theatre Upstairs... No Root. No Fruit. We need your support to create and nurture the roots of this theatrical gem that we hope will flourish long into the future.

Other Ways You Can Help...

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help and support the production. We need to spread the word about this production and this campaign and we would greatly appreciate you sharing this campaign on your own social media

From the bottom of our hearts... Thank you!

story:
CASTLEREIGH THEATRE PROJECT

Castlereigh Theatre Project is a documentary theatre company based in Victoria, BC. Founded in 2007 by playwrights Francesca Albright and Jude Thaddeus Allen, the company creates verbatim-style plays that explore the relationship between artistic expression and the nature of true events: fact-based plays built on real-life accounts and storytelling that explore both current and universal themes.

GOD'S LAKE

Inspired by the mysterious death of a young Cree woman, God’s Lake is an original work of documentary theatre that address the issue of safety for young Indigenous women and girls living on isolated First Nation reserves. This production will stage the lived experiences of people from the fly-in community of God’s Lake Narrows, Manitoba. The play uses the words of real people, verbatim from interviews conducted over six months in 2017. God’s Lake is a collaboration between playwright Francesca Albright and award-winning filmmaker Kevin Lee Burton. Directed by Atomic Vaudeville’s Britt Small.

DEVELOPMENT and PRODUCTION 

Castlereigh is asking for your support for the crucial second phase of development.

PHASE ONE (completed): 6 months of research, interviews and writing by co-creators Francesca Albright and Kevin Lee Burton.  This phase is supported by the CRD Arts Development, BC Arts Council and the Banff Centre for the Arts.

PHASE TWO (in progress): Auditions, re-writes, rehearsal, and initial workshop production at the Metro Studio Theatre in Victoria BC January 4-6, 2018. Dramaturgy by Gordon Pengilly, direction by Britt Small, production design by James Insell, lighting design by RJ Peters.  The cast features Indigenous performers from BC and Manitoba: Nick Benz, Nyla Carpentier, Taran Kootenhayoo, Frances Koncan and Erica Wilson. This phase is partially funded through the CRD and the BCAC but requires additional support from the community.

PHASE THREE (developing): National touring and production.  We are currently in discussions with 2 major Canadian companies about presentation in 2018/19 .  We are committed to the longevity of this work and outreach to both small and large communities across Canada to maximize the potential impact of these under-served and often neglected voices.  This phase will be supported through guarantees from partner/presenter companies and we are currently seeking further support from the Canada Council for the Arts.

YOUR SUPPORT

We need to raise $10,000 to complete the second phase of this incredible project! Funds will go specifically towards the artist fees for the rehearsal process and the initial workshop production.

  • for $25 we will personally thank you in the program
  • for $100 you will receive a thank you and 2 tickets to the workshop production in January
  • for $250 you will receive a thank you, 2 tickets and a meet and great with the artists

HISTORY and IMPACT

Castlereigh has produced works Castle in the Sky, The Dublin Play (workshop production) and Ocean Fox. Castle In The Sky was workshopped in Victoria, 2011, and given a staged reading at Intrepid Theatre’s You Show. This was followed by the festival premiere of the play at Sage Theatre’s Ignite Festival and a subsequent provincial tour, including Medicine Hat. In April 2016, the play received its professional premiere over a week-long run at the Belfry Theatre Studio. Directed by Britt Small (Atomic Vaudeville) the play was well-received and reviewed.

Kevin Lee Burton (Swampy Cree) is an award-winning director. His experimental film Nikamowin (Song) received the Best Experimental and Best Indigenous Language Production awards at the ImagineNATIVE Film + Media Arts Festival in Toronto and went on to be named as part of the Toronto International Film Festival Group’s Top 10 list. Kevin has worked with the National Film Board of Canada; creating his short documentary film, Writing the Land, and co-creating Gods Lake Narrows Interactive which won a Webby award. Kevin was listed as Canada’s Top 20 to watch by the Victoria Film Festival in 2008. Kevin has worked as program assistant for the Native and Indigenous Initiative at the Sundance Institute in Beverly Hills, California. He is also a founding member of the ITWĒ and Mamaweyas Collectives. Trained at an all-Aboriginal training Program (Indigenous Independent Digital Filmmaking Program) in North Vancouver, British Columbia, Kevin has been carving a niche in working with his ancestral language, Cree. Kevin is originally from God's Lake Narrows First Nation in Manitoba, Canada.

This play, God's Lake, is a rare window into a First Nation community that is an essential and original part of the fabric of our Canadian story. God's Lake will shine a light on their lived experiences and amplify their voices. It is our intention through the sharing of this work to increase understanding and encourage dialogue.

CHALLENGES

Although we have received some municipal and provincial funding, public arts funders increasingly expect that arts organizations reach out to the private sector and individuals to contribute to project funding.  Also, public granting is a highly competitive field with demand greatly outweighing the arts budgets. Your support in many ways is the key to successful arts projects, especially for theatre which is born in community and comes to completion in community.

"The purpose of theatre is... making an event in which a group of fragments are suddenly brought together... in a community which, by the natural laws that make every community, gradually breaks up... At certain moments this fragmented world comes together and for a certain time it can rediscover the marvel of organic life ... The marvel of being one." - Peter Brook

Other Ways You Can Help

There are many ways to show your support for this project:

  • Help us get the word out and share this campaign.
  • Purchase a ticket to the workshop production in January 2018 through ticketrocket.co
  • Take out an ad for your business in our program. (CONTACT: francescaalbright@me.com)
  • Become a primary investor/executive producer with contributions of $1000 or more. (CONTACT: francescaalbright@me.com)

ACTOR BIOS

Nick Benz is an artist with Croatian, Irish and Mi'kmaq ancestry. Nick grew up in Ontario playing sports, riding horses and doing musical theatre but after high school decided to move to New York City to pursue dance. In the city Nick's studies focused on Hip-Hop, Vogue and Caribbean culture/dance. Some of Nick's credits in NYC include horseback riding for The Metropolitan Opera and various commercials. Nick is now involved in various local Vancouver theatre and dance projects and is a certified Gyrotonic(R) instructor with a special interest in physical therapy.

Nyla Carpentier (Tahltan, Kaska, French, Scottish) is a multifaceted performing artist currently residing in Vancouver. She is a poet, a powwow dancer and workshop facilitator. As an actor, Nyla toured in the theatre for young audience show Raven meets the Monkey King with Axis Theatre and performed with Savage Society's productions of The Boy who was Abandoned and Battle of the Birds. She was in The Flats/Les Flats by Ginny Collins, a co-production with Prairie Theatre Exchange and Theatre Cercle Moliere in Winnipeg, Manitoba. This past summer she was at the Blyth Theatre Festival in their production of The Berlin Blues by Drew Hayden Taylor and Ipperwash by Falen Johnson in Blyth, Ontario.

Taran Kootenhayoo is a Denésuliné and Nakoda Sioux actor, spoken word poet and playwright. Born in Cold Lake, AB, he is now based out of Vancouver, BC. He received his Acting for Stage & Screen diploma from Capilano University in 2015, is signed with Premiere Talent Management, and is in Full Circle’s First Nations Performance Ensemble. Past written projects have included work with the SOAR Aboriginal Arts Program, Cuywsti and Tom Cone’s Sacred Space Festival.

Frances Koncan is an Anishinaabe interdisciplinary theatre artist from Couchiching First Nation. She holds an MFA in Playwriting from the City University of New York – Brooklyn College and a BA in Psychology from The University of Manitoba. Her work as a playwright focuses on the reclamation of Indigenous heritage within contemporary landscapes, almost always includes the use of the word “hella”, and draws from the guiding principal of short Millennial attention spans. Her plays include Riot Resist Revolt Repeat, zahgidiwin/love, After the Ball is Over, How to Talk to Human Beings, The Dance-off of Conscious Uncoupling, and Little Red. In 2017 she was the recipient of a REVEAL Indigenous Art Award and the Winnipeg Arts Council’s RBC On The Rise Award for emerging artists. She is currently based in Winnipeg.

Erica Wilson is an Metis/Anishinaabe emerging artist in the Winnipeg theatre community, starting with theatre classes at Manitoba Theatre for Young People and its former Aboriginal Arts Mentor-ship program. Erica is now a current student at the University of Winnipeg taking her studies of theatre a little further, Erica has worked with several theatre companies including Urban Indigenous Theatre Co, Sarasvati Productions—where she has recently been on tour with their mental health project "Shattered," and in “Two Indians” for their FEMFEST 2017,--- Vault Projects “Riot Resist Revolt Repeat” and Royal Manitoba Theatre Centre assisting directing “Sarah Ballenden”. Erica has also been involved in reconciliation work with Canadian Roots Exchange as a youth Initiative 2014 in providing workshops in Winnipeg.
story_txt:
CASTLEREIGH THEATRE PROJECT
Castlereigh Theatre Project is a documentary theatre company based in Victoria, BC. Founded in 2007 by playwrights Francesca Albright and Jude Thaddeus Allen, the company creates verbatim-style plays that explore the relationship between artistic expression and the nature of true events: fact-based plays built on real-life accounts and storytelling that explore both current and universal themes.
GOD'S LAKE
Inspired by the mysterious death of a young Cree woman, God’s Lake is an original work of documentary theatre that address the issue of safety for young Indigenous women and girls living on isolated First Nation reserves. This production will stage the lived experiences of people from the fly-in community of God’s Lake Narrows, Manitoba. The play uses the words of real people, verbatim from interviews conducted over six months in 2017. God’s Lake is a collaboration between playwright Francesca Albright and award-winning filmmaker Kevin Lee Burton. Directed by Atomic Vaudeville’s Britt Small.
DEVELOPMENT and PRODUCTION 
Castlereigh is asking for your support for the crucial second phase of development.
PHASE ONE (completed): 6 months of research, interviews and writing by co-creators Francesca Albright and Kevin Lee Burton.  This phase is supported by the CRD Arts Development, BC Arts Council and the Banff Centre for the Arts.
PHASE TWO (in progress): Auditions, re-writes, rehearsal, and initial workshop production at the Metro Studio Theatre in Victoria BC January 4-6, 2018. Dramaturgy by Gordon Pengilly, direction by Britt Small, production design by James Insell, lighting design by RJ Peters.  The cast features Indigenous performers from BC and Manitoba: Nick Benz, Nyla Carpentier, Taran Kootenhayoo, Frances Koncan and Erica Wilson. This phase is partially funded through the CRD and the BCAC but requires additional support from the community.
PHASE THREE (developing): National touring and production.  We are currently in discussions with 2 major Canadian companies about presentation in 2018/19 .  We are committed to the longevity of this work and outreach to both small and large communities across Canada to maximize the potential impact of these under-served and often neglected voices.  This phase will be supported through guarantees from partner/presenter companies and we are currently seeking further support from the Canada Council for the Arts.

YOUR SUPPORT
We need to raise $10,000 to complete the second phase of this incredible project! Funds will go specifically towards the artist fees for the rehearsal process and the initial workshop production.

for $25 we will personally thank you in the program
for $100 you will receive a thank you and 2 tickets to the workshop production in January
for $250 you will receive a thank you, 2 tickets and a meet and great with the artists


HISTORY and IMPACT
Castlereigh has produced works Castle in the Sky, The Dublin Play (workshop production) and Ocean Fox. Castle In The Sky was workshopped in Victoria, 2011, and given a staged reading at Intrepid Theatre’s You Show. This was followed by the festival premiere of the play at Sage Theatre’s Ignite Festival and a subsequent provincial tour, including Medicine Hat. In April 2016, the play received its professional premiere over a week-long run at the Belfry Theatre Studio. Directed by Britt Small (Atomic Vaudeville) the play was well-received and reviewed.
Kevin Lee Burton (Swampy Cree) is an award-winning director. His experimental film Nikamowin (Song) received the Best Experimental and Best Indigenous Language Production awards at the ImagineNATIVE Film + Media Arts Festival in Toronto and went on to be named as part of the Toronto International Film Festival Group’s Top 10 list. Kevin has worked with the National Film Board of Canada; creating his short documentary film, Writing the Land, and co-creating Gods Lake Narrows Interactive which won a Webby award. Kevin was listed as Canada’s Top 20 to watch by the Victoria Film Festival in 2008. Kevin has worked as program assistant for the Native and Indigenous Initiative at the Sundance Institute in Beverly Hills, California. He is also a founding member of the ITWĒ and Mamaweyas Collectives. Trained at an all-Aboriginal training Program (Indigenous Independent Digital Filmmaking Program) in North Vancouver, British Columbia, Kevin has been carving a niche in working with his ancestral language, Cree. Kevin is originally from God's Lake Narrows First Nation in Manitoba, Canada.
This play, God's Lake, is a rare window into a First Nation community that is an essential and original part of the fabric of our Canadian story. God's Lake will shine a light on their lived experiences and amplify their voices. It is our intention through the sharing of this work to increase understanding and encourage dialogue.

CHALLENGES
Although we have received some municipal and provincial funding, public arts funders increasingly expect that arts organizations reach out to the private sector and individuals to contribute to project funding.  Also, public granting is a highly competitive field with demand greatly outweighing the arts budgets. Your support in many ways is the key to successful arts projects, especially for theatre which is born in community and comes to completion in community.
"The purpose of theatre is... making an event in which a group of fragments are suddenly brought together... in a community which, by the natural laws that make every community, gradually breaks up... At certain moments this fragmented world comes together and for a certain time it can rediscover the marvel of organic life ... The marvel of being one." - Peter Brook

Other Ways You Can Help
There are many ways to show your support for this project:

Help us get the word out and share this campaign.
Purchase a ticket to the workshop production in January 2018 through ticketrocket.co
Take out an ad for your business in our program. (CONTACT: francescaalbright@me.com)
Become a primary investor/executive producer with contributions of $1000 or more. (CONTACT: francescaalbright@me.com)

ACTOR BIOSNick Benz is an artist with Croatian, Irish and Mi'kmaq ancestry. Nick grew up in Ontario playing sports, riding horses and doing musical theatre but after high school decided to move to New York City to pursue dance. In the city Nick's studies focused on Hip-Hop, Vogue and Caribbean culture/dance. Some of Nick's credits in NYC include horseback riding for The Metropolitan Opera and various commercials. Nick is now involved in various local Vancouver theatre and dance projects and is a certified Gyrotonic(R) instructor with a special interest in physical therapy.Nyla Carpentier (Tahltan, Kaska, French, Scottish) is a multifaceted performing artist currently residing in Vancouver. She is a poet, a powwow dancer and workshop facilitator. As an actor, Nyla toured in the theatre for young audience show Raven meets the Monkey King with Axis Theatre and performed with Savage Society's productions of The Boy who was Abandoned and Battle of the Birds. She was in The Flats/Les Flats by Ginny Collins, a co-production with Prairie Theatre Exchange and Theatre Cercle Moliere in Winnipeg, Manitoba. This past summer she was at the Blyth Theatre Festival in their production of The Berlin Blues by Drew Hayden Taylor and Ipperwash by Falen Johnson in Blyth, Ontario.Taran Kootenhayoo is a Denésuliné and Nakoda Sioux actor, spoken word poet and playwright. Born in Cold Lake, AB, he is now based out of Vancouver, BC. He received his Acting for Stage & Screen diploma from Capilano University in 2015, is signed with Premiere Talent Management, and is in Full Circle’s First Nations Performance Ensemble. Past written projects have included work with the SOAR Aboriginal Arts Program, Cuywsti and Tom Cone’s Sacred Space Festival.Frances Koncan is an Anishinaabe interdisciplinary theatre artist from Couchiching First Nation. She holds an MFA in Playwriting from the City University of New York – Brooklyn College and a BA in Psychology from The University of Manitoba. Her work as a playwright focuses on the reclamation of Indigenous heritage within contemporary landscapes, almost always includes the use of the word “hella”, and draws from the guiding principal of short Millennial attention spans. Her plays include Riot Resist Revolt Repeat, zahgidiwin/love, After the Ball is Over, How to Talk to Human Beings, The Dance-off of Conscious Uncoupling, and Little Red. In 2017 she was the recipient of a REVEAL Indigenous Art Award and the Winnipeg Arts Council’s RBC On The Rise Award for emerging artists. She is currently based in Winnipeg.Erica Wilson is an Metis/Anishinaabe emerging artist in the Winnipeg theatre community, starting with theatre classes at Manitoba Theatre for Young People and its former Aboriginal Arts Mentor-ship program. Erica is now a current student at the University of Winnipeg taking her studies of theatre a little further, Erica has worked with several theatre companies including Urban Indigenous Theatre Co, Sarasvati Productions—where she has recently been on tour with their mental health project "Shattered," and in “Two Indians” for their FEMFEST 2017,--- Vault Projects “Riot Resist Revolt Repeat” and Royal Manitoba Theatre Centre assisting directing “Sarah Ballenden”. story:
Who We Are

Purple Crayon Productions was founded in 2016 by a group of then-high school students in the DC area working on a production of Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are Dead. This company has been a labor of love, and we've since produced two other shows, including one original work in the DC Fringe Festival!

We're excited to get started on our fourth production this summer, conceived and directed by Catherine Horowitz and Sophie Falvey, two of our founding members. This is also the first play we've produced to be cast entirely by audition, and we're proud of the outstanding group of actors we've found!

Production Costs

We're raising money here to finance our production costs, the breakdown of which is below:

  • Theatre rental 
    • Renting our space will cost $500 per day, over four days. This, in addition to other service charges required by the theatre, totals over $2000. 
  • Set pieces
    • We're hoping to include a variety of natural elements in our set for this production, including a layer of real dirt across the stage!
    • Chairs, tables, lamps, and a platform! We're looking to use free, recycled elements in our set, but we'll still need to buy wood and a couple of the pieces. 
  • Costumes
    • We have eight actors playing about 28 characters all together; that means 28 different costumes!
  • Props
    • We'll be looking for period weapons, as well as flashlights, lanterns, and cookware! 
  • Marketing and programs
    • Our wonderful artist, Raina Greifer, is currently working on an original design for our production posters, cards, and programs. As part of our Marketing campaign, we'll be printing and distributing these around the DC area!

How to Help

Donating any amount to this campaign helps greatly! Due to the demands of this production, we're looking at increased costs to our previous shows-- but we believe we can do it with your help!

Please feel free to follow or like us on social media:

  • Instagram: purple.crayon.productions
  • Facebook: @purplecrayonproductions

And don't forget to purchase tickets when they go on sale and spread the word!
